We did not have to travel with bullet train carrying all that stuff! :)

Stayed before at Ryumeikan and was excellent again, great value considering it's five minutes walk from Tokyo Central Station, North Yasue exit, fantastic if you are using the Shinkansen and JR lines like I do for business. Rooms are modern and I opted for a single A Discovery room, which has a larger bed and decent sqm for one person with complementary WiFi. Rooms are very clean and service all round is excellent. I did not book breakfast, which is Japanese style however their are plenty of restaurants and the usual fast food/coffee houses in central station or in Ginza 10-15 minus away or a few via subway or JR Yamanote line. If you are thinking of staying at near by Yaesu Fujiya then don't, Ryumeikan kills it for quality at similar prices! Check out their website if you want different configurations rooms for larger groups.

We selected Hotel Ryumeikan for our recent vacation to Tokyo based on Tripadvisor reviews. We decided to stay in a location that is quieter (compared to Shinjuku/Shibuya), yet conveniently located - near Tokyo JR Station and Nihombashi Subway. The 24-hour Family Mart next door is also very convenient for self-catering of breakfast and purchasing snacks and drinks. The Keisei bus stop right outside the Family Mart makes airport transfers from Narita very easy. Location is perfect. Hotel staff speak good English, and very helpful. Thank you for making our stay comfortable and enjoyable. We will certainly recommend the hotel to our family and friends.

i stayed here for 3 nights 4 days during a recent tokyo sightseeing tour with friends. the location is close to tokyo station - 10 min walk or so, and also right around the corner from nihombashi station (2~3 min walk). also the airport bus bus stop is close (30m distance) so i didn't have to waste any time lugging my suitcase around. most of the hotel staff spoke English well, which - based on my experience there - is extremely rare in Japan. there are lots of convenience stores, restaurants (all price ranges), coffee shops nearby too. it's definitely not a budget hotel.....but worth it. i would stay here next time go to tokyo.

Close to Nihombashi metro station, easy access to Shibuya, Omotesando and Asakusa! Tokyo station is just across the hotel. Perfect location! I booked a corner deluxe room with additional extra bed to accommodate three persons. The room is very clean, cozy and for Japanese standard I can tell it's quite spacey. We got three big luggages, and still got plenty space to move around.The water closet system also nicer than luxury 5-stars hotel I previously stayed. Tried the Hanagoyomi restaurant for dinner, its good and recommended although there are lots of restaurant nearby. Everything is flawless. I enjoyed everything in Tokyo!

it really is as good as everyone says. in some ways it was the nicest place we stayed in japan over 2 weeks. very modern, clean, quiet and comfortable. staff is very friendly and can speak some english. breakfast was primarily japanese cuisine with a bit of cereal/yogurt for those less experimental. if you book early you can get 30% off from their website making this accommodation very reasonable.

We stayed here because of location and a good deal from a travel site. The hotel is a short walk from Tokyo Station, the rooms are clean (if on the small side, as you'd expect in the middle of Tokyo). Service was good. The hotel kept our luggage for three days at not extra charge. If I find it to be competitively priced, I'll happily stay here again.

This hotel is relatively new and it shows. Rooms and facilities are very clean and modern. My stay was in a single room. Room amenities are good. The room also included an electronic safe which is reassuring to have. The bed was comfortable and the bathroom very functional.Price point was reasonable, especially for the very good location right across the street from Tokyo Station and around the corner from Nihombashi.The staff was very friendly and efficient.My only disappointment was the lack of any drawers or shelf space to store items unpacked from your suitcase. There was a single hook on the wall which I used to its capacity with 3 hotel provided hangars and three of my own.

This is a terrific place to stay. As you walk out of tokyo station yaesu central/north exit you wander left maybe 200m and there it is, a welcoming beacon in an at times, overwhelming city.The staff are really sweet and helpful and the rooms are spacious, with a city outlook . The rooms have everything you need and could want-i esp. liked the capsule coffee maker-making it esp. easy to self cater for breakfast as we chose to do.There are no extra annoying charges for water bottles etc and the toiletries supplied are very generousIt is quiet, the beds are firm but comfortable, The proximity to tokyo station makes economical travel around tokyo really easy(though a bit of subway walking!)-as an aside the one day metro pass is a great value and the return narita express ticket with the preloaded suica cards is a real bargain.Admittedly my Japan experience is limited to this hotel and a similarly priced ( inferior) hotel in Kyoto but the Ryomeikan met all the needs of a father and son trip to tokyo at a price that was reasonable (72k yen) for 3 nights in the middle of town in a pretty pricey country.

This is a lovely little hotel right near Tokyo Station, Ginza, Mitsukoshi, the Imperial Palace gardens - easy to get to and from. Lots of places to walk around. Reasonable. And yes! You get your own little nespresso machine -- just like being at home. Beautiful toiletries. Not a lot of whiz bang fancy Tokyo hotel stuff, but this is a charming, simple, convenient -- actually wonderful - place to be in Tokyo.

Tokyo... a different kettle of fish from the rest of Japan... the same applies to hotels!Whilst most of the hotels we stayed outside Tokyo were great value for money, clean and central in Tokyo we had both the worst and best experience ever, and that was only within 2 days from each other!We booked an Hostel (by mistake) and the experience was surreal... the bathroom out of the shining!!! So within an hour of checking in we picked up our bags and checked in the Ryumeikan and all was good again!A bed that gently rocks you to sleep at the sound of your own iPod? Yes thank you!A nespresso machine in the room with complimentary coffee pods?? Yes thank you!A super technological toilet? YES!!We were at the end of our trip in Japan so ready for good coffee and proficient with Japanese technology!The Ryumeikan is very central and well connected. The staff was nice, the hotel super clean and given the time of the year and the sudden booking the hotel was excellently priced.The Daimaru shopping centre just across the road is easily one of the best in Japan.We were lucky to stroll in Daimaru on time for the New Year sale day "lucky bag" and the atmosphere was buzzing with excitement, we ended up queuing for a "lucky bag" not knowing what was the content. Anyway it's Japan of course it was something good!!!We shall be back at the Ryumeikan, we shall be back Japan!!

Very glad to have stayed at Ryumeikan, and would definitely stay there again. The hotel is five minutes walk from the Yaesu North exit of Tokyo Station, and ten seconds from Nihombashi Subway line. The room was a reasonable size for a Tokyo hotel room, and had a fantastic bathroom - the shower is in its own glass 'cubicle' with a rainwater shower head. Japanese style bidet toilet was a great addition, however it was a bit freaky as the toilet would get 'excited' (start powering up) whenever someone walked past it or walked into the bathroom. Free WiFi was a major plus. The bed was reasonably comfy, but the pillows were a bit annoying - whoever decided wheat was a good addition to a pillow obviously doesn't know what comfort is. Free water daily. The room was very clean, and staff took great care in 'tidying' our belongings and making the bed each day. A very comprehensive amount of toiletries were provided. I would highly recommend Ryumeikan.

So I find this hotel and book the room as it is 5 mins walk from Tokyo Station. After the initial madness of Tokyo Station we make it onto the street and into the hotel lobby which is on the 15th floor (Weird) Very smooth check in we make out way to our room. I was sharing the room with a friend of mine and we brace ourselves expecting a room the size of a matchbox as I've heard so many other travellers complain about lack of room space in Tokyo.For 2 girls travelling together this place is a GEM! There was so much room. Even enough to spread our suitcases out.It was clean and tidy and extremely comfortable. Not to mention, the lobby has free flavoured tea with own tea cup and measuring spoons. Such a pleasant experience. With a Family Mart downstairs and a vending machine ramen store around the corner (MUST TRY) this was a pleasure to come home to at the end of long days exploring. Enjoy peeps!

This was definitely a very interesting trip for us. A bit of background about us as travelers and reviewers 1) We were suppose to head to Paris2) We were not very into Japanese Culture, and have no clue of the language or the writing3) But because we are young parents, and did not want to leave the kids for far too long and yet still want to enjoy a bit of lonely times and cool weather, and love autumn season - Voila, Japan it was for us.4) 1st ever trip to Japan for both of us Firstly, most of the things that other reviewers have mentioned were absolutely true. In general, there is almost nothing bad that I would even thought of worth mentioning, but of course, I need to let you know the uniqueness of this boutique hotel.Now points worth mentioning. a) The front desk executives spoke English and were very very helpful. We were welcomed warmly from them, and they have helped us hold our baggage before the check-in time. This gave us a bit of time (2 - 3 hours) to walk around Tokyo, We went to the gardens in the Imperial Palace which was 20 minutes away from the hotel, towards the West. b) The buttons in the toilets AND the room were very interesting. The funniest thing about this hotel (and perhaps other hotels in Japan - am not sure due to my limited knowledge of the city and country) was that the seat covers of the toilets are heated and warmed up. It lifted up within 1 second quietly attesting to Japanese technology. Just look at their hybrid cars (Toyoto/ Honda) - absolutely silent running engines. So the covers were not exactly comfortable initially, because we do not have them in Malaysia, but after a while of adjustment, it was very nice. should not talk about the rest of the buttons! (Laugh). In room 1417, the buttons on the control panel not only let out very soothing classical music from the bottom of the bed, but also let out a gentle vibration that stimulated comfortable sleeping. Yes, it was mentioned in the room menu and I kind of believe that, now. c) Value for money, especially when I monitored the prices for about 2 months prior to departure. I paid about USD200/night. It was a stop over for us. d) It's about 5 minutes walk to the Tokyo Station (East Side) where we boarded the Shinkanzen (Bullet Train) to other cities in Japan. Absolutely convenient and we did not even need the cab. The pathway to the train station was properly done up. I do not think my lugged luggage bags would complain. We also walked southerly and arrived at Ginza shopping district. e) When we arrived from Narita Airport via NEX, we accidentally came out from the Train Station (West Side) and because we are literally illiterate, we took a longer route round the station, to the hotel. That in itself took about 15 minutes walk. We walked towards the North from the red bricked building, turn right under the rail bridges towards the East. We kept walking, past 2-3 traffic lights, saw Shangri-La and Tokyo Station (scratched my head again) on the RHS and finally we arrived at the hotel safe and sound, next to a trunk road. If there's anything ill about our trip, it would be this and even so, I wouldn't consider this as anything bad as well.f) Very CLEAN and truly a NON-SMOKING room. That's a huge plus point for us, as we felt that a lot of Japanese smokes, especially in their restaurants. Another plus point which we really appreciated, was that the room had an air purifier. g) Nearby eateries both Japanese and Western styled, and 3 minutes towards the south of this hotel, there is a shoe shop with decent boots for sale. Excellent service there too! So in summary, I would recommend this hotel to anybody anytime. It's no fuss, simple, easy and probably the most centrally located (without paying through your nose) in Tokyo! Once we were near the Train Station, the whole of Japan was literally within our reach. Trust me, this is coming from somebody who did not like Japanese culture before - and we are truly converted. Thank you people in Ryumeikan for making our 1 night stay ever so memorable!

Hotel Ryumeikan is a very nice place to stay while in Tokyo. Nice rooms,friendly and helpful staff. Staff speak English. Very convenient location near Tokyo station. The easiest way to find the hotel from the station is to exit from the north Yaesu exit, turn left, walk a few blocks. You will see the sign on the building on the other side of the street. The Narita Express comes into the other side of the station (Marunouchi side) so you will have to cross through the station. We would stay here again. Hotel restaurant was good also.

I love this boutique hotel. We booked both the semi double and double room. Both are Very nice rooms with great amenities in the room and perfect location. Front desk staff is not the friendliest but polite. Good rate if you book way in advance!
user_name:
Yenny C
Jakarta, Jakarta Raya, Indonesia

review_body: Our friend from Tokyo recommended we stay one night before going to Kyoto by train. The Narita express line was down due to an accident, but it was easy to take the bus to Tokyo station instead. The hotel was just next to the bus stop - one minute walk.We had a 14th floor room with a great view. The room was very clean, comfortable, and we loved all the bathroom tech and little goodies. The staff was very nice and did their best to help us navigate. The hotel held our bags and we walked around the imperial palace (FYI gardens are closed on Mondays), and walked to the Tokyo fish market (20-30 min walk) before catching our train to Kyoto.Would stay here again - highly recommend!

The location was superb, very close to Tokyo Station, on Yaesu North Exit, side by side with Daimaru. We're family of 5, we stayed only for 1 night. We booked two rooms via email (corner deluxe with extra bed and standard, interconnected each other), big room for Tokyo, we had quite enough space to put our big and heavy luggages. Comfy bed. Japanese restos nearby offered good price (not too expensive).The reception staff, spoke wonderful English. Highly recommended hotel to stay in Tokyo.

The location was excellent and the people of Hotel Ryumeikan were even better - we had a wonderful stay, just too short! We booked on line and the 40% discount was much appreciated. Arranging to send our bags on to Kyoto was very helpful, and printing some instructions that helped us to get to our Kyoto instructions was very helpful - thank you everyone!

I stayed two days in this hotel and I highly recommend it. Firstly the hotel is very well located, close to all major train and subway, and you can visit the Imperial Palace which is 5 minutes away. I had a double room with a reasonable size (especially for Tokyo), the bedding is very comfortable. The bathroom is small but very practical and I really enjoyed all the goodies offered by the hotel. The room also had a Nespresso machine with a good choice of capsule. The hotel pays great attention to detail and offers many amenities to its guests like the little tea self-service in the lobby. I will return to Ruymeikan the next time I stay in Tokyo!

We found this hotel quite easily from Tokyo Station, which we caught a JR train to from Narita International Airport. If you have a JR travel pass, its free. Take the north exit onto Yaesu St, cross the road and keep walking north up one block. The reception and restaurant are on level 15 and all the rooms are between floors 8-15. This is a great hotel - the rooms aren't tiny (for Tokyo) and nicely appointed. Very comfy bed (with a menu for vibration and music instead of an alarm?!), good linen, kimonos, slippers, mini fridge and compact but great bathroom with plenty of complimentary stuff to use. Fabulous shower with amazing water pressure and toilet with all the gadgets (warmed seat, sensor light, auto flush, etc). The room has a Nespresso machine! Vending machines are on each floor and coin operated washing machine and dryer on two floors. The staff are really lovely.There is an English style pub next door (part of the hotel) that has draught beer, a good selection of spirits and food, a Family Mart next to that, and a starbucks-type cafe called Excelsior next to that. We had breakfast at Excelsior each morning - bagels and coffee- before hitting the streets. There are some restaurants around this neighbourhood (which seems very safe even at night) if you want to dine locally, plus the hotel has a nice looking restaurant on the 15th floor next to Reception. Tokyo Station is on the Yamanote line and most attractions for visitors are on this line. If you have a JR pass, travel is free. We were on and off the Yamanote line all day.Overall I would definitely recommend this hotel for location and general comfort.

Excellent location, friendly and helpful staff, close to Tokyo station and major metro stations, narita bus at door, light and bright, ask for non-smoking rooms if you prefer, local eateries closeby and good illy cafe.

A great place to stay, well equipped and welcoming rooms. Well Air conditioned and maintained.On the negative side my room curtains were drawn the view being only on to a building.The reception being on the top floor and the rooms are accessed by lift makes the hotel anonymous and discrete.

We really enjoyed staying at the hotel. Even though it is small, it is very well decorated, very functional, clean and modern, just love it. It is a few minutes to Tokyo station by walking. I will strongly recommend this hotel and will consider to stay there again if I visit.

It is unbelievable that hotel has only 1 baby cot available which was what we were told. it is also weird that japanese are well known for their politeness, which surprises me a little by the "coldness" and unsympathetic attitude of one female officer at the front desk. I explained to her that I needed a baby cot as my son was running a fever and needed a more comfortable space to rest. She just kept saying no, without any eye contact and totally expressionless. We picked this hotel because of the many good reviews and especially it has an award presented by tripadvisor.

There are many positives about this hotel, notably the proximity to the main Tokyo train station, very modern and comfortable rooms, a very nice buffet style Japanese breakfast, easy and discreet access to rooms from the ground floor with a room key providing security (not that its needed in Tokyo), decently high speed wired and wireless internet for ALL your internet enabled devices, and the list goes on. I was particularly impressed by the bathroom with its fully automated toilet with electric control over every imaginable function plus auto flush! Want the seat lifted? Just press the button. Room size is moderate by Japanese standards certainly plenty big for one in the single queen room I had. My main peeves were the lack of natural lighting for the room I was given - I had a window with a great view of the side of the next building 8 ft away - and the lack of any significant control over the AC. Even on a cool November evening the room was uncomfortably warm and the AC controls had no effect on anything as far as I could tell. The open window helped but also let in substantial street and construction noise.But certainly I would stay there again if I had a room with a view (any view would do) and some assurance of temperature control.

Went to Japan for the first time this year during Golden Week, one of the busiest weeks in the country. I only had a couple of nights in Tokyo as it was a layover trip before I flew to South East Asia. Picked this hotel due to the amount of great reviews it had on many websites and it didn't disappoint.The location was superb, right at the heart of Tokyo across Tokyo Station. Travelling to all surrounding attractions (North, South, East, West) was easy. Staff was attentive and room had all the necessities. The key is that there was access to anything and everything nearby. I'll be staying at this hotel many many more times in the future. Highly recommended!

I spent two weeks traveling around Japan and this was by far the best place I stayed. The location is fantastic, directly across from Tokyo Station. The room was small, which is typical, but very comfortable. They had great amenities too. The usual things, toothbrush, slippers, shampoo, etc.. Also provided was bottled water, snacks, an origami set and a stationary set that included directions to make the perfect airplane. While I was staying here I became very ill. When I inquired about getting a doctor, it wasn't possible because it was a Sunday. The front desk offered to call an ambulance. I refused and hoped I would feel better. The young lady at the front desk asked to come to my room, she brought pain relief, ice packs and a thermometer. She continued to check on me and bring me water. Finally a manager insisted an ambulance needed to be called and i was taken to the hospital. Thank goodness I went as it was pretty serious. I am so incredibly thankful to them for their care and concern. I will absolutely stay here next time!

My husband & I just got back from Japan & we spent our last night in Tokyo at Ryumeikan on the 15th floor. What a fantastic hotel it has everything that a 4 star hotel would have. Yes the rooms are small but everything in Japan is small :) Location is fantastic right across the road from Tokyo station & there is a subway station around the corner. Everything you need at your door step. Our room has a Nespresso machine not even the big hotels have that as a big coffee drinker that just blow my mind they think of everything & we loved that about the hotel. Toiletries you don't need to worry this hotel has thought of everything. Staff were great. Like everything in Japan hotel & rooms were spotless. We will definatley be staying here on our next visit to Japan. Also do not worry about noise being so close to Tokyo Station because you can hear a thing Tokyo is pretty quiet at night.

what a lovely hotel, right opposite Tokyo train station,arrived very early room not ready but we were able to leave our bags and go off to explore when we returned our luggage had been taken to our room,the room was great, large comfy bed good quality furniture, lovely bathroom,large soft towels,kimono on the bed and lovely free soft slippers, the room and bathroom where spotless and there where many good quality toiletries. the sheets and towels where changed every day if required but if you didn't want them changing or your room cleaned you could put a sign on the door and the hotel will give money to charity what a great idea I do feel it isn't necessary to have clean sheets and bedding every day so we opted for this option several times

After four weeks and eight different hotel stays in Japan, we couldn't have been more surprised or happier with the quality of the hotel. Ample amenities, comfy pillows and bedding, terrific location and quiet rooms, our only complaint is that we could stay only one night. Staff were helpful, friendly and professional. We already started recommending it to others. One caveat: breakfast at the hotel is a Japanese buffet, so if you prefer western breakfasts, you'll have to go elsewhere. However, there are plenty of eating establishments nearby to make this irrelevant (at least for us).

Stayed in a superior, spacious room on the 13th floor for 1 night only (the last one of our Japanese holiday). Close to Tokyo station but we needed a cab anyway, since we were travelling with heavy luggage. Loved the nespresso machine. Bathroom was rather modest but, as always in Japan, immaculately clean. Extremely friendly staff at reception. Lovely bathrobes (kimono style), lounge chair, finally a hotel with an English language channel!, easy for return to Narita airport the next morning. We stayed at Mercure Ginza hotel for 6 nights at the beginning of our holiday and found Ryumeikan a bit expensive compared to the Mercure Hotel.

The room was nice and clean but small. Enjoyed check in on the 15th floor. Staff was excellent and location was great as we were leaving Japan the next day. Will stay here again on our next visit. We checked out in the morning but were able to check bags as flight was n the evening. The location made it easy to visit a number of tourist spots before we left.

The hotel was conveniently located right outside Tokyo Station and was easy to find. The double room did not have much going for it, but I guess you can't expect much either... The room was clean. Unfortunately the room did look out at the wall of the building next door so there was no light and claustrophobic.The staff at check in and check out was very friendly and the price point (~$130) makes up for the negatives.

Staff was friendly and helpful, rooms are clean and quiet if a bit small by western standards. Hotel is located nearly across the street from Tokyo Station and Daimaru Dept. Store. The Imperial Palace is within walking distance as is the Mitsukoshi Dept. Store. The Tsukigi Fish Market is a short taxi ride away...between $10 to $15 US.

We arrived before the check in time, however the staff allowed us to check in early because one of the rooms is ready. The hotel is located near the Tokyo station. The price is much more affordable comparing to other hotels that are at par with it. We are staying in a double room and I love the bathroom design where the toilet(fully automated with sensor) is separated from the bath area(equipped with bath tub). The room is spacious and it has a air purifier that you can turn on as you like. I am impressed with the array of personal care items they provide(1 set for him and 1 set for her) especially when I saw a Shiseido travel set(replenished each day). For coffee lovers, our room comes with a coffee machine with free coffee capsules. In the neighbourhood, you can find convenient stores, food, karaoke and some night life just few minutes walk away.

Clean rooms, central location, everything you can expect from a city hotel in Tokyo. Main station can be reached within a few minutes. Also, very friendly staff. Would immediately recommend this hotel.

This was the best hotel we stayed during our trip to Japan. The rooms were small, but perfectly thought out (except for the somewhat transparent bathroom door), the beds were some of the most comfortable we've slept in, and the crackers, tea, and espresso in the room were delicious. We loved the complimentary loose tea in the lobby and enjoyed the lunch buffet. The most impressive, however, was the staff. Helpless with our nonexistent Japanese and the complicated reservation process for seemingly every nice Tokyo retaurant, we relied on them heavily, emailing many requests in advance. They managed to make us reservations at nearly every place (despite the repeated phone calls required), and to remember our complicated preferences, always calling restaurants on the first available day, even when that was weeks after our emailed request. They also watched our luggage during our numerous short trips from Tokyo and helped with everything else from directions to museums to tips about the ATMs. With the advance booking specials it is an absolute steal for the comfort and service you get.
user_name:
Masha720
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Excellent service despite the fact that I didn't successfully book a bus ticket from the hotel front to the Narita Airport. Room is clean, nicely placed items and thoughtful arrangement of items impress me. Location is just beside Tokyo Station, which is where you can travel to other parts of Tokyo. A round seat is provided in the small shower area is very thoughtful as well. One improvement could be giving the Yubisashi Pocket Map Tokyo English Edition directly before checkin for English Speaking customer will be very helpful. For me, as a English speaking customer, I have to look around the table behind the pillar and personally I found it pretty useful in Tokyo.

I booked 2 people in a "single" room and found it quite big enough for both of us. I was worried that the bed would be too small, however it was just fine (just don't expect a king size bed). Single cup Nespresso coffee maker, tea, snacks, bottled water, and ample toiletries included with room.The location was great - within walking distance of Tokyo station and a large shopping center.

It was relatively easy to get to the hotel from Tokyo Station. I was told to look out for a beige building but the exterior of the hotel isn't really beige. Just look out for the hotel sign at the top of the building. As we reached the hotel around 7 am, we couldn't check-in yet but the staff were willing to keep our bags for us. We went back again at 12:30 pm, hoping that our room would be ready given that check-out time was 11 am and the housekeepers would have had some time to clean the rooms. But we were told that we had to wait for another hour. I felt that this was rather inflexible, especially since we saw our bags being transported to our room before the hour was up. It would have been nice if our room had given priority in terms of preparation since we had reached the hotel in the early hours of the morning and had been wandering around for sometime with no rest.Aside from this initial hiccup, the rest of our stay was comfortable. The staff didn't have a good grasp of English, including the restaurant staff. But one of them was helpful enough to come to our room to personally show us how to access the English TV channels. He was also kind enough to check the TV schedules for us on the Japanese channels to see whether there were any sports programmes showing. Unfortunately, we didn't get his name but he was on duty at the front desk at 1:30 pm on 2 Oct :) It would be nice if the hotel expands the number of English TV channels as I saw quite a few non-Japanese guests staying there. We stayed in the Forus room so there was no view. It was a bit disconcerting at first to look out and see the wall of another building but we got used to the lack of view. The shower stall (no bath tub) was awesome and was a key reason for me picking the Forus room. The comfort sleep system was over-rated - I didn't see how it would help to lull me to sleep. The items provided to us (e.g. bedroom slippers) were of good quality. The hotel was close to Tokyo Station and another subway station (name of which I cannot remember now) so in terms of travelling around and from Tokyo, it was convenient. There were also eateries, Starbucks and Takashimaya nearby so we felt relatively safe walking back at night. All in all, if I do go back to Tokyo, I would consider staying here again.

I stayed at this hotel for a total of 9 nights from late September, having chosen it for its proximity to Tokyo station and the positive comments I had read about it. Before commenting on the hotel, I have to add that I lived in Japan for many years, I speak the language and know a lot about the country (I went to college and worked in Japan), and now I came back to this country after an absence of almost 3 years. Now, back to the hotel, I have to say my expectations were not high, but not low either, having read the comments of previous users, and basically what I wanted from this hotel was decent service and a roof above my head while travelling around Tokyo with a friend (I booked 2 identical rooms, single). Trying to be as objective as I can, I did not enjoy the experience of staying at this hotel for the following reasons: 1)The room was simply too small; while I knew this beforehand, I found the price too high given the very very small space. In other words, the room may have been acceptable but only for a lower price given its size. Also, or even worse, the room faced a brown or beige building so it felt like a prison, really. If I tried a bit harder I may have been able to touch the wall of the opposite building. As I said, I stayed for 9 days at Ryumeikan, but this period was broken into two periods (2 and 7 days), having travelled in Japan in between. After the first 2 days, I asked the staff to get me a normal room with some view, ready when I get back for the second stay. But upon checking in again, I had the same problem and I complained…it was really hard to make them yield, I was told umpteen times it was not possible, but in the end I got very angry and told them that I can get a similar room facing a wall in a cheap business hotel like Toyoko Inn, but it would not cost me 200 dollars but 50 dollars. At last, after 10 minutes of negotiations and anxiety, the front desk lady told me she would call me back in 10 minutes (probably she went to escalate the issue to the higher manager) and in the end I got a room with a view on the 13th floor (this one was on the 8th floor). So in the end, it WAS possible to get a better room, despite all the talk that it was impossible.2)They asked for full payment in advance. When I checked in I had the option to pay by credit card or by cash; usually the hotels in Japan ask for your credit card and take a copy upon checking in, using it only if you disappear, but otherwise they wait until check-out and then they ask you if you want to settle by CC or in cash; at Ryumeikan, it was all upfront payment; 3)I included breakfast in my room package, and so I ate every day at the buffet restaurant on the 15th floor – the meal was identical every day, and by the 5th day I was getting tired of the choices available; also I found the price too high, basically 2500 JPY per person, I am sure the price of what I ate every morning did not surpass 800 JPY. Furthermore, on the last day I had to leave at 7 AM, so could not have the breakfast there (buffet opens at 7 AM), so I asked for a refund (why waste 50 bucks?) but they told me “impossible”; however, they stamped by breakfast tickets to be able to use them “next time”…I found this rather insulting and idiotic. Who knows when I will come back next time and what makes them so sure I will use their hotel? Apart from these points, the hotel was clean and very close to the station. The shower had good pressure, the toilet very clean and all necessary amenities available. The staff were very polite, but then again this is how they are everywhere in Japan, there was nothing special about Ryumeikan in this sense.All in all, I would not recommend this hotel for more than 1-2 nights. I think it should be good for people who want to be out all day and have a place to sleep at the end of a long day. I paid almost 20,000 JPY per night, but I would say the fair value of the room is closer to 10,000 JPY. But then again, prices are generally very high in Japan, so I had the option between a cheap and depressing business hotel of about 5000 JPY, Ryumeikan, or hotels like Hyatt or Shangri-La that cost at least 400 dollars per night. Given the choices available, Rymeiukan then is “relatively” cheap.

We stayed twice at Hotel Ryumeikan on our recent trip to Japan, at the beginning for 4 nights from 22/9 and at the end of 1 on 5/10/2013. It is a fantasic base for a Japanese holiday. We had the same double room, western + Japanese style room which was large by Japanese standards, extremeky comfortable and the amenities were exceptional. All the staff went out of their way to help us.

We only had 1 night around Tokyo Station area and based on the glowing reviews for this hotel, we decided to book this. We were certainly not disappointed from the moment we stepped into the lobby on the top floor to when we got to our room and was greeted with the much anticipated Nespresso machine ;)This being smack in the middle of the business districy of Marunouchi and Yaesu, the lobby on the top floor had impressive views overlooking the urban surroundings. Very nice touches in the various teas that guests could imbibe while waiting for check-in or out, both of which were hassle-free and quick.We were a bit worried that the Forus Semi-Double that we booked from Agoda at USD190, would be a really tight squeeze but it was actually okay. So we bumped shoulders a bit but the little things that make a hotel memorable more than made up for the squeeze. Firstly, the Nespresso machine with the 9 capsules beckoned and if you are a coffee addict, the smell of brewing coffee in the room would surely make your day. So I figured out what the whole "designed for comfort sleep" meant when I fiddled around with the various controls on my side of the semi-double bed. Ambient, dimmed lighting, soothing spa music and gentle vibrations at your feet will get you into sleep mode fast, unless you drank all of the 9 Nespresso capsules. Other thoughtful touches included 2 sets of yukata (Japanese robes), fluffy slippers and toe spongies for the ladies who need to touch up their nail polish. The bathroom came with rainforest shower and massage jets and there was even a swivel stool to sit on in case you got tired of standing! No view, but really I don't think you need it as you will be more engrossed with the sleep modules after the hot shower. Would definitely come back here again if I had to stay around Tokyo Station. Just to point out though that from Tokyo Station, make sure you find the Yaesu North Exit. The hotel is on the opposite side of the road on the left, past the Family Mart and Excelsior Cafe.

On arrival, we were immediately greeted by staff and made to feel special. I was surprised by the large size of the room; I had heard stories about hotel rooms in Japan being tiny. This room was quite similar to a standard-sized room you would find in the U.S., and we had booked the lowest-priced double. The room had lots of extra amenities such as comfortable robes and pajamas, origami paper and instructions, funky postcards, all of which were a nice touch. The toilet had all the gadgets one expects in Japan, although it was a bit surprising the first time the toilet lid went up on its own. Overall, I was extremely impressed and wish we would have been in Tokyo for more than one night.

We booked a "universal" room but was upgraded to a standard twin. We were pleasantly surprised at how spacious the room was. The twin beds were very comfortable. The bathroom was so smartly outfitted that we didn't mind that it was small. The best part was the amenities, which were nicely tucked away in drawers in the bathroom. I was thrilled with the Shiseido makeup remover, cleaning foam and creams. Men have their own shiseido stuff! Our room was quiet even though it was near the elevators. The proximity to Tokyo station made this a top choice. The Maronuchi subway station is just a block away. Please remember the subway entrance/exit name or number or else you may end up walking a few blocks to get to the right place. Tokyo's underground is a whole city in itself!. If you crave Italian food, there is one with Japanese name only at the end of the block where the hotel is (towards Tokyo station) Surprisingly good Italian food. Cash only.

Very conveniently located across from the Tokyo station, right next to the airport bus stop and only 15 minutes away from the Imperial Palace, surrounded by bars, convenient stores and restaurants, the Ryumeikan is a real find. We decided to book the deluxe corner room (which is great value if you can book a few months in advance) and it was perfect. Beautifully furnished, spacious, quiet and light and with a high tech toilet! It was a wonderful bedroom to return to after a day's sightseeing.The staff were all courteous, helpful and very welcoming and all spoke perfect English. For a Scot, I was surprised and delighted that I could have haggis and all sorts of British fare in the London Pub on the ground floor.If you going to Tokyo, I recommend that you order your room now at the Ryumeikan for great value, great location and great service.

We stayed at Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo twice when we were in Tokyo. The hotel offers very reasonable hotel price in the central Tokyo and offers clean room and convenient location. The hotel is only 5 minutes walk from Tokyo Station, which can reach to any where by JR trains. Though the hotel room is very small, Tokyo is an expensive city so it is not a big deal for us. The customer services are excellent. One time the receptionist helped us move the luggages from the storage area to the lift and bowed at us when we were about to walk into the lift. In Western World, people would expect tips for this service. We tried to offer the guy tips and he rejected. He said that it was his duty to make sure we had a good stay with the hotel. We were shocked but happy to hear it. The hotel has one nice restaurant which offers yummy wagyu A5 beef and tuna at affordable prices. You must try A5 beef and tuna in Japan because you will not be able to try them elsewhere.

My sister and I booked this hotel based on Trip Advisor reviews and we were not disappointed! Check in went smooth with a very friendly staff. When we would get into the elevator one of the people working the front would rush behind us and stay in a full 90 degree bow until the elevator doors shut! Talk about service!There were free waters replenished in the room daily. We used these to make our nespresso coffees every morning. I am a coffee snob and these were delicious!There were free Japanese post cards that we took advantage of in the lobby.We are somewhat high maintenance when it comes to soap/shampoo/hairdryers - but we were thoroughly happy with the products they provided! They even provided free shaving cream/razor! The shower had excellent pressure and hot water every morning. Also, free wifi, which is not easy to come by in Tokyo. We also rented a Japanese cell phone and pocket wifi through, "Rentafone Japan". This package was waiting for us upon check in - which we had arranged for through Rentafone. There are tons of udon うどん, ramen らめん, and tenpura 天ぷら restaurants within walking distance. Not to mention cute cafes with inexpensive, "morning sets"。Which include a sandwich and coffee (or something similar. Cafe Lattes were the absolute best wherever we went!!Clearly, we loved this hotel! In addition, it was so conveniently located across the street from Tokyo Station! Just take the Yaesu central or north exit and cross the street and walk north. The Hotel Ryumeikan will be on your right just past the Excelciar Cafe.Stay at this hotel!! You won't be disappointed! Also, makes for a great location to take trains all over Tokyo to see the sights!! Also, all the Shinkansen bullet trains leave from this station and the NEX goes directly there from Narita.どおもありがとうございます ホテル リュメイカン。 楽しかった！！ あなたたち和一番 いい です！

Have stayed at many hotels in Japan during my annual, and sometimes twice annual, visits to my favorite country in the world. Based on my criteria for choosing an hotel, which are price, location (can't beat its closeness to Tokyo Station and its underground food streets and the food halls of the Daimaru, Takashimaya, and Mitsukoshi Department Stores), and quietness, the Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo ranks not only as my favorite hotel in Tokyo, but my favorite hotel in the world. Am looking forward to booking my next stay at the hotel for spring next year.

If you are arriving by train from the airport as we were Tokyo central station can be a challenge. It is huge and it took a while to find the Yaesu north exit however once found and onto the street it was easy to find the hotel about 200 metres to the left on the other side of the road.The hotel is very classy with a clean feel about it. The reception staff were very friendly and had a reasonable grasp of English. The room we had was small and although I booked a double room the bed was up against the wall on one side. When I queried this they said it was a double room. only staying one night I wasn't about to argue but climbing down the bed in the middle of the night is not something I would expect of a double room. Everything although small was classy, the fittings, the toiletries, and the snacks and water provided.The bathroom was exceptional as was the toilet. What is it about the Japanese and toilets?It seemed to have a mind of its own and came to attention as soon as you got near to it.The immediate area is dominated by the massive railway shopping centre with lots of eateries and shops. Further up the road under the large corporate buildings there are restaurants and more shops. The other side of the railway station is the Imperial Palace. There is a walkway through without having to buy a train ticket.Something to be aware of if visiting Tokyo for the first time, navigation can be a challenge with street names being in Japanese and communication without Japanese language skills can be difficult. As always you tend to muddle though and get to where you need to go one way or the other.

Perfect place to stay for our first visit to busy Tokyo!We asked at the Tokyo Station Info where the hotel was.Take the Yaesu side of the station - Central Exit - and turn left. Some of the building has a beige coloring, so if you look for that - the rest is easy. Cross the road and walk 5 minutes! Lovely lobby on 15th floor - very pleasant staff and accommodating - keeping our luggage while we went exploring and having it in our room when we arrived back. (We knew we had arrived early). Tea and water was available in a very attractive sitting area. The restaurant is there as well. Although it looked delicious, the breakfast menu was more than we needed so we went close by for a coffee and sandwich. Staff gave ample help with how to get to some of the sights around, with only a 5 minute walk back to the station for our commute.Loved our very attractive room and lovely bathroom. WIFI was excellent.We only stayed one day as were leaving for Nikko, following the "Japan by Rail" itinerary! Easy to get back to the station! Stay longer if you can!

Friendly staff, great service and location~ It's unbelievable, friendly staff that spoke well english, and very helpful. 京成巴士到成田機場就在樓下(這次麻煩櫃台幫忙電話預訂京成巴士(兩日前), 再到樓下全家機器輸入confirmation no. 和電話, 全家櫃台繳錢即可, 服務人員非常友善...非常推薦的飯店 :-} )

5 minutes from tokyo station ,nice room with elegant&cosy environment.Plus free WIFI and prefessional staff. Suggest people who visit Tokyo the first place live in Tokyo Station area (better commute) and consider this hotel.

Great stay in this hotel. The location was fantastic, two minute walk to Tokyo station. Not the best area for if you like going out partying at night though. We stayed at the beginning of our Japan holiday for five nights and hadn’t booked anywhere to stay for when we returned to Tokyo after traveling throughout Japan but after the first two nights here I knew we had to come back! We stayed in a Forus room. The room had an extensive range of toiletries including Shiseido moisturisers and a Nespresso machine with four different flavoured coffees. Also included was four bottles of water, packets of chips and flavoured teas. All of these items were replenished daily. The room itself was small. The bed was fantastic (on the small side though), the bed had a music, lighting and vibration function to put you to sleep at night. You could also plug your ipod into the bed and play your music through the speakers. The toilet possessed every function imaginable – a sensor for automatic flushing, bidet, dryer, seat heater. None of it was in English though so it was through trial and error to discover which button did what. The hotel had only one English TV station – BBC (I think) and free Wi-fi. Didn’t eat at the hotel restaurant so can’t comment on that but ate and had drinks at pub downstairs (The London Rose?) and it was honestly the WORST food I had in Japan so I wouldn’t recommend going there. We booked the first time 40 days in advance and received 40% off the room rate. The second time I booked over 10 day in advance and received 20% off the room rate. This was the only hotel I stayed in Japan I found that actually charged my credit card before my stay (which is usual practice for hotels in Australia). Staff were friendly and helpful. Just a note the hotel has laundries on the smoking floors and this is where the alcohol vending machines are. The non-smoking floors have only soft drink vending machines. Overall I highly recommend staying at Hotel Ryumeikan.

Fantastic hotel only a couple of minutes from Tokyo Station (good instructions for getting from the station to hotel are on the Hotel web site).We stayed in room 1412. A double room located at the end of a corridor. The room map on the back of the door showed this room was a little larger than a number of others on the floor.Pros:Modern RoomVERY Clean - including the bathroomQuietCoin Laundry on a number of floorsLocation was excellent, also close to a number of subway linesCons:None of any note.

Modern hotel just a few minutes walk from Tokyo station and a metro station. Really good value for money for a central hotel in Tokyo. Rooms were just about big enough and the staff were extremely welcoming and helpful. Great hotel!

Very good hotel only two minutes walk from Tokyo station. The rooms were small, but perfect for one person, and it had all facilities I needed. The breakfast was traditional Japanese and very good, and the view from the restaurant was excellent.

Japanese hospitality at its maximum expression. Helpful and friendly staff. My room was very small (even compared to Tokio's standards) but even so I did not missed any of the usual amenities. Excellent location and communication, a lot of restaurants close to the hotel.

We staying in one of the new korus rooms (after a terrible night in the semi double room of 17 sq m)Overall a much larger room which had most of the things we needed. However the room had some significant drawbacks which after significant investment were a disappointment. Firstly the bed which as a small 4'6" double was woefully small as a king or even a queen would have been appropriate for a room costing over £150 a night. Secondly the television offered 4 channels of european tv including BBC World. Sadly when we tried it was offering a pre defined audio track of jazz and no explanation of the lack of other language channels which if working would have made the world of difference for non japanese speakers.The lighting and audio system were billed as a new way of experiencing sleep and relaxation. Connecting my iphone to the system would only produce audible sound at maximum volume and this was poor quality and distorted. The lighting which I'd hoped would be all LED was a mixture of this and CFL low energy bulbs incapable of dimming or providing the relaxing evening atmosphere promised.The highlight (bemusingly the expensive item) is the toilet which auto flushes and produces every trick from a sliver remote control. Some english language help would avoid embarrasing flushes and water works. Overall the bathroom was good however a cheap shower wall material still makes it feel like a pre built installed system. Some tiles or real stone would make a world of difference here.So apart from location we wouldn't recommend this hotel. A shame as it gets so much of the little things wrong but tries so hard in other ways.

Of all the hotels, I stayed in Tokyo Hotel Rymeikan is the best . Staffs are very kind and helpful at all times. Location is great and all the amenities are within a reach.I love everything at Hotel Ryumeikan and dfinitely I will stay there again.

Staff great! Extremely helpful at all times! Perfect location, 5 minutes from JR station, 5 minutes to subway! Felt very safe at all times. 5 stars !! There are plenty of places to eat around hotel and at the JR station. The department store at the JR station has a wide variety of food. If you dont's like local there is an excellent Mcdonald's in the station.

We stayed here for one night. The lobby is on the 15th floor and has a great view of tokyo station. It is a 5 mins walk from tokyo station so that's very convenient. There is also a family mart at the ground level!Rooms were clean and hotel was very quiet.Would stay here again.

This property is just across the road from Tokyo Train Station so the location is very convenient for getting around Japan's capital. From the airport there is a train to Tokyo Station that costs $30.And takes about an hour. There is also a bus that costs $10 that will take considerably longer at most times of the day due to traffic congestion. It does however stop right outside the hotel.Rooms are a decent size for Tokyo,very well appointed and very comfortable.There is even a Nespresso coffee machine. The front desk staff are quite helpful. There is an English style pub next door (Rose and Crown) and also a 7 Eleven grocery store and a coffee shop.Tokyo Station also has a large selection of places to eat. The hotel is however a little pricey.

Great location just 2 minutes walk from Tokyo Station Yaesu North Exit with plenty of eateries around. But most importantly, it's the staff with big heart who makes the differences. It's the sum of more then 100 years Japanese hospitality in the heart of Tokyo.

Very close to the Tokyo station. Four adults and one kid live together in the Japanese room type and not felt crowded. The room got everything you need and all are free including drinks. Great service is what we like the best.

Stayed here only 1 night en route from Kyoto to Narita airport. Booked online direct with hotel around $144/night. Loved the location of next to Tokyo Station for transport convenience. Tokyo Station also has TONS of shopping/food options! The hotel was extremely comfortable, nice size room (we stayed in "Forus Single-B") and bed - was worried bed might be too small for me and hubby, but was just perfect (we are both 5'6" 140-150lbs.) Bathroom has great amenities. Coffee maker, fridge, water kettle, slippers, robes, etc. Very clean, fresh, quiet. Customer service at front desk was wonderful - stored our luggage for 4 hrs. while we explored, since we had a late flight. If only we could stay a bit longer - will return here if we come back to visit Tokyo!

Great service, staff is very kind, hotel,is just in front of Tokyo Station, which makes it easy to move, many cofee shops and restaurants near and the room was amazingly clean and even the bed has a function to give massage you.

Tokyo can be an expensive place to find a good hotel. Hotel Ryumeikan was very nice with lots of extras included. I highly recommend this place. Very close to Tokyo Station which is convenient if you are traveling by rail.

We stayed here for 3 nights during our trip to Japan. It has great views from the reception, the staff are lovely and the rooms are lovely, clean and comfy. The hotel is also 2 mins from the train station. Great hotel in Tokyo.

Stayed here May of 2012 for my honetmoon. the hotel was so Clean, staff is awesome, great location (so close to train station, great restaurants, shops! Close to Ginza district!) the Room was large by Japanese standards but didnt feel cramped. Complimentary water and coffee everyday in our rooms. I could go on and on, would stay here again when in Tokyo!

This hotel is excellent. The views from reception are fantastic, it is very centrally located (literally 2 mins walk from Tokyo station) and the rooms are much larger than the Japanese standard. Staff were also great.We had stayed 3 nights at the beginning of our trip in another Tokyo hotel and I wish we had come straight here. It is a bit pricier than other hotels we stayed in Japan, but worth the extra 30 dollars. Even if you are on a budget, do consider this as there are frequently deals on this hotel. The number one rating on trip advisor is spot on!

We stayed in the Junior Suite, an amazing room!!! The hotel is very close to Tokyo Station, and there is a 24h convenience shop next door. Staff very friendly, a wonderful smell of Japanese incense, the best there is!!!!!!

Conveniently located near the Tokyo train station - just 5 minutes walk. We stayed there for 3 wonderful nights for a great price after hotel's advance booking discount. The room is small (but expected in Tokyo) but very clean, modern and well-supplied. The toilet, the nespresso machine, special blend tea, bath ammenities, lullaby-vibrating-bed, etc have convinced us to stay at this hotel again the next time we are in Tokyo!

We stayed at the Ryumeikan for two nights August after a six week trip to the States and Europe. We were initially put off when, after a long flight, we were unable to check into our room due to our early arrival. However, that was the only negative of our whole stay. We had arrived from the airport by train and the walk to the hotel from the station was, literally, a few minutes. We took the express bus to the airport on our departure and it picked up right outside the hotel. We found the hotel itself immaculate and the staff lovely. We had a double room and the bed was large and comfortable and we had all the facilities we needed, including an excellent coffee machine and a kettle for the tea drinkers. We treated ourselves to the expensive (Japanese) buffet breakfast one day and loved it! Would definitely stay here again.

A quiet one step above salary-man/woman hotel. We loved the amenities such as Nespresso and robes and great bath stuff. We thought the bathroom was fine. very clean but no tub. We enjoyed that the elevators went right to the room floors as the reception is on the top floor. The hotel was crowded but not too noisy due to them winning the trip advisor award. It's a very nice location near Ginza and Tokyo station. A very nice choice. My heart is probably more for staying in Koenji or a more " neighborhood location" in Tokyo but this is a great place for 2-3 nights at the beginning or end of your Japan trip. Enjoy! you are close to the palace so go for a nice little run! Also this hotel spoke very well English... not always the case in Japan or Tokyo although everyone is always ready to help.

Great location for those who have the flight the next day, just next to Tokyo train station. Great price, service, very clean. Breakfast very expensive though - about 25 euro and rooms extremely small, double bad rather for one than two people.

Our stay at the hotel was great. We booked the standard room and upgraded to Forus B upon arrival.We enjoyed the sleeping ambient light system and the music player, very relaxing after a long day-out. Cleanliness is superb.Everything is provided snacks,bottled water,japanese tea and Nespresso for coffee lovers were all available and overflowing.Loved the green tea shampoo,conditioner,body wash, body lotion and other toiletries provided separately for men and women. Sleepwear was provided even for my daughter and the slippers as well. Coin laundry and vending machine is 4 doors away to which our room was located. Had lunch at the restaurant and it was a good experience @1,500 Yen per person,my daughter is free of charge.The nearest exit to the hotel from Tokyo station is Yaesu North Exit where Daimaru shopping mall is located. Very accessible to Akihabara electronic station,Ueno station where ameyoko street is (cheap shopping), Shinjuku, Shibuya and Harajuku (try the famous crepe) via JR Yamanote Line. Shinkansen/Bullet train main stop at Tokyo station if coming from Odawara Station (Mt. Fuji) and Disney Resort via Keio Line.Plenty of local restaurants at First Avenue lower ground of Tokyo station.I was really thankful to the hotel staff (esp Ohori),she helped me in buying the bus tickets going back to Narita airport 2 days in advance,accompanied me to the Family Mart convenience store which is just a few steps from the hotel.Told me that once the tickets were bought it wont be cancelled or changed.Due to some reason, we weren't able to make it to our scheduled bus pick-up. Called the front desk two hours before the bus sched and asked for help,glad it was Ohori on duty. Though it was hard and very confusing for them, about us missing the bus,they were able to call the bus company,went to the bus stop and managed to re-sched our pick-up. Btw, Bus terminal is just 1 minute walk from the hotel and the rate was cheaper, 900 Yen/person, compared to the Airport Limo (orange bus 3000 Yen/person)..Thanks Hotel Ryumeikan, will definitely recommend to friends and will surely come back for our next Tokyo trip.
user_name:
Evelyn B
Tuguegarao City, Cagayan, Philippines

review_body: They Hotel Ryumeikan is perfectly situated near Tokyo station and a bunch of interesting restaurants. The hotel itself is quite comfortable. Personally I very much like the high-tech fixtures in the bath including the best shower fixture I've ever had in a hotel. Breakfast in the hotel restaurant is a bit expensive although a little expensive.

The Hotel Ryumeikan is located a short walk from Tokyo Station. The hotel is on the 8th - to the 15th floors of an office building. The lobby is small but very nicely done. The hotel restaurant has a very good selection of seasonal Japanese meals, and you are 5 minutes from dozens of restaurants near the station.The rooms are quite small but well equiped, clean and efficient. From a value perspective, it is a great hotel.

HRT is a very short walk from Tokyo JR Station, exit Yaesu North Exit. I was pleasantly surprised by the high standard, level of service and fit outs provided. The bed system was new to me and very comfortable and great for weary travelers. Got the Forus Discovery Room and it was a very decent size and I had a 40% discount as I booked the room 40 days ahead. Took a high floor unit but no views at all - window faces a wall. Definitely recommend it esp with the discount.

After the Conrad, we chose to stay there and my God, we have found a pearl;Everything you need, they have it for you to use.And if you plan ahead, you can have really good prices.This hotel is worth a 5 star hotel, without the price.I 'll go here surely and definitely next time in Tokyo.one of the best surprise of my trip in Japan.

I stayed at 3 other hotels during my stay in Tokyo and this tops the list. (in tokyo )Ryumeikan is our first stop in Japan of our 19 day trip and after being to other hotels, Ryumeikan is a royal treat!Cosy room for two people but bigger than the average japan hotel rooms. Yukata & Kimono provided. Absolutely loved the toiletries. From hair wax and lotion for guys to face wash and moisturizer, even bath salts were included. Certainly made us felt like royalty with such treats.Location friendly, extremely friendly and helpful staff.Definitely on my list if I visit Tokyo again!

We booked our semi double room for 6 nights, having heard the great reviews on trip advisor. And having stayed, we now totally agree with everyone else! Perfect location, very comfortable rooms (Tokyo-small in size but perfectly formed), very helpful staff, ideal in every way. I'd say book here and don't waste time looking elsewhere!

Great hotel, in an excellent location for those on vacation wanting to visit the tourist sites and explore Tokyo, who could ask for anything more? We stayed three times, 3 nights on first arrival, an additional night before family leaving, and I had a single room as stayed on for work for three days - all was very good, and would recommend to other visitors, the hotel also has good services to offer, such as Wifi, PC and printer, laundry, free tea in reception, and staff were very friendly and welcoming.

This is the second time that I have stayed at the Hotel Ryumeikan and it has maintained a very high standard of hospitality on both occasions. Conveniently located close to Tokyo railway station, the hotel provides a friendly, clean and comfortable stay - with everything you could wish from a top class business hotel. Good bed/ a quiet and relaxing environment and the additional bonus of vending machines - good in hot weather. I cannot speak highly enough of the Ryumeikan - and look forward to see be there again next year :)
user_name:
Ro D
Milton Keynes, United Kingdom

review_body: Ryumeikan was our first stop during our trip to Japan. It's in a brilliant location, almost next to Tokyo Station, and also the Nihombashi metro stop. The rooms were clean, modern and spacious, and the bed was super comfy (just what we needed for the jetlag!). Staff were friendly, good facilities, excellent value for money.

Hotel Ryumeikan was everything it should have been and more. Gracious and English-speaking staff, clean and modern rooms and great location. My only warning is that they are very slow in answering emails sent to them in English so you may want to give them a call instead if you would like something on short notice. Other than that, just fantastic!

We stayed at this hotel for one night due to an early train in the morning. It's not the most "hip happening" neighbourhood, but its well connected to transport links, so ideal for our purposes. The room itself was compact, functional, with little extras like a Nespresso machine andd free-postcards (with stamps). Everything was clean, tidy and functional. Great if you want to be near Tokyo station and very reasonably priced (£85/night).

A very convenient place, just located nearby Tokyo station. Services are good and not annoying. Rooms are clean and neat but not too small as other hotels in Tokyo. Me and my family will definitely choose this hotel again.

8 day business trip to Tokyo. Used TripAdvisor to find it and booked it. It is not a huge "western" hotel with their giant atriums and water fountains in the lobby but who stays in the lobby? I stayed in the FORUS A room; many bells and whistles which included a bed that would lullaby me to sleep with soothing music, dimmed lights, and speaker inside the foot of the bed. Remote control TOTO toilet, awesome shower, great staff, free wifi in rooms. Would stay here again. Only complaint was the buffet on a value score. It was traditional Japanese which is fine with me but it rolled in at $25 USD, for which all I could manage to create was a miso soup, rice, bit of fish, and juice combo. The food was great--the value was not. Future days were spent grabbing breakfast at nearby Starbucks or cafes.

When choosing where to stay for a week in Tokyo, I went for the structure closest to the train station, considering good reviews and budget. And I can say with no doubt that Ryumeikan is the best hotel I have ever stayed so far!...obviously I should say what I mean with "best": there are no beautiful scenary outside the window (to be true my window had no view at all!) or no opulent hall, but Ryumeikan has what an hotel should offer:_ first of all LOCATION, LOCATION, LOCATION, which is for sure a plus: 3 minutes from Tokyo station (and Chiyoda and Marunouchi subway line) and 2 minutes from Nihonbashi subway station on Ginza, Asakusa and Tozai lines...which means is the perfect starting point to explore the city and also beyond_ second: structure itself: I booked a "forus" room: I had any kind of amenities I could have asked and the bed was great (it has a system - integrated with lights - which lulls you at nights and wakes you gently up in the morning) Useless to say that I slept really well!_ third: service! Everything was perfectly clean, personnel was friendly and discrete, the structure was really quiet.If I have to find a drawback, rooms are quite small, especially if you spend them a week like me, but I think is a common problem in Tokyo...

My wife and I come to Japan every summer and we always stay at Hotel Ryumeikan while in Tokyo. The rooms are beautiful AND spacious, the amenities are wonderful, the service is excellent, and the location across from Tokyo Station is so convenient. The room-type choices are good and the 30-day advanced-booking discount gives us a great rate since we always stay several nights at Hotel Ryumeikan. I also appreciate that the hotel has wi-fi access in the rooms. We travel often and are still surprised to find that in an age of mobile devices, a number of so-called high-end hotels still offer lobby-only wi-fi or no wi-fi at all. In our opinion, Hotel Ryumeikan is Tokyo's best hotel value.

This hotel was one of the highlights of our stay in Japan, regarding its amenities.The equipement is very classy and high-tech :- you have a jack connector in the bed and integrated speakers in the room to play the music from your phone !- you have a Nespresso machine ini the room- the lobby is classy, with a nice view and the possibility to prepare your own teaLocation is good but not as good as you can expect : the hotel is close to the station (2 minutes away) BUT the station is huge, which means that it is not always convenient to enter the station from the hotel side, depending where you want to go.Also don't forget that there is a bus service from/to the airport that stops just in front of the hotel !

Excellent location and very friendly staff. Rooms are very modern and have lots of nice little extras (foot-massage pad, tasty tea and crackers, Nespresso machine, fancy sleeping-system). The room we stayed in (semi-double) is small, but this is very normal in Tokyo.

The location across from Tokyo Station makes this immediately convenient, but its spacious rooms, polite customer service, and amenities make it special. The four bottles of water (two in the fridge: two at room temp), Nespresso machine, snacks, tea, and large selection of quality bathroom items (Shiseido face products, hair gel, quality razors with shaving cream, bath salts, in addition to the usual items) makes this an extra special hotel for us. The washer and dryer also make this a place we choose over more expensive options where laundry has to be sent out (soap comes with the washer). Those who want to send their laundry out have that option. The breakfast is traditional (we haven't eaten other meals) and tasty. This is our fourth stay here and we plan to stay here in the future when we return to Tokyo.

We arrived at Tokyo Station after taking the Shinkansen from Kyoto, exited the Yaesu North exit, turned left and had no trouble finding the hotel. Our family had two adjacent Forus semi-double rooms. The rooms are small (Welcome to Japan) but surprisingly luxurious. There is a Nespresso pod coffee maker with a good selection of coffee, an electric tea kettle, tea (I especially liked the Rose Red Lavender tea), and crackers. Also water bottles that were replenished every day. The bathroom was great. The most technologically advanced toilet we had the whole trip and a shower with good water pressure and a rain feature. The toiletries were outstanding. The Forus sleep system was very relaxing and we drifted off to sleep to the music and gentle vibrations under our feet. The awakening was not so gentle, we were awoken abruptly in the morning by bright lights in our eyes, but we may have programmed the system incorrectly. It was still fun and innovative. We found the staff to be helpful. They kept our luggage safe for us on our last day after check-out and helped us figure out the best way for our family to get to Narita airport. We requested non-smoking, adjacent rooms and that’s exactly what we got. The free wi-fi worked which is very important when you are traveling with teenagers. All in all a very positive experience and we would not hesitate to recommend this hotel.

We only stayed here for one night when we had just landed before catching a train in the morning but it was gorgeous, comfortable super close to tokyo station, the staff were all so lovely and helpful, would definately stay here again

Beautiful rooms, very comfortable, SUPER CLEAN, helpful front desk people. They went out of their way to speak English (which was obvious it was not easy for them) to tell me how to save money by going to the airport via bus not train, which I would have never thought of. The hotelis also very close to train station, so coming from anywhere else is a breeze. I highly recommend you stay here.

OK the rooms are small but there is so much packed in that you largely don't notice. The room was super clean and efficient. The staff was professional to the utmost. There is a coin laundry on floors 10 and 12 for ¥300 per load to wash and dry - detergent included. A great value in my book. Location is fantastic but pay attention to other TA posts about finding the best exit from Tokyo station (Yaesu North). Once you master the best exit you are just meters away. Excellent value overall.

I have only good things to say about the Ryumeikan. The atmosphere of the hotel is luxurious and relaxing - starting already from entering the lobby elevator, continuing all the way to your bedroom. The service is top notch, and the rooms are nothing far from spectacular in their design.We actually slept our best sleep in this hotel during our 3 week Japan trip. The bed was superior to anything we've had before, the mattress was excellent, and the pillows were the best pillows I've ever tried. They even had a night ambience system, where the room lightning and the bed interact in creating a fake sundown combined with relaxing music when you go to sleep, and wake you up in the morning with a fake sunrise, relaxing morning music and vibration in the bed. Never had anything like this before, and for us it worked like magic, we're considering getting such a system home now.To top off everything, the restaurant is great, and the location is fabulous - and for the price you pay, you get much more than you deserve (compared to the price level in Tokyo).Thank you Ryumeikan, we will be back next time!

We stayed here for one night and left with good impressions. The hotel is super close to Tokyo station after you've travelled from Narita all tired and hungry! The room we stayed in was super clean, had everything you need in the room (toiletries, fridge, tea/coffee making facilities) and service was impeccable. It's close to food and entertainment where all the salarymen go after a long day at work. I highly recommend this place, I wish I got to stay longer!

My son and I stayed at Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo while in Japan. The staff was wonderful and helpful and were quick to answer questions. The rooms were bigger then what I had thought and very clean. Our room had a small refrigerator which was perfect to throw a few drinks in as Japan was very humid and our room also had a small coffee maker with pods and creamer and sugar which was such a blessing as I am a huge coffee drinker. The hotel is located very close to the train station so you can get there in just a few minutes. There are also some great restaurants near by as well as a couple of convenience stores. Some days it was easier to take a taxi and the staff was always very nice to write down the addresses in Japanese as the taxi drivers often do not speak English. I cannot say enough good about this hotel and staff, truly a great find at a great price and should I ever have the chance to return to Tokyo, this is my first choice!

The hotel is just a couple of minutes walk from Tokyo Station and Tokyo Metro Nihonbashi Station which is excellent. Room was spacious and tidy. Facilities are well maintained. We especially like the amenlities provided and the coffee is of good quality. Staff have high English level and are polite & helpful.

It's Conveniently located near Tokyo station and other metro lines. Hotel staff is eager to meet all your requests, even if it's beyond the service they offer. The hospitality of the staff and the environment of the room makes people definitely feel like coming back in the future.

It's Tokyo so don't expect a massive room. Stayed here in july2013. Functional room with plenty of amenities and wonderful location. Don't worry about North American standards cuz this hotel is all you need wrapped up in a nice tight package.

Unfortunately, we picked this place only for our last night- based on it's extremely close proximity to the JR Tokyo Station (if you were standing at the Central exit of the station, walk out to the road, look down the street to your far left and there it is, right across the road!). The unfortunate part being that we didn't spend our first 5 nights in Tokyo there! We did get a great price online, but it would be worth the money they were charging, as it had some of the biggest rooms we encountered in Tokyo, as I said, the location is excellent, and the staff and service were great! The lobby has great city views from the floor to ceiling glass windows (we were even sat up there during a 5.0 earthquake tremor), and an on-site restaurant which looked and smelled great (didn't get to try it). There's even a convenience store downstairs!Would definitely go back, and stay for longer to make the most out of it.

We stayed four nights in the Japanese Suite A room and we thought everything about it was excellent!Spacious, clean and generously appointed room and bathroom, and the beds were comfortable.The hotel is conveniently located five minutes walk from the busy Tokyo station. But being this close to a train station and heavy car traffic, we were a bit worried about the noise, but the room was very quiet.We had a better rate since we booked the room more than two months in advance. The dinner at the hotel's restaurant, Hanagoyomi, was also excellent with impeccable service.We loved our stay at Hotel Ryumeikan!

A great hotel near Tokyo station. I stayed for 5 nights in late May - nothing to fault. The beds are very comfortable and my room was very quiet and well appointed. Loved the shower. Book ahead to get a better rate. I'll be back - one day!

I stayed 5 days in this hotel and the room was very good.The room have a good size and is very clean, and I didn't had any problem with noises.The hotel have a good location, 5 minutes walking from Tokyo station.The only problem that I had, is that they didn't call me a taxi on my check out. I had to do this on my own and I had three luggages with me.

I stayed at the Ryumeikan on a business trip for a week and it was excellent. Everything you expect from a business class hotel in the heart of the city, plus many other amenities that make traveling to Tokyo much easier.

This hotel is a great option for travelers wishing to stay near Tokyo central station. We stayed here one night on the day of our arrival. The Narita express train takes 1 hour from the airport to Tokyo station. The station itself is massive so getting to the hotel can be tricky. My best advice to locate it is as follows: Take the "Yaesu North Gate" exit, turn left at the "gran Tokyo North Tower" and walk along the street for about 200 yards. Look across the street on the right and look UP (the name is on the top of the hotel tower). The price we paid was reasonable, and the room was average for Japanese size (i.e. small) and comfortable.
