There is a gorgeous lobby on the 15th floor. Staff was very friendly and spoke English for the most part. A 24 hour famliy mart is right next door (what a bonus!). There is no ATM nearby that takes US atm cards. The closest is at Citibank around the corner. You can ask the staff on how to get there and they will be happy to assist. Overall this is a great choice and I would recommend it.
user_name:
NikG76
New York City, New York

review_body: Our family of 4 is visiting Japan for the 1st time, and decided to stay at the Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo after reading other reviews about the hotel. I wanted to stay near Tokyo Station because we are taking the Shinkansen( bullet train ) to Kyoto and Osaka. This hotel is the best choice available for us. I highly recommend this hotel.I booked our stay via the hotel's website, and they offered 40% off if booked 40 days prior (although it is best to book earlier since the room choices decrease pretty quickly). Prepaid by credit card upon booking. Chose the standard single(1 bed about 140cm good for 2 persons) rather than the Junior suite since it came out cheaper. The rooms are on the smaller side( Japanese rooms are built to make use of all available space, and smaller than Western type hotel rooms), but space is still ample, not cramped.I emailed the hotel regarding nonsmoking rooms( make sure to choose the Nonsmoking designated rooms rather than just request for it), as well as having my daughter ( who is arriving ahead of us from Haneda airport) check in ahead of us. Plus requested for adjoining rooms( they do not have interconnecting rooms). Note that the hotel's lobby is on the 15th floor. Everything went along smoothly, they checked my daughter in, got us 2 rooms next to each other with a good view of the surrounding are. Hassle free.They emailed instructions on how to reach the hotel from Narita airport. Best and most economical way is to take the Keisei bus(#31), cost is ¥900. The best part is the bus literally stops at the corner near the hotel( Limousine bus stops further awayand Narita Express ( NEX) requires transfer and stops at Tokyo Station Yaesu North exit which is about 3 minute's walk). Have to purchase the return bus ticket to Narita at least 2 days before departure( receptio at the hotel has the info, payment is at the Family Mart close to the hotel. Plus the Nihonbashi subway stop (T10 line) is right behind the hotel.Everyone we dealt with were so helpful. There is a nice lounge on the 15th floor, they have a seating area with complimentary tea. The rooms have bottled water( in the refrigerator) pajamas, slippers and bathrobes. The main purpose of our hotel room is for resting and sleeping after a whole day of touring and shopping. So we did not use or require any facilities like a swimming pool or a firness center.We checked out of the hotel to travel to Kyoto and the front desk kept our luggages free of charge until we go back for 1 night's stay. They also have postcards in the room and will mail the postcard free of charge.We are going back for 1 night and will be staying in their Forus room Discovery. We are looking forward to this. Staff members are very helpful, rates are really reasonable and great value for Tokyo. It is a very central place, so this hotel is in the best location for a lot places. The bathrooms and amenities and toiletries are so complete and plentiful.Alll in all, this is really the best hotel to stay at in Tokyo.

It's just next to the Ginza line and 5 minutes walk to the JR Tokyo station. Great location if you want to hang out in Ginza or go to Tsuikiji market early in the morning also some big department stores nearby in the nihonbashi district. Very quiet as this is more of business / finance area. about 30 minutes by Metro to Shinjuku / Shibuya. The facilities new, modern, clean. Great value!

I stayed at Hotel Ryumeikan in Tokyo for a week with my girlfriend during our first trip to Japan. I thought the hotel was very nice with some of the most comfortable bedding I have ever enjoyed in any type of hotel, luxury or business class. Beyond the nicely appointed rooms, the location was excellent. Directly across the street from Tokyo Station, it made day trips throughout Tokyo very easy to do. Also, nearby were many nice restaurants to choose from for eating around the hotel. Overall, I will make this my " go to" hotel any time I am in Tokyo, you cannot beat the quality, location, and value. During our stay we enjoyed two different room types and the full double room was well worth the nominal increase in price for a larger room and sitting area.

I was looking for a hotel near Tokyo station, and this hotel was a great discovery. It is very easy to get to if you're arriving in Tokyo by train (a three minute walk and there are super clear directions on their web site). The hotel was a great value, especially compared to other hotels in the neighborhood. It has a modern design, with impeccably clean rooms and a lobby with a great view of the city. Highly recommended!

This hotel is nice. Near to JR train station. Easy to find food.Room also clean & a bit big for Japan's standard.But the staff very very very unhelpfull. We arrive at 7.30 am at Tokyo, before that we already request for early check-in. But the hotel didn't give us respon, although by email. So when we arrived, they say we need to wait until 2 pm.. Oh my goodness.. We were very tired, not shower yet.. We beg the staff to help us to gave us the earlier, but still can't. Fiiuuhhh...The staff also can't speak english well..

Great choice. Close to Tokyo main station with another metro entrance around the corner. We arrived jet lagged and with my bag lost by United airlines. They were very helpful in changing our reservation to add a night hoping the bag would arrive. The amenities really eased my pain. They had facial products that covered everything I was missing besides the usual shampoo etc. they had a hairbrush, bath salts, hair bands, facial scrub etc. They called to cancel our reservation at the other hotel and called the airport for us to check on the missing bag. Whenever you go to reception they go out of their way to help. Great relief after and awful experience in the USA at a Residence Inn where our iPhone and iPad were stolen. They also have a safe in the room!

I stayed here for the second time after staying here in October 2012 for a holiday. Its location is excellent and the hotel staff provided great service again. I was supposed to pay up for the second night stay upon check in but my credit card wasnt working. The person checking me in kept trying to find the fault, by calling up the credit card bank although it was after office hours. They let me stay the night and asked me to pay the next day (it was resolved when I checked and found out my credit card's limit was maxed and it was eventuyally restored). The room is small but extremely clean and well-kept. As a bonus, a bus to Narita Airport picks up passengers just outside the hotel so you do not need to lug your luggage to Tokyo Station. The hotel rate is among the lowest in the vicinity.

We stayed two nights at the ryumeikan in tokyo. The building is easily accessible from the main Tokyo train station. The room we got was extremely small but very confortable. Overall, we got a very good feeling in this modern hotel.

The room is not so big; but has everything you need, clean and comfortable. The check-in/ out is efficient. Besides; the location is just perfect, couples steps to Tokyo station, and easily to find a restaurant nearby.

This is one of the better hotels you will find in the heart of Tokyo, across from Tokyo Station (main train station) with plenty of restaurants, at a great price for an excellent room. On our recent trip to Tokyo, we had two separate stays at this hotel. Our only complaint/disappointment was when we made the reservation via Delta's / Hotel.com connection, we were told our room had two double beds, but instead it had one double bed and the room is very small. There is no closet and barely anywhere to walk around in the room as the bed and the wall desk/chair takes up pretty much the whole room. The bathroom is perfectly fine...not the smallest bathroom, but is fine. As usual, Tokyo hotels have excellent water pressure and they also have very firm beds, which we prefer. My husband loves their heated toilet seats and built-in bidet. We paid $197 USD a night and would have gladly paid more to get a larger room at this hotel at not a whole lot more money, but since it was a prepaid rate, we were stuck with it. Their rooms are quiet and we would highly recommend staying here.

We recently spent 3 nights at the Hotel Ryumeikan, and were very pleased with the location, facilities and service. It was a short walk from the the Tokyo station, ands very easy to find. The room, though small by American standards, was beautifully appointed and extremely clean. The Japanese soaking bathtub was just what we needed after a long flight. There are nearby coffee shops, including a Starbucks around the corner, 7-11's, and restaurants. I didn't realize that the case holding my extra camera cards was missing until we got on our cruise ship. We soon received an e-mail through our booking company advising us that we had left a personal item. We contacted the hotel directly, and they said it was my camera cards. They made arrangements for sending it back. I have left things at hotels before, and have never had this kind of customer service before

While not a "luxury" hotel, Hotel Ryumeikan is very new, super quiet, and appointed perfectly (comfortable bed, good lighting, wireless internet, etc.). The staff are very efficient and speak English very well. Their reservation system works well. And the best part to cap all this: it is the closest affordable hotel to Tokyo station. Also, it is easy to find.

The hotel was easier to find then I thought it would be. If you are arriving at the Tokyo station just follow the directions on the hotel website. The station is very crowded but once you get out (make sure to take the right exit), just cross the street, go left and up one block. Look up and you will see the hotel sign on the building. Our room was a good size with a modern bathroom ( large bathtub and great automatic toilet.) It was nice to have four water bottles in the room free of charge each day. We walked to the Imperial Palace, but couldn't see too much since it is closed to the public.Hotel is very convenient for using the trains.

We loved staying at Hotel Ryumeikan. Right from the pleasantly scented entrance our whole experience was wonderful. We got a Forus Semi-Double C Create room. We booked it through Agoda because they allowed us to choose which semi-double room size to reserve. Do be aware that Agoda requires you to pay for your entire stay at the time you make your reservation. The single semi-double rooms are A, B, or C, with C being the largest. We could have reserved the room through Hotel Ryumeikan's website but I was worried about reserving a room without using a credit card, which apparently is common in Asia. Some other hotel reservation websites wouldn’t allow us to choose room size A, B, or C at Hotel Ryumeikan.The Forus single semi-double C was plenty big for two people and space to spread out luggage. The room was 26.9 square meters and non-smoking. The bed was 140 cm x 205 cm which was slightly smaller than an American queen size bed but it was fine for us. The bed was very firm, just be aware. The pillows had a combination of buckwheat hulls and a soft filling which are popular in Asia. They are nice for neck support and we found them to be comfortable. They also have regular pillows. The bed has automatically dimming/brightening lights, music, and vibrations at the foot of the bed to help you fall asleep and wake up, which was very nice. Our room had a Japanese toilet with a heated seat, automatic nightlight, and automatic flush. There was plenty of counter space in the bathroom. The bathroom also had a hairdryer. The shower was a shower stall style (no tub) and was very nice, very strong spray, also with a rain shower head. The room was very clean, and feels newly renovated. The room also had a closet and wifi in the room, as well as a desk and small couch. The window only looked at the building next door but the room was so nice we didn't mind, and we just left the curtain closed. I recommend printing directions to the hotel - after a long flight, you don't want to be searching for the hotel while carrying luggage. From Tokyo Station, take the Yaesu North exit (follow the signs for Yaesu Central), exit by Daimaru department store, then cross the street, go left for 2.5 blocks, and the hotel will be on the right. Print a street view if desired.The hotel is also a short walk to Nihombashi train station for accessing trains that don't go through Tokyo Station. It was easy to get to Tokyo Station for using the subway and it was also nice to be able to get on the Shinkansen for day trips without having to transfer to another train station. Tokyo Station has plenty of restaurants to eat at. If you are looking for some nicer restaurants nearby, I recommend the Shin-Marunouchi building (the one closest to the Imperial Palace south corner - there are several Marunouchi buildings). There are several nice restaurants on the fourth and fifth floors as well as shops. We had a very nice dinner at a French restaurant there. There is an awesome French bakery Maison Kayser just a five minute walk away. Be aware they don't open until 10 am.  The hotel was quick to respond to emails before our trip, and they were very helpful. They put a lot of nice personal touches into the hotel and room. We liked Hotel Ryumeikan much better than the Hotel Granvia at Kyoto Station which was nice but was a very large hotel and felt very impersonal. We thought it was fine to stay near Tokyo Station even though it is a little less of a tourist area and more business. Most days we just hopped on the subway since Tokyo is so big. It is really helpful to be close to a train station. Tokyo Station is very large, so plan for extra time to find your train and platform. On our last day we were running through the station with our luggage to find the platform for the Narita Express to make our train in time. We really enjoyed our stay at Hotel Ryumeikan and would definitely stay there again. We highly recommend it!

Hotel has attentive staff, nice design, comfty rooms though smallish but the best of the hotel is the greatest location for traveling around Tokyo and Japan- next door to Tokyo station.They have all usual amenities, it is possible also to rent bicycle and big plus they have self using washing machine which is definitely better option than expensive washing service.

We stayed here as a couple in May 2013. What can I say, I just loved this hotel, it has such a nice feel to it. Staff were all so friendly. It was our Wedding Anniversary so they gave us a Mini bottle of Champagne..which was a very nice touch!Both of us could not fault one single thing with this hotel and we travel very often. The room was bigger than we were expecting. Bathroom was an ample size, very clean and I loved all of the freebies! Bed size was also great..I especially loved the toilet, the best we saw in Japan! It did take me a day or two to learn how to work it...The location was perfect, right outside Tokyo station and a short walk from The Imperial Palace. We didn't have breakfast at the hotel, we walked to Maison Keyser just up the street for French Pastries and Coffee. We forwarded our luggage from the hotel to Kyoto, this was such a hassle free process and I strongly recommend it if you are to travel onwards within Japan by Shinkansen.The Japanese really do think of everything..We would love to return next year.

Bedroom was fabulous with lots of different facilities to make it out of the ordinary for the western traveller. Very comfortable bed and the amenities are first rate. Staff are universally professional and friendly. Lobby is on the 15th floor - which is also where you take your very Japanese breakfast.Well located a short walk from the main Tokyo railway station so the rest of Tokyo - indeed Japan - is at your fingertips. Great directions to the hotel on their website.Very very good indeed.

We only stayed 1 night at the hotel but were really impressed. English-speaking staff are all so nice and friendly. The room was very clean and well-designed. The bed was super comfortable. The bathroom and amenities were also great. The hotel is just a short walk from Yaesu north exit of Tokyo station. We got discount from the advance booking promotion so the rate was really reasonable. We'll definitely stay here again on our next trip to Tokyo.

only stayed in two hotels in Tokyo to compare against with the first being the Apa business hotel. We stayed in the Forus Single A (whose name I found misleading which has a double bed designed for two people) and by comparison this hotel has wopping sized rooms although was more expensive. great location to walk to Ginza (oxford street of Tokyo) and jump on the Narita express back to the airport. Hotel also had a free in room Nespresso machine which was a nice touch.

We chose this hotel based on TA reviews. Hopefully, this review would help others make an informed decision :)Ryumeikan is the best Tokyo hotel we have stayed so far over 2 Japan trips. It is not the most expensive (Prince Park Tower was twice the room rate), but it gave us the best experience, by far.A bit of background: we stayed at Ryumeikan on the final day of our 2-week Japan trip. It was our "chill and relax" stop before the flight home the next day. We have always treated Japanese hotels as rooms to sleep in at night, rather than rooms where we can enjoy ourselves during the day. Ryumeikan so totally changed that perception.Pros:- Modern, boutique hotel décor consistently applied in rooms and common areas.- Lounge at the top floor has a nice view of the area with complimentary tea to enjoy.- FORUS system. It is one of those new-fangled room environment control system that integrates lighting, music, vibrating bed...(you get the idea :) It is definitely worth a try!- In-room Nespresso coffee machine. For coffee lovers like us, this is a godsend. Miles better than those you get in Lawsons and vending machines.- Room is new, cosy and extremely comfortable. Designer is a genius who balanced functionality and form perfectly. We want to stay in there all day!- High-end Toto Neorest toilet. Using it is a joy in itself.- Location: within short walking distance from Tokyo station. Get out at Yaesu North exit, cross the big street in front of you and turn left. Look out for the Keisei bus stop (there will be queues) and the Victorian Pub.- Keisei bus. This must be the cheapest way in and out of Narita. Forget NEX and other options. For 900 yen per trip, this saves you a lot of yen and best of all, Ryumeikan is right behind the bus stop. No more worries about lugging heavy bags up train escalators.Cons:- Our room had no view and stared right into a wall. Does not take away from the experience though ‘cos we just went up to the wonderful lounge at the top floor when we want to get a view.Tips: This is really a nice "stopover" hotel. You can do all your shopping in Daimaru, all 7-storeys of it, just across the street.Do have a meal at the Victorian Pub. We ordered the beef steak. Never ate so much meat in Japan :)Stay more than a night here. We are still kicking ourselves for staying only 1 night.

We got to stay at Ryumeikan because of a long lay over. We looked for a hotel that is near Tokyo station and came across this one. So glad we did! The location is very convenient. Took N'EX from the airport got off at Tokyo station, took us a few minutes to get to Yaesu exit then another 5 minute walk to the hotel. Checking in wasn't that bad. The staff was very friendly and courteous. We checked in around 7pm. Our room wasn't ready right away so we had to wait a while at the lobby which was on the 15th floor. There, you can view Ginza I believe from the window. They also have complimentary tea that you can make yourself which we never got to try. Anyhow, We got the forus room & paid around 170 USD. The room may be small but it was nice, modern and very clean. Though there was a funky smell when we first walked in but the room spray provided took care of it and I guess the air cleaner as well. The bed was comfy enough but what I really liked was the bathroom, because of it's cleanliness. The amenities provided was great too.We will definitely stay here again on our next trip to Tokyo next year :)

I stayed here for the first and last two days of my trip to Japan, and without a doubt this was the best hotel I stayed in. The rooms are standard Japanese size (small compared to Western standards), but I found them to be very clean and well maintained. They also give you a free bottle of water everyday, which I found to be a very nice touch. Laundry machines are located on certain floors, which is a lifesaver if you're traveling light. Oh and the showers in the Forus rooms are amazing! Incredible water pressure and massage options.The service at the front desk was impeccable too, and they even gave me a nice pocket map of Tokyo's subway lines with useful Japanese phrases (with English translations of course) on the back. Very polite and friendly, and they helped me with various things like sending luggage to another hotel via Ta-Q-Bin). Location wise, it's located in the middle of a business district I think, but there's a lot of restaurants around so finding food shouldn't be a problem. It will be busy though, since a lot of salarymen will be hitting up those food places. A Family Mart is also located right next to the hotel, which I frequented a lot. It's about a 5 minute walk to Yaesu North entrance of Tokyo Station, but be warned that it'll take a bit longer to reach the actual train you want to get on. Tokyo Station is absolutely massive and shouldn't be underestimated. Akihabara is also really close by if that interests you (2 stops).Flawless experience in my book. Also, free Wifi! For some reason, all the other hotels I visited had free internet in the form of a Ethernet jack. Hotel Ryumeikan was the only one that had actual Wifi in the room. I'll definitely visit again on my next trip to Japan.

Very clean, quiet, smoke-free room. Although the room air was dry, I found that to be the case in multiple hotels in Japan. Courteous English speaking staff were quick to respond to e-mails and while I was there, spent time obtaining information for metro stations and taxi estimate. The advanced online rates made this a very good value for such a convenient location. A very short walking distance to the Tokyo JR station north Yaesu exit, metro station, post office, convenience and department stores, and mall under the train station. I was able to manage a wheeled 22" suitcase and backpack on the NEX to Tokyo JR Station, and walked to the hotel. Hotel had area maps and a super helpful rail map with point-and-speak Japanese phrases and pictures.

Reached hotel way earlier than check in time. Room is available and so I paid some extra money to check in early. Good decision as I can catch some sleep after the late night flight. The room I stayed in is a Forus room. The sleep system, lighting, Nespresso machine, WIFI and shower facilities are great. Totally enjoyed my stay there. Location and price is very good. Deserve the ranking and reviews here on Tripadvisor.

A lovely hotel with a fantastic relaxation system in and around the bed. I rarely sleep well the night before a flight, but I tried the system this time and had a the best night's sleep in a very long time!

The location is just about perfectly located for anyone arriving from Tokyo Narita at the central train station. Just make sure you get good directions as it can be confusing to leave the station properly and find it even though it is close!It was a 3rd country stay on an international honeymoon trip, and they were the only hotel to have a bottle of champagne as a complimentary gift, much appreciated! The room was very comfortable, with expert design and functionality. My spouse now insists we get the Japanese toilet that they had here.The only negative which gets -1 is that the air conditioner has a control panel that didn't seem to work for us. This caused the room to seem a bit hot and stuffy at night causing some sleep trouble. It was only on our last day that we discovered there was an AC exhaust vent next to the bed that was pushed shut. This could have been made clear and detracted somewhat from an otherwise great stay. Overall, we would recommend and gladly stay again.

Fantastic hotel. Great location. Spacious rooms. Clean bathroom. Wonderful breakfast. Staff is very welcoming and extremely professional. If you travel for business, you'll love the attitude. I'd go back in a heartbeat.

Stayed at Ryumeikan for 9days.The location is fantastic ,5 minutes walk to Tokyo station and Shinkansen.A Ginza line subway just around the corner.The room fell very cosy and also there is free wi-fi in the room.The toilet amenities made this hotel stand out from similarly priced hotels. The reception staffs are very friendly and helpful.Highly recommend for traveller who will use Shinkansen and very easy to transport to and from Narita.

We stayed here at the start and end of our trip and highly recommend the place for it's convenience, comfort and customer service. It's only a small hotel with the reception on the top floor, I like to have a chat with staff on the way out every morning to get advice and tips for the day so it was a bit of a bummer to not be able to do that every day, BUT the positives far outweighed this negative. Location is AWESOME right across the rd from Tokyo Station and very easy to find. It's also close to Nihombashi metro which is convenient for several sights such as Asakusa and Ueno. There are lots of restaurants & bars in the surrounding streets and busy nightlife especially Friday night. The first room we had was huge, the second room for 1 night at the end was small but still comfy. Beds are very hard which we loved, this hotel gave us the best nights sleep of the trip. One of the BEST things about this hotel was the tiny self serve laundry, 1 washer and 1 dryer on the 13th floor for something like $2AUS per load, when comparing that with $40 for laundry service for just the bare essentials this really was a huge plus. Staff were lovely and all spoke English well enough.

If you are planning to stay around Tokyo station, this hotel is excellent value. Our room was a above average size which was excellent value for central Tokyo.Service was great, and is often the case it is the little things such as being given a hot face towel when we arrived at midnight coming in from 5'c night after a 12 hrs of flying. Nice introduction. The front desk staff spoke decent English which is good for those of us whose Japanese is a little bit lacking.It may well be normally at other Japanese hotels, but I liked the bathroom which has a Japanese touch to it such as bathing stool and bucket(you can still have a normal stand up shower if desire) and a deeper than the normal bath which was nice to relax in after a long day of walking. The hotel also supplies a good selection of toiletries which I haven't seen much of at other hotels such as hair gel, face masks, various skin and ageing creams! All very welcome.As is normal at most hotels in Japan, you get free WiFi and the speed was pretty decent.We had a buffet breakfast on the first morning and it was very much a Japanese style breakfast which i quite liked. Nice and refreshing food rather than the normal pastries and fried food. Though if you dont want to spend the money on a buffet breakfast each day(which is relatively expensive), the Excelsior Caffe next door does a cheap sandwich set breakfast meal which was pretty good.Hotel is about 3-5 minutes from the Yaesu North exit of Tokyo station, though realistically it is about 10 mins to get to an actual platform by the time you navigate through the station. Though, a better bet if you are planning on using the metro, is to go straight to Nihonbashi metro station only about 2 minutes from the hotel in the opposite direction which we found a lot more convenient.Having stayed in Shinjuku when last in Tokyo, this area of Tokyo is a bit more orderly and quiet. Having said that, it is still Tokyo and still plenty of places open to go to eat and drink and Tokyo station is always buzzing.

Initially I booked Shinjuku Sunroute but had chosen this hotel since it is only SGD80 more per night and saves me the hassle of changing JR to Kyoto. Stayed 2 nights and this is my 5th time to Japan so I hope I am able to give a fair review. Let me quickly touch on the important factors for choosing hotel: 1. Location- is actually not 3mins walk from Yaesu North exit. Is about 5 to 8 mins with luggage. 15mins from your JR exit. Ensure you have a 4 wheel luggage unless you use a Taqbin (courier service). this is why I didn't rate this hotel location as 5*- you can use an airport bus but I would advise N'ex since it is covered with JR pass or Suica card which saves you close to 6300yen.- With location at Tokyo station (is a major interchange), it is great for travelers planning to visit Kyoto/Osaka/other places since is the first stop so you can get seats even on non-reserved trains during Golden Week like us! The Japanese train transfers are a challenge if you have a big luggage, trust me. You will have to walk from one end to the other unless you know the directions very well. This is the main reason why I choose to stay near Tokyo station. If you are just planning Tokyo, you can choose Shibuya or Shinjuku however they are not far from Tokyo station using the JR Yamanote line as well.- very near Daimaru/shopping using the same Yaesu North/Central exit or entrance. You can easily get food there or Excelsior Cafe which is just 20m away and FamilyMart, 10m away.Starbucks is also just round the corner. There are many eating places around the hotel since there are many working crowds2. Service-typical polite Japanese folks-provided maps whenever necessary but they do not have a proficient concierge who can advise properly especially when English is not spoken commonly but that's ok since we have been to Japan a few times-they do not help you to put your luggage in the room which I found it appalling for the price paid -SGD 340 per night! Then again is Japan...everything is expensive in Tokyo ESP. 3. Rooms- we picked a twin room with two standard beds. While it is small (approximately 28sqm), it is adequate for two with one big and small luggage.- bathrooms are also good in size with a separate vanity area- the beds and pillows are also right in firmness - the only complain I have is the lighting, too dim and no way toadjust it to be brighter- cleanliness is top notch!Others - hardly any views, we had a view of the Tokyo station area only- they provided a whole basket of vanity items like hairband, facial creams which I like since they are from Shiseido-4 bottles of complimentary water which is from Kurobe area - robes for sleep is provided as well- we can't comment on their breakfast since the rate was without as we reckon we might be better off hunting for food elsewhereWe may choose other hotels in our next trip since there is nothing too outstanding about this hotel but it is still good overall minus the price. I can get maruonochi hotel at the same rate.

Ryumeikan located about 100m from Tokyo Station ( main station where the Shinkensen start n stops). For usd150 a night for a normal standard double room, its ok for Tokyo area n also infront of Shangrila Hotel .Once you are in Tokyo station,take the Yaesu North Exit , you will exit into the main road thru Daimaru shopping centre,turn left ,walk 50 m and look up for the signage.Reception is on the 15 floor , clean , nice atmosphere , english speaking receptionist , 5 star toiletries. Free wifi in your room , nice bed , nice view ( i stayed on the 14th floor ) Starbucks n other restaurants plentiful around . No complimentary coffee but you get green tea , black tea n organic tea , you want coffee........go to Starbucks !!

We liked this hotel because of the ideal location opposite Tokyo's central station and stylish modern character. We paid about 100,- euro per night and it was worth it. The room was small though but was fine for us for a couple of nights. Service is very good. Rooms have a typical Japanese toilet with buttons, a sprinkler and warm seat. Outside there are plenty of restaurants and shops, and it is right in the middle of the city.

We booked a Forus Single Room through the hotel website and for advance prepayment, a 30% per cent discount was accorded. Room rate per night was JPY18,200 (without breakfast).We took the Narita Express from Narita Airport and arrived at Tokyo station within 56 mins. Tokyo Station is a huge maze but we managed to locate the Yaesu North Exit through Daimaru and the hotel is just 3 mins walk across the road. Very convenient and accessible!Reception is on the 15/F and the check in process was fast and Front Desk staff are friendly & efficient.Hotel Ryumeikan goes out of the way to pamper female guests! The bathroom is well-stocked with toiletries like face scrub, ageing care lotion, hair wax, hair band, hair brush and a mini pouch containing Shiseido cleansing gel, lotion and moisturiser. Wow! On the 12th floor where our room is, is a vending machine and laundry room (washer & dryer). They are also very generous in providing 4 bottles of mineral water daily. There is also free in-room fast wifi connectivity. The only odd thing is that the safe deposit box is hidden in a drawer below the bed.We had our breakfasts @ Cafe Excelsior which is less than 2 mins walk to the left of the hotel. We also found a very good Thai restaurant called Sukhumvit Soi Thong Lo @ Sakura-Dori St (diagonally opposite Starbucks) about 2 lanes away from the hotel. Portions are small but the quality is as good as those in Bangkok. Dinner for two costs Y3430. There are many eateries in the vicinity as well as within Tokyo Station.If you are travelling on the Ginza line towards Asakusa, the station to head to is Nihombashi Station which is a 5 mins walk behind Ryumeikan Hotel. The Nihombashi station is located below Takashimaya Dept Store. The hotel scores high in service, room comfort and its wonderful location to Tokyo Station and to the many restaurants nearby! Will I stay here again? Yes, in a heart beat!

Convenient location, super valuable under 40% discount off its normal rate.Opposite to Tokyo station 八重洲 N Exit,Airport shuttle stop in front of the hotel.Less than 800m from the Imperial Palace, best if you like morning jog.

I recommend this hotel maybe more for 1 or 2 nights as the location is convenient arriving in Tokyo or just before departure (JR line direct to Narita airport). The room is quite small but really well designed, with an amasing bathroom (wonderful shower for Japan), all toiletries and above all Wifi in the room, which is not so often in Japan. Very clean and friendly staff as everywhere. However, for those who want to discover Tokyo, this is not the best area. For sightseeing and restaurants, shopping, you may be aware this is a business area, where Japanese people have drinks and dinner after work, so usually packed and not really charming. I prefered the area of Shinjuku for instance.

Very nice boutique hotel on upper levels of office building, two blocks from Tokyo Station main entrance. Nice Japanese bathroom with modern amenities. Pod coffee machine!! Japanese restaurant off lobby was very good for easy dinner and staff very courteous to our young daughter. Note: Hotel lobby is on upper floor and no baggage assistance is available.

A superb hotel, only 3 minutes walk from Tokyo Station, with friendly and helpful staff.We had a double room, which was a great size for Tokyo hotels. A large comfortable double bed, desk and small sitting chair made the room very comfortable for 2 people. The room is very well soundproofed, with no noise at night.Room includes a Nespresso machine, with no charge for coffee capsules, and free bottled water is provided. The bathroom is a combined bath and shower "all-in-one" and there is a separate toilet. The bathroom amenities are very good and yukatas are provided.The area has a wide variety of restaurants and bars within 5-10 mins walk.Highly recommended and fair value with advanced purchase that is available.

Ryumeikan hotel is perfectly located near Tokyo Station and allows to visit any area of Tokyo by direct metro and train connection and access to/from the airport and Sinkansen trains to Kyoto or other cities.The hotel is very clean and staff are friendly and helpful. However rooms are extremely small and the double bed is of the size of a single bed by European standards.The restaurant which serves dinner and breakfast is extremely expensive and food is disappointing, specially compared to the wonderful meals you can have in Japan.

I initially booked another hotel in the Ginza area but after I read the reviews on Tripadvisor, I changed my booking to Ryumeikan. We got the Junior Suite A which was the last available room that could accommodate our family of 4. It was a smoking room but we didn't smell any smoke. The staff did very well in eliminating any smoke smell. All the drinks in the fridge, as well as the pay per view movies, were included in the room rate. We found the location very convenient as it was a few minutes walk to/from Tokyo Station which had a lot of good restaurants and the Daimaru Department Store and food bazaar which we frequented everyday. The staff was also very helpful when I asked for assistance thru email prior to our trip in confirming details with the local tour provider about the tour which I booked online. They also recommended the best mode of transportation to take from Narita airport when there are a lot of luggage (airport limousine bus), including info on the fare and trip schedules. There is a Family Mart right beside the entrance to the hotel which proved very useful because we arrived late at night and didn't want to go far for something to eat.Ryumeikan is definitely my first choice when we go back to Tokyo.

Terrific hotel, very reasonably priced for the quality of rooms and service. The building is somewhat nondescript and can be difficult to find. Take the Yaesu exit, carry a map or ask someone. Large rooms by Tokyo standards, well-furnished and spotlessly clean. Free internet.Breakfast was only Japanese style and fairly expensive (2500 yen), but there are enough cafes and restaurants nearby. Can't be beat for the price and location.

During my stay in late March (4D 3N) we were greeted by the English speaking staff at reception and they were very helpful when we booked our airport coach buses the next day, you'll need to pop into the Family Mart next store to complete the process of getting the tickets though. The pick up/drop off bus stop being right at the entrance of the hotel made things much easier for us. Take note the bus ride to and fro is 1 hour and you should purchase your ticket 2 days in advance to make sure you don't need to standby for seats.The standard room we stayed (double bed, I wasn't sure if the twin bed rooms were full) was sufficiently sized and enough for us to open our large suitcases. The bathroom was amply sized with a bathtub and I cannot rave enough about the hairdryer. Was considering to buy one home but the transformer was a concern for usage in HK. It dried my long hair at least half the time it would take were I to dry with my own hair dryer. Soft fluffy slippers eased my sore feet at the end of the day.The complimentary postcards featuring art drawn by artists they support was a nice touch, I sent off the postcards through reception and guess what? The postage is on the house so I sent my 2 postcards to Sydney and HK :)The location is definitely a bonus, just a few minutes away from Daimaru (with 3 floors of Tokyu Hands and a huge foodhall) and a bit further away from Tokyo Station, we took the train every day. As we went during Cherry blossom season, the next street was beautifully tree lined and we took quite a few pictures there too. Looking forward to my next visit to Tokyo and will definitely want to stay at Hotel Ryumeikan.

Great central location - walking distance from Tokyo station (Yeasu N exit). Good sized room - we expected smaller - and very comfortable. Very convenient for airport train. Reception staff spoke good English & had local district maps to help us find our way around. We ate breakfast at a coffee shop close by. There is a Citibank ATM 2 blocks away as many ATMs do not take foreign bank cards.Walking distance to the Palace gardens. would definitely stay again.

This is my 3rd time staying in this hotel. I have checked out for booking hotel around Tokyo station in serveral websites and found this hotel is the best in term of location, the hotel is not old and the price is reasonable though there are some more stars hotels around the areabut the price is on expensive side. 5 minutes walking to the Tokyo station. There are some food and convenience stores near by as well as buses to airports. The bus stops are in walking distance.

We stayed for 5 nights in this hotel and we are more than happy that we have chosen the Ryumeikan for our stay in Tokyo. The roomsize was ok, although we had a "small room". It was very clean, the shower was great and there was free coffee available. Also the bed was very comfortable and although smaller than our standards, big enough!The hotel was only a few steps away from Tokyo station, very conveniant as you can really find everything there, shopping mall, plenty of restaurants,... Next to the hotel is the excelcior café and a bit further starbucks if you don't want to pay the 2000 yen for breakfast at the hotel. Also nextdoor a family mart, small supermarket with cold drinks, snacks etc...We liked it a lot and will definately go back at a next visit to Tokyo!

Location ! Location ! Location ! This hotel is so handy when moving around in Tokyo. Staff are very helpful, and rooms are very clean and updatd ! We have been staying here for every trips we did in Tokyo.

This hotel is ll worth the hype and rightfully deserve its 5 star excellence! Check in and out is a whizz away, security is top notch with only your key card that could access that level.Room is bigger than the usual Tokyo hotel rooms, comfortable with more than an average amenities one can desire, from hair dryer to wi-fi to green tea. You name it, there have it. (Even tv speaker in the toilet!). Bed is one of the most comfortable you could find.It is also well situated in Tokyo with jr Tokyo station just 3mins walk away, and bus stop just a couple of blocks away, both with transport access to and from the airport. Staff is well equipped with English language as well.If you are going in the Sakura blooming season, you could even catch the blooming on the next street as well.There's no better hotel under my opinion in Tokyo that could match them in terms of money well spent, location and comfyness.

I stayed at the hotel on my first visit to Japan in March/April 2013. The service at the hotel was flawless. The rooms spotless, comfortable and the beds with the music and vibrating feet to put you to sleep at night are an amazing addition. The rooms are so quiet too, so a good nights sleep is guaranteed. There are plenty of amenities in the room including coffee, tea, a fridge and lots of bath room toiletries. The hotel is super quiet and the location was great, right across from the Tokyo station. It's a short walk to some fantastic food places, and also make sure you take a walk and wander down under Daimaru and taste some of the delicious food available there, including fresh fruits and vegetables, fish, and bakeries.I would 100% stay here again on my next visit.

My wife and I spent two nights here. The hotel is very conveniently located a five minute walk from Tokyo station.We chose the hotel for its ease of access to Tokyo station with its easy access to Narita on the Narita Express. The hotel is also just around the corner from Nihombashi metro station. In terms of location it was a very good choice, you can easily get to/from the airport, travel around Tokyo and then return to this little oasis of calm. There are plenty of restaurants near to the hotel, most of them either had English menus or plastic food, so it is relatively easy for non-Japanese speakers.The room was well equipped with an en suite bathroom containing a fantastic shower. We stayed in a Forus room, which is an interesting concept. The bed vibrates in time with music to send you to sleep and the lights slowly brighten to wake you in the morning. It is certainly a novel experience.The reception staff were very helpful, we asked lots of questions about places we would like to see and they were happy to tell us how to get there. They also gave us maps, an English guide to Tokyo and an English guide with basic Japanese phrases.Would we return? Yes. Next time we have a layover in Tokyo we will stay at the Ryumeikan.

When I had booked my Tokyo trip months in advance I came upon this hotel through my Trip Advisor research but passed on it as it wasn't on sale and opted for another hotel instead but am very happy it did go on sale closer to arrival and I was able to switch my stay as I very much enjoyed my recent 3 night stay at this high quality hotel in an outstanding location.Rather than stay in a standard room I opted for a small upgrade to the Forus Discovery room and with a 30% off sale with full prepayment booked several weeks in advance at roughly $150 night found it a very good value given the central location of the Ryumeikan to Tokyo Station and near many far pricier luxury hotels. My room was 815 and since it faced another building's wall really had no view but that helped make it darker and easier to sleep for me. The Forus room category also feature a programmable sleep aid system that plays soothing music and gently vibrates the foot of the double bed and brings down the lights and does the reverse at the time you want to awaken that you set into the bedside control panel. I originally thought it a bit of a gimmick but it really is a pleasant way to drift off and awaken over some anonymous digital alarm clock beeping. The Discovery room also features a large shower stall, no tub, with five shower heads & nozzles you could adjust to your liking and it made for an invigorating start to the day that I grew to like. While not a large room as I was staying solo it was plenty big enough and offered plenty of well designed storage including drawers below the bed that I could put clothes and personal items away but still have them easily at each. The heated toilet seat and choice of toilet controls also sat well with me. Rounding out the room features was a nice Nespresso coffee maker, flat screen TV with a few channels in English (CNN & BBC), good soundproofing so you didn't hear your neighbors, individual heating & cooling plus and an in-room safe were also other room features that made this little room a comfortable place to unwind and get some restful sleep away from a hectic city while still being right in the middle of it.The staff is also as wonderfully helpful and hospitable accommodating my requests and answering my questions quickly and efficiently. The hotel is exceedingly well managed and run and you notice that in many ways from staff interaction to art postcards the hotel will post at their cost to bike rentals and Yubisashi city maps that are printed in both English & Japanese to ease your sightseeing should you get lost. In short, lots to like about this hotel and recommend to those wanting a central location at a decent price. I can't really find much to fault about the entire stay except that perhaps the terms & conditions of the 30% off promotion could be a little clearer when booked online as while I couldn't find it written anywhere despite having to fully prepay at time of booking to a credit card this rate is completely refundable up to 2 days prior to arrival as was confirmed to me by a staff member when I'd email asking about the fine print. That, however, is a very small detail compared to everything the Ryumeikan does and does very well and were I to return to Tokyo would definitely put this hotel at the top of my list of hotels as I'd love to return for longer than 3 nights.

Other than a small hiccup at check in, this was an excellent hotel. We booked a triple room (which was a twin with an extra bed) and we had plenty of space even with a cot in the room as well. Take care to book a triple for three people (apparently this is not assumed when paying extra for a triple). The woman that checked us in was quite surly, an anomaly in Japan I found, but the rest of the staff were outstanding. I left something at our previous hotel that they organised to get to me overnight at a very reasonable price, and one staff member even walked with my 4 year old son to the post box at 9pm (it was outside the hotel and down the street a little) as he didn't understand that they would send his postcards for him- so lovely. The hotel is in a great location, a few blocks from the mammoth Tokyo station, which has food options that would take a year to sample. It is walking distance from the shopping district of Ginza and there is an airport bus for Narita outside and one for Haneda down the road. There is also a convenience store next door. There is a laundry room in the hotel which is a godsend when travelling with little children!I highly recommend this hotel if it is in your budget. It has a lovely feel to it, the rooms are really nice and the toiletries were excellent - my aching body appreciated the bath soaks each night after walking all day! All in all, a great end to our trip to Japan.

Awesome hotel. The location can't be beat. You're just down the street from Tokyo Station, a major transportation hub. The area around you has plenty of restaurants, shopping, etc. This is a hotel that has thought of all the little things. I stayed in the cheapest room they had, but I still had slippers, coffee and tea every morning, and a wide range of toiletries. They also included origami paper and a free postcard which they mail and pay the postage for. It's the little touches like that that make this hotel awesome. The only downside (and this isn't even really a big deal) is that the cheapest room might be a bit cramped for two people. I was on my own, so it was perfect. I was expecting small, so it was fine. As a side note, I planned the trip with a friend who because of scheduling had to book a hotel later. He booked one right down the street and roughly the same amount that I paid per night, but when I went to visit him, I was shocked at how much nicer my room was than his. Seriously, this hotel is fantastic. Book now!

Great location (couple of blocks from the palace and across the street from Tokyo central). Rooms are small but not tiny. Very comfortable. Fantastic shower. It has everything you need and superb service.
user_name:
ale g
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We stayed five days at this hotel. It was just across the road from Toyko Central Station and consequently at the hub of all train services.The staff were excellent in every respect, polite, helpful and friendly.The rooms was a little small but very clean, comfortable and quiet. We did not have breakfast in the hotel as their restaurant served mostly Japanese food and I am not very adventurous when it comes to sampling strange food.The reception is on the 15th floor and all bedrooms are on floors below this which is an advantage in that you do not have to go through Reception when coming or going.We used Tokyo as a base to visit other locations and the hotel was an ideal spot to come back to to replenish our energy cells.We regard it as somewhat of a find because of its location and at the same time quiet and resful.

We chose this hotel on other reviews read on Trip advisor. As we were only spending a short time in Tokyo we needed something close to the station for the bullet train to Nagano. Excellent location only 2-3 minute walk to the station, comfortable beds, ( my husband liked the special bed) great shower/bathroom and very clean. Staff spoke excellent English and nothing was a drama...they even helped him find a barber on a busy Saturday morning. We will be definitely staying here again on on next trip.....

This hotel, perfectly located, is just down the block from Tokyo Station and has flawlessly executed rooms that are certainly large enough, by Tokyo standards. GREAT beds. Quiet, clean, spotless. The price ideal.I think this is a superb find.I left a cashmere blazer in the closet and they tracked me down at my next to hotel. Extraordinary.

We stayed for one night here as we arrived in Tokyo. The staff were very helpful, spoke excellent English and did all they could to make sure our arrival in Japan was as easy as possible. The proximity to Tokyo station was especially convenient if you need to use the Shinkansen.

The room, bed, and bathroom were perfectly fine. The location, for us as first-time visitors, was great. In five days, we must have spent four hours in Tokyo Station, just 3 minutes away and a city in itself. We had made plans to meet our local guide (a great free service, by the way--Google it) for breakfast our first morning there. Until you have seen an all-Japanese buffet you have no idea how different our cuisines are. We love Japanese food, but not for breakfast. And at $80 for three, eating eel at 7:00am was no bargain. We did eat dinner in one night, and it was very good although lacking in any atmosphere. The staff is friendly, but no too fluent in English.

Service and location is great!!! The Tokyo train station is at 3 min walking distance so you can get to the train or the metro extremly fast. The fish market is better to go in taxi if you want to go to the tuna auction. The only thing is that the rooms are a little small but it is expected in Japan. He sooner you make the reservation the better!!! Highly recommended. If you go there, there is an excellent Japsnese restaurant near by. Walk out of the Hotel to the left ( south) no more than 2 streets and on the left side after a golf store turn right. The rethaurant will be to your right downstairs. It's name it's Mizuki.

I am writing this review from my bed in the hotel! That's how happy my husband and I are with our stay.The location can't be beat for access to the train station.The room is so clean and comfortable and super quiet, I can't hear a sound from the busy street outside. That may be because our room is butted up against the next building with a view of a wall, but for our needs it's perfect. We arrived from NYC yesterday and after 20 hours of traveling were delighted for an easy check in and hot and powerful shower in a super clean non-smoking room. The tub is deep too, which if we were here longer I would soak in for sure. We walked about 20 mins to find a specific place to eat, which turned out to be closed, but stumbled upon a lot of dining options right near KANDA station, which was only about 10 mins from the hotel on foot. We had an AMAZING ramen meal at a tiny and authentic restaurant. What a wonderful way to say hello to Tokyo. We picked this hotel because we are leaving for Osaka in a couple of hours and walking to the train station was a priority.We are here for only one night, but would stay again in a heartbeat. For price, location and comfort level Ryumeikan can't be beat!

Wonderful to have such a good value in central Tokyo. Wish they had a gym, but other than that, no complaints. Room well appointed but naturally small. Lobby small and no other public spaces than restaurant but Tokyo at your feet.
user_name:
Lpdds
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel was perfect in every way. Quiet, clean, relaxing room. Great service. Perfect location to everything in Tokyo...especially the train stations. When we return to Tokyo, this is where we'll stay. The room amenities are above and beyond. Loved it. This might be the best nights sleep we've ever had.

This hotel is ideally situated for the first time visitor to Tokyo and Japan as it is 200m from the main railway station from which you can board the Shinkanzen (bullet) trains. The reception for the hotel is on the top floor (Floor 14) and the rooms are on the 6 floors below - the rest of the building is given over to offices and so the entrance at ground level is a bit understated.Our room was smaller than the norm in European hotels but was by no means as tight as other reviewers of Japanese hotels would suggest. The room was bright and modern and the double bed was very comfortable. The bathroom was superb - shower only - and the range of toiletries and other suchlike items was great - and they were replenished daily. There was free coffee from a Nespresso machine in the room. There was free and effective WiFi.The staff were very friendly, polite and helpful. It is also possible to borrow laptops and umbrellas from reception.All in all - a great stay for the 5 nights we were there.

Excellent location, quiet, clean, a place to relax even if located in the heart of business affairs, a lot of amenities (Nespresso capsule machine included that I, as Italian, appreciated a lot!). I didn't try breakfast.

As I’m sure you’ve already read from other reviewers, the rooms are tiny—but this hotel is awesome! It is centrally located—literally a three-minute walk from Tokyo station. It is quiet and spotless with friendly and helpful staff. Add to this list of pros the price and there is no reason to look any further for your hotel needs. We didn’t try the restaurant on-site (which I believe other reviewers said was expensive), but there are so many places to eat nearby that you’ll be spoiled for choice. Our children loved all the food in the Tokyo station basement—if they had it their way we would have had all our meals there. My only complaint applies to most hotels in Japan (and Asia for that matter)--the mattress is too hard for my taste.

Great location across the road from Tokyo Station (Yaesu North Exit), where the shinkansen (bullet trains) arrive, and many metro lines run through, including the Keiyo line to Disneyland. The hotel restaurant offers Japanese food only, but there are many other fantastic restaurants and coffee shops nearby. The Daimaru department store is located across the road at the Yaesu North exit of Tokyo Station, and has the amazing food hall in the basement as well as excellent cafes on almost every floor, and the 12th and 13th floors have numerous very good restaurants that are open until late at night.We got interconnecting rooms, which were perfect for our family of 4. The rooms were very clean with lovely amenities, including a Nesspresso machine. The beds were very comfortable, with a choice of pillows.An express bus for Narita (900 yen per person one-way) leaves hourly from a stop about 50 meters from the hotel door.

The room is very clean, warm and comfortable.it is better if The bed size could be larger . The location is very great. It is a good choice if you want to have a free travel in Tokyo. Next time I still choice them when I back Tokyo.

clean, more than acceptable. no cons.just in front of the central station (if you get to find the correct exit)important: there is an english pub right next door. excellent after too much miso soup and sushi.
user_name:
Compass431801
Castellon de la Plana, Spain

review_body: Stayed here overnight because my connecting flight was next day. The hotel is conveniently located near Tokyo station in a recently revived business district and is about an hour train ride from Narita. Great location if you want to explore Tokyo and relatively close to the airport but don't want to be stuck in an airport hotel or an airport town like Narita. Check-in was fast and staff was helpful. I have no complains. The room and bath are small but was not surprising for Japanese standards. Very clean and comfortable. I liked the Toto toilet with heated seat and all the other cool functions that leave you squeaky clean. The tub and shower are sparkling clean. The best and nice surprise was all the amenities they provide like slippers and foot massager (most especially helpful after a long haul flight), complete set of toiletries with bath salt and sponge exfoliator, nightshirt, green tea and hot water heater, city map with useful Japanese words. The bed was firm and comfortable and they provide rice pillows and regular pillows and fluffy down comforter. It was truly a comfortable and relaxing stay and after a long haul flight I felt refreshed and ready for my connecting flight next day.Great value for money relative to more expensive Tokyo hotels. Thumbs up and highly recommend!
user_name:
NewYorkWorldExplorer
New York City, New York

review_body: The Rymeikan hotel is a short stroll fron the Tokyo central train station. The rooms are clean & tidy. The hotel lobby is in the 15th floor along with a japanese resturant . Close by is the Excelsior coffee shop not a bad place to sit down and organise your day. The room was quite cool ( or not ) having a port hole from the main room looking into the bath room ( high up the wall for the not so extroverted), the toilet has the bideau functions attached also. Room was warm & plenty of hot water. Great toiletries tray provided along with robes & slipers. This was vlaue for money ( last minute booking ), and is perfectly located for use of the Tokyo underground rail system. Also the local food eateries are great if you want to have a short stroll from the hotel.Thanks Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo

Amazing location next to the Marunouchi train station, pleasantly decorated and spotless clean little rooms with lots of nice-to-have ammenities (i really liked the cable that allows to plug an ipod to speakers over the bed). Service is very professionnal, as usual in Japan. I paid less than 15.000Y per night for the forus room, which accommodates 2 people; it's a bit tight, but not uncomfortable. Unbeatable value for money in central Tokyo.

Stayed at the Ryumeikan Tokyo for 7 days with my girlfriend over Christmas this year. To be honest, we were a bit anxious before we arrived about how the hotel will be. But the moment we stepped off the taxi, we were absolutely in love with the place. Here's why.The property is in pristine shape. It's not a typical hotel where you walk into the lobby on the ground floor and there are tourists and staff falling over each other. Rather, the entrance is more like an apartment, with only a lift lobby. For the reception, you'd have to go to the 15th floor. We loved this, as we felt like we were staying in a serviced apartment, rather than a hotel. We stayed at a Forus C room. Our room, although slightly smaller than average, was very well designed. There was great utilization of space, plenty of amenities in the bathroom and main room (including Nespresso machine). The bathroom was immaculate, with a separate shower booth (great force on the shower) and the legendary ToTo automatic toilet. The only drawback of the room was no view, and very little storing space (two compartments under the bed). For 2 people that's a bit tight, but it's very manageable. The room, otherwise, was very quiet with comfortable bed and pillows.The staff were extremely polite, as are the entire population of the great city of Tokyo. They were very eager to help out with any queries with excellent command of English. Thanks to wonderful(sarcasm) Air China, our baggage was delayed by a day and the staff were very cooperative during the process, coordinating with the airline whenever they could. The best thing was that the hotel's staff was always there when you needed them, but never really in your face otherwise. The staff always makes the hotel. No wonder we had a great stay!Last but in no way the least, the location of this hotel is unbeatable. It is literally steps away from the Tokyo Central station, which is the main hub for all metro and commuter trains in and out of Tokyo, including the Shinkansen. But don't think this makes it a crowded area, you won't even feel like you're staying next to a central station. The hotel is also walking distance from the Imperial Palace, which is on the Marounochi side of the station, among other things. Daimaru, which is right opposite the hotel is the legendary Japanese department store. The neighborhood has plenty of sushi bars, ramen places as well as a Starbucks. You couldn't find a better location for a hotel.7 days wasn't enough for a first-time trip to Tokyo. We're definitely coming back and when we do, we won't even bother looking for any other hotel. Hopefully, Ryumeikan will have a room available! Carry on the great work, guys!

Hotels in Tokyo aren't cheap, but I'd have to say this one was affordable AND awesome. CONVENIENT LOCATION. Really enjoyed our experience - we only booked 1 night here because it is near Tokyo Station which we were departing from the next day for a Kyoto trip. Wished we would've stayed longer.FRIENDLY STAFF. We asked the reception to keep our bags for the few days that we were away so that we could pick it up when we return. Great service, friendly English-speaking staff.AWESOME ROOM. Our room had a rain shower thing and even a spot to sit. Very nice. Love the bed with the music and speaker to help us relax or even wake us up in the morning! Japanese rooms are tiny, this one is small also, but not overly so.SPECIAL TOUCHES. It was our honeymoon and they gave us a nice bottle of champagne. And bathrobes come as standards for most hotels in Japan I think, but Ryumeikan also provides us with a little booklet with Tokyo map, subway map and some Japanese lessons. Very helpful since that was the start of our journey.We will definitely return (to Tokyo and to this hotel.)

it is a real nice hotel, i'm so glad i booked it, excellent location , though the Tokyo station isn't easy to get mastered in first place. Hotel itself is so wonderful, specially the shower , the famous Japanese style ToTo toilet. and the bed is so nice, with music and speaker combined to help for relaxing and wake up ! room itself is nice with well design, not small at all. the good design for the bed make it not feel like a semi double bed.  It is a very pleasent staying, have to share it.

We stayed here on a family holiday and while it was not cheap to have two rooms for 4 people it was worth it for the extra space as the interconnecting rooms include a bigger corner room. The rooms also included a Nespresso machine, much appreciated, and the beds were very comfortable. Like a lot of smaller mid-range hotels in the city there is no pool or gym. The location is very central opposite Tokyo railway station for the JR line and shinkansen and adjacent to the Nihombashi metro. There is a good FamilyMart convenience store down the road and several nice cafes and restaurants. The hotel staff were outstanding ; very helpful with directions, maps and writing addresses in Japanese. They staged a great mochi pounding on New Years Day. We would definitely stay here again.

My husband and I stayed one night in at the hotel, and we had a wonderful experience. The staff was friendly, the room was clean, and they had many nice amenities in the room. Like many other Japanes hotels, they provided humidifier, comb, shaving kit, headband, pijama, slippers, etc. When we checked out of the hotel, the staff gave us hand warmers for the road. Very thoughtful. The hotel is located only few minutes away from Tokyo Station. It has free wifi. The rooms are tastefully decorated. My room did not have a nice view, but the other amenities, the staff, and the location made up for it. The room is small, but it is the standard hotel room and bed size in Japan. We stayed at a double bedroom, and it was comfortable for two people. I will definitely recommend this hotel and will stay there again.

I stayed here with my parents in a triple room. Location was so convenient as it was only a few short minutes from Tokyo station/Nihonbashi and close to many quality department stores.There was a convenience store and bakery downstairs and there was a shuttle bus to Narita airport.Wifi connection was very good.Overall a great hotel that made sightseeing and getting around a breeze.I look forward to coming back to this hotel.

This is the third year running that we are staying at Hotel Ryumeikan on our annual trip to Tokyo. Hotel improves in their service quality every year. The triple room is great size for Tokyo and amenities & condition top notch. Very convenient by airport limousine to/fro Haneda and also Narita. Good eating places eg. izakaya near hotel and Tokyo station.

This was another excellent hotel we stayed in during our 10 day tour of Japan.Spotlessly clean , very quiet, friendly staff - a great view too from the hotels restaurant - right above the city skyline.We only stayed here for one night but the location was perfect - literally across the road from Tokyo station - ideal for getting anywhere in and around Tokyo.Highly recommended.
user_name:
Amy_Lea_10
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: The Florus semi double room was a great way to get over the jet lag from 9.5 hrs of flying, not to mention the airport wait at departure . A bit compact but not lacking in amenities except for closet and perhaps towel-hanging space. Location was great, although because our flight arrived so late at Haneda, we took the bus to the TCAT terminal (900 yen) and then a taxi to the hotel (around 1000 yen). If you have a lot of luggage and need to take the bus instead of train back to the airport, the bus pick up is a short walk to the left , right in front of the Hokkaido store, directly across Tokyo station. The food was great if you like Japanese food, like we do. The buffet breakfast's western items included dry cereal , milk, yogurt, fresh fruit, coffee and sausage. Toast or croissants would have been nice. We will definitively return if staying in Tokyo.

The location of this hotel is absolutely fantastic for getting around the city. You can get from here to pretty much anywhere with real ease.The hotel is a 5-10 minute walk from the Yaesu North entrance of Tokyo station. It's actually on the same road. Nihombashi subway station is around the corner, a 2-3 minute walk away.Otemachi subway may look close on the map, but it's a good 20 minute walk. It's handy if you have to use it, but plan to get by without it if you can.Even though the hotel is right in the city, next to the station. It's easily the quietest city hotel I've stayed in. The room doors are big heavy fire doors, but they soft close with literally no sound.We didn't hear any noise from the street, even though there was construction work going on on the other side of the road from the hotel. The windows are obviously very well sound proofed.Depending on which website you use to book, they describe the rooms differently which is a bit confusing. I was travelling with my wife and we booked a standard 'semi double' which on the Ryumeikan website is actually called a 'standard single'. Essentially this is a room with a normal double bed (for UK sizes) pushed against the wall. The room was very small, there's only just enough room to open a large suitcase on the floor. There's no wardrobe, the only hanging space is a hook on the wall for a couple of coats and a few shirts maximum.There's a fridge in the room that they stocked with bottles of water we used each day and were free of charge. There's a small convenience store right next to the hotel which is handy.The array of toiletries provided in the bathroom was actually quite impressive. In amongst the collection were a hairbrush, toothbrush, shower cap, hair band, bath salts, shaving gel and moisturiser.Little things that impressed me were the mirror in the bathroom was heated so it doesn't steam up. The shower gel and shampoo were topped up every day so they were always full. There were slippers and pyjamas provided. The toilet is a funky Japanese toilet with a heated seat and all the bidet features that appear to be standard in Japan. These are minor things, but I've paid a lot more for hotels in London and got nothing like the level of service this hotel provided.Another example, when we arrived they gave us warm towels and a pocket map of Tokyo.Additionally, we actually checked out of this hotel and back in again after staying in Kyoto for a few days. The hotel reception were more than happy to look after a case and bag of ours whilst we were away. This was free of charge and when we checked in the second time they'd already put our bags in our room. Another nice touch.Overall I fully recommend this hotel. The location is truly excellent for getting around Tokyo, combined with the high level of service, it makes it really great value for money.

We stayed in a double room which had a king size bed and a small sitting area. The bed was really firm which we prefer. Considering its location the room was also really quiet, even with construction work happening across the road. We couldn't hear any noises from outside or the neighbouring rooms. The bathroom facilities were comprehensive and really well kept with the typical Japanese toilet and a shower and bath. Air con and heating was easy to adjust. We didn't have breakfast included, but thought we would try the hotel breakfast on the first day. It's pretty much Japanese fare only, and even though we were prepared to be adventurous, we just couldn't handle that sort of food to start the day, so went to some local cafes for a more Western option for the rest of our time. The hotel is right next to the Nihombashi subway so it's very easy to access public transport. **TIP** If you get dropped off by the airport limousine bus all you need to do is head left as you step off the bus straight down the road a couple of blocks. If you've been walking for more than five mins you've probably gone past it. The hotel is on the same side of the street as the bus drop off. We were given a map at the airport that showed something entirely different, so we spent a fair bit of time wandering around trying to get our bearings. If you look up as you're walking, you'll see the big R for Ryumeikan on the top of the hotel building before you get to the hotel.

Stayed at Ryumeikan for 7 days - both in their Japanese Styled Junior Suite and Twin Room.The Suite is fantastic, while the Twin Room was nothing much to shout about.The suite came with free drinks (mini bar) and movies.The Toilet amenities are more than generous, not forgetting the superb heated toilet seat, which really does help in the cold weather.Breakfast was Japanese affair, which did help as we had many cafe breaks with western style meals.

I booked this hotel because of the reviews by Trip Advisor contributors and was delighted to find the hotel as nice as described. The basic room that I booked through hotels.com with one double bed was very small with one place to put a suitcase and no closet. The window had a wide and long sill on which I put most of my folded clothes. Despite the lack of a closet and the compactness of the room, everything looked new, was immaculate, and felt very cosy. There was a small fridge, hairdryer, LCD TV (with only 2 English language channels -- CNN and BBC), and great ethernet and/or wifi connections at no cost. The outlets in the hotel fit standard 2-prong U.S. plugs (either the grounded kind or the old ones with 2 identical prongs). There is a decent desk with an office chair. The bathroom had a deep tub and an on-the-wall or hand-held shower with fabulous water pressure. The toilet had a heated seat and other nice options. The mirror over the sink had a defogger so that even when the room fogged up from a shower, a part of it was always clear. The amenities were abundant and nice -- robe, slippers (replenished when I took a pair to bring home), shoe brush, toothbrush, hairbrush, comb, razor, facial cleansers and moisturizers (no body lotion however), liquid shower soap, shampoo and conditioner. Despite its downtown location, the room was very quiet with the windows closed. My room (1105) was right over the A/C/heating system and so it was very noisy when I opened the windows -- imagine that this would be true for the same and neighboring rooms on the 10 - 14th floors. The hotel felt very safe as a key is required to get to the hotel floors (note that this is a business building with the hotel being on the upper floors). The reception is on the top floor (15) which is not immediately clear when you walk into the building. Walking in from the street, you need to turn left and go through another set of glass doors to the elevators and then go up to the 15th floor. There is a sign downstairs,but it's on an LED screen that rotates so that I saw nothing in English or indicating where the hotel was when I first walked in.The staff were okay, but the ones I interacted with did not have great English and I don't speak Japanese. The advice they gave me on getting to Narita airport was confusing with one staff member recommending one bus company (the one right next to the hotel) and another saying definitely not to use that bus as it was complicated and required buying a ticket from a specific convenience store (apparently not the one nearby). (I'm adding some transportation tips under Tokyo Central Station).As noted by others, the location of the hotel is very central. Tokyo is a town of distinct neighborhoods, and the Ryumeikan is in a very business-y area with Tokyo Station a block away. The area doesn't have a lot of character, but there are many restaurants nearby and the station has more restaurants as well as a department store, Daimaru, that has an expansive selection of prepared foods, including sushi, tempura, sweets, etc. on the lowest level. There is a "Family Mart" (convenience store) right next to the hotel and "Excelsior Cafe" is 2 doors down. Were I to return to Tokyo, I would certainly consider staying here again; the reason I might not would be because I would like to be in another area with more little shops.

I am so pleased that I chose to stay at Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo. It is located across the street from Tokyo Terminal (JR Lines and various other trains, including Shinkansen) and around the corner from Nihombashi Station (Tokyo Metro). And with its close proximity to these transportation lines, you can bet there are an ample number of restaurants and shops nearby. But let me also mention the hotel's amenities. I thought the service and accommodations at the ANA Crowne Plaza Osaka were par excellence, so I wasn't expecting much when I arrived at Hotel Ruumeikan. But boy, was I wrong. The hotel is very quiet and "boutique-y" and has laundry facilities for its guests. The staff is very helpful and all speak amazing English. My room (single) is immaculate and although it doesn't have an official closet, the frills within it make up for the lack of storage space. There's an in-room espresso machine.
