There's an ample office area. There's a small refrigerator. They leave clean pajamas for me daily. Sound good? Wait, there's more! My room is a FORUS room. I wasn't sure what that meant when I booked the room, but let me tell you: it's heaven. When I want to go to sleep I turn my FORUS sound system on. It automatically turns down all the lights in my room and begins to lull me to sleep with relaxing music and vibrations at the foot of my bed. I've never figured out how long this plays because since my first night here I've fallen asleep within a few minutes. When I set the alarm clock the opposite happens... The lights in my room gradually begin to come on about ten minutes prior to my wake time. Ten minutes later the lights are fully on, music plays to awaken me sweetly, and soft vibrations beckon me to get up. I'm seriously wanting one of these systems in my house!Tonight is my fourth night at the Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo and I've found everything to be consistently terrific. Book your room!!!

Just returned home after 8 nights at this well located hotel. The twin rooms were of a reasonable size given that it is Tokyo and much larger than some of the other hotels nearby. The location is brilliant. A 5 minute walk from the Limousine Bus Service drop off/pick up point for Tokyo Station, a Ginza line subway station around the corner and a 5 minute walk to Tokyo station & the shinkansen. Also in the small streets behind the hotel there is a myriad of restaurants offering every imaginable Japanese food choice which complements the huge choice available at the station. Reception staff speak Engish and are very helpful. The rooms are very clean and have all that a traveller needs including a Nespresso machine. The beds ae firm but very comfortable and my dodgy back was all the better for sleeping in them. Am planning my next trip to Tokyo and will definitely stay here.

The new Forus rooms are amazing, they have 3 types (A/B/C), i had the chance to try type A and B, type B is slightly bigger and have a sofa inside the room. But in any Forum room, what makes it different is the sleeping tech, you can set your preferred wake up time and once you click Start, the room lights will be auto switched off, the music will be softly played until you feel so relaxed and fell asleep. When the preset wake up time is up, the music will be played again, and room lights will be on. You can also switch on the foot vibration. This sleeping experience is very unique and very useful when u need a good quality sleep.The room rate is a bit pricey but given a premium location it's totally worth all the penny. Just cross the street to enter Tokyo station (north entrance, for shinkansen track) or a few steps from Shimbashi station if u want to take Tokyo MetroThe service from the front desk staff is super, on my arrival day it was raining, so after checked in a staff offered me an umbrella. The second day i was supposed to move to another Forum room, the staff told me to just pack my bag and leave it in the room, they will move it to the new roomOn my departure date, i carried too many luggages, was just checking if any porter from the hotel could help, one of the frontdesk staff (a lady) was giving me a hand, carried one of my luggage to Tokyo station, it was beyond hotel service that i had in my life so far.Overall, i'm very pleased with Ryumeikan hotel. I'll recommend this hotel to anyone especially those going to Japan for business related.

We stayed four nights at this hotel at the beginning of our Japan trip. It is next to Tokyo Station and is an easy five minute walk from where the Narita limousine bus service stops. The room was small (no room to unpack, to speak of), but otherwise comfortable, with a great bed! There's a full-sized bath tub and a very nice shower. Room slippers are provided and they encourage you to keep them. The lobby is on the 15th floor, above the rooms. We didn't spend much time there, but wished we could have. The staff was very helpful and arranged to courier our large suitcase to our next destination--a service that is very reasonably priced and worth every penny!

I stayed here over a weekend in October and found the staff incredibly polite & helpful, the room efficient and well appointed for the business traveller, and conveniently located for the tourist or business traveller. Very close to Tokyo station where trains to Narita, the city, or all points in Japan. Highly recommend it if this price point is in your travel budget.

I booked this hotel for one night on my way from Vancouver to Kyoto only because of it's proximity to Tokyo Station so I didn't really have high expectations. I was delighted to find it immaculately clean, very well appointed with robes, slippers and a wide array of bathroom amenities and very comfortable. Fast internet. The front desk staff were very welcoming and helpful. The location is great, really just steps from Tokyo Station and within walking distance of some great shops and restaurants - including The Ginza. There's even a Starbucks around the corner.

We stayed in this hotel for 2 nights in November 2012 and found it very comfortable and convenient. We booked a corner room which was large, very well appointed and maintained to a very high standard. The staff spoke good English and were helpful when we arrived. What is unusual about this hotel is that the Reception area is on the top floor of the hotel (15th Floor) and the rooms are on floors 8 to 14. It is only 3 minutes walk from Tokyo Station which makes it convenient for arriving in Tokyo or departing from Narita Airport.

Great location between two subway stations (Tokyo and Nihombashi) so most sights are easily accessible from at least one of the subway options without having to change lines. Clean and quiet, but also with a number of extra touches like slippers and a robe and I really liked the way the keycard worked. The card was swiped over the pad on the door to unlock it (or to access the proper floor on the elevator). I find most keycards annoying because you need to introduce them into the key slot and then slide them out and hope that gives you a green light. Often that system requires multiple attempts, but at Hotel Ryumeikan it works every time.

it's located very close to the main train station and is easy to find. some people may find the reception on the top floor strange, but i actually preferred it. i only need to go to them at check-in and out, otherwise i would call the front desk. the view wasn't that great due to construction, but i didn't come to tokyo to sit in a hotel. the rooms were very clean, the service impeccable, and the level of english spoken here is good. at the airport, we realized we forgot a large sum of money in the safe! luckily the staff were kind enough to wire it to our bank account after we called to explain our mistake. i will probably stay here again the next time i come to japan.

We stayed at this hotel twice - once at the start of our trip to Japan and we liked it so we booked to stay at the end of the trip, too. As per the other comments, the location is really, really good for exploring Tokyo and also other places nearby thanks to the proximity to the main train station.One useful tip: the hotel is even closer to Nihonbashi subway stop - which is on many useful subway lines. We only discovered this on our 2nd stay, it would have saved us quite a bit of time on the first stay!The rooms are comfortable, the compact ones are compact as you might expect (but not cramped), the others are pretty decent size for a hotel room.

The hotel is well situated for anyone arriving from the airport and debarquing at Tokyo station. Modern, clean and comfortable room with the ubiquitous automated modern toilets that you see even in McDonalds in Japan. Location is near the main upscale shopping district of Ghinsa and walking distance to the imperial gardens. Plenty of eateries and karaoke bars around. A good value overall.

I booked the hotel in Feb this year and they have got my booking just right when i checked in yesterday.I expected an older hotel and was pleasantly surprised that the hotel is very clean, new and modern. Although the room size is smaller, the layout and ergonomics was very good for a small room. Hotel personnel is polite and can speak understandable English.The hotel is very near to make transportation hub of Tokyo station which also house many food and shopping outlets.Will definitely come back again when in Tokyo.

The location of the Ryumeikan is almost ridiculously good. It's only a few minutes' walk away from Tokyo Station's North Exit (go out at the North Exit, cross the road and walk a little way left). There is also a 24-7 convenience store next door to the hotel. The room was a bit small, perhaps, but as I was on my own, the size was no trouble at all. It was clean and the bed was comfy. Staff at the reception speak good English. There are drinks vending machines on certain floors, which is useful if you need a drink and don't want to head downstairs to the convenience store. It's not cheap, but as I was looking for a place for just two nights with location as a priority (i.e. proximity to a major station served by the Narita Express), this proved to be worth the expense.

The room is very small thus either de or luxe but not both as you cannot fit deluxe into this room. If you like small Parisian hotel rooms, you will love this. The room has everything: the safe sits in a draw under the bed. The service is excellent, the room immaculate, the bathroom out of the late 21 st century with a toilet that will wash your bottom, heated seat, and self flushing. The shower has a large head, an additional wand, and several jets that you can direct at yourself. There is a small refrigerator in the room and a Netspresso. The internet works well.The hotel is across the street from the central Train Station, an ideal location to use to explore Tokyo and the price was reasonable.

This is a great option for exploring Tokyo! We booked the 'corner deluxe' room and it was huge! Very comfortable room with great layout and windows on two walls with views of the Tokyo station. Bathroom is awesome too with modern Toto fixtures. Very quiet hotel too. The location of the hotel is perfect! 3 min walk to Tokyo station and 1 min walk to the nearest subway station. Don't worry about staying near a train station - I think Tokyo is the only city in the world where the area near the station is nice and very business like and not dirty. And to get to the hotel from the airport just take the Ne'Ex train and get off at Tokyo, go up to 1st/street level and follow the signs for Yaesu North Exit and then follow the easy directions on the hotel's website. It's a 5 min walk.While staying in Tokyo I recommend doing a day trip to Hakone including one of their onsen (we really liked Tanzen Toji-kyo) - it was a highlight of the area and very easy to get to (just ask at the tourist office in Hakone-Yumoto).

We stayed at the Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo for one night at the beginning of our second Japan trip, having chosen this hotel on the basis of TripAdvisor reviews and weren't disappointed. Located a block from the entrance to the Tokyo JR station (the main hub for Shinkansens and the Narita Airport Express), it was in the ideal location for taking a Shinkansen. The staff were very professional, and the rooms new and clean. There was no view from our room (a Double Semi-Forus), but it didn't really matter as we spent most of our time recovering from jet lag or out and about. While the room was small, we found that there was still ample space for our two suitcases, along with a good sized desk and wireless internet - which was important for planning where we'd be going.The Semi-Forus room had a special bed which lulled you to sleep with sounds, surround sound speakers and vibrations to wake you up gently in the morning. It was an interesting novelty, and particularly Japanese! The shower was also amazing - you had a main shower head, as well as three smaller shower heads.A very good value-for-money hotel if you needed to stay around the Tokyo Station area. We'll be using it again for the same purposes next time round.

Very well located, walking distance from Ginza and just across Tokyo station. A lot of nice amenities. Rooms are tiny - at least by western standard. I would definitely repeat as a base to explore the city - but not if I needed to stay for long period in the room.

Ryumeikan is an excellent Tokyo hotel, located just on the other side of the street from Tokyo Station, which is a good hub for many trains, and there's loads of taxis around at any given time. The one funny thing about the hotel is that the reception is located in the top floor, instead of ground floor. There's a restaurant (with quite a pricey brekkie), and a pub downstairs (that's apparently never open), but the sheer amount of restaurants around Tokyo Station makes it up. Rooms - well, clean, beautiful, and feng shui to the max; toilet is also very good (no bathtub, but who needs one anyway) with *amazing* shower. You don't get to see the staff of the hotel that often, since well they are located in the top floor instead of ground, so there's no reason to hike up there usually. But who wants to see them anyway? And then there's the speakers, which I absolutely love. Yeah, great set of almost-surround-like speakers embedded in the bed, providing very good quality sound for evening/morning music listening, which is usually the one thing that's relatively complicated in a hotel room. Here, it's great, actually, amazing. View is practically non-existent, but who needs a view when you can head out to the city instead. Great place!
user_name:
Timo V
Helsinki, Southern Finland, Finland

review_body: I have stayed in many four and five star hotels and Hotel Ryumeikan far surpasses those hotels in terms of service, comfort, cleanliness and amenities. The room we had was small but compact with a very comfortable bed. Bottled water was available daily and the coffee maker was great. The front desk staff was very friendly and extremely helpful in guiding us on touring Tokyo and outskirts on our own. The restaurant served great Japanese food and the Japanese breakfast included a variety of juices and cereal for those not adventurous enough to try the Japanese breakfast items. The hotel is walking distance to the Tokyo Train Station with access to trains for the city or outside the city as well as access to underground shopping and a variety of dining options. It is just a ten minute walk to the East Imperial Gardens, really close to the Ginza and the surrounding restaurants serving delicious Udon and Soba meals. The hotel really reflected the Japanese people very well: cultured, orderly, courteous, efficient and comfortable. My husband and I hope we can visit again.

Perfect place to rest our heads the night we arrived from Canada and had to get a train the next day. Easy to find, clean, comfortable, loads of amenities and the restaurant had good food with an easy to navigate menu. Included breakfast was great too. Really close to ginza as well. Lots of good gawking and walking in the hood.

This hotel is within walking distance of the Tokyo train station, a great location for getting around in Tokyo as well as leaving for other places in Japan. We stayed at the hotel twice. Very nice rooms with comfortable beds. Exceptionally friendly and helpful staff at front desk. As other reviews have mentioned, the first time you look for the hotel can be tricky, but after you know where it is, getting around is easy. Find the North Exit of the Train station, cross the street, turn left, go down about two blocks...the hotel is on your right. This hotel is a good value and we will stay there again.

This is my 5th stay and I love it. It is located next to Tokyo Station (north east of the station to be exact) and from there you can get around whole Tokyo easily. I even took shinkansen to elsewhere for day trips as Tokyo Station is the terminus of Tokkaido and Tohoku lines.The size of the rooms are reasonable for Japanese standard and they are really clean. They also provide great amenities and you can find washing machines and dryers on 10th and 12th floor (guest rooms are located between 8th and 15th floors).There is also a bar and Family Mart just below the hotel. You can find more food and shops in Yaesu underground passage (a minute walk away) which connects to Tokyo Station.I will definitely be back again!

We only stayed here for one night before an early flight out of Narita, but how I wished we had found it earlier. It is well located opposite the Tokyo Train station, although it is a little hard to fathom the various exits at the station. But once we had that, it was very easy to find.All the satff we encountered were exceptional. Well versed in what was in and around the hotel, fluent in a number of languages and really friendly.It was a good sized room (for Tokyo!) with a magnificent bathroom. All the amenities were first class, with a range of tea and coffee options. The bed was very comfortable. So comfortable in fact that the early morning wake up seemed just so much harsher than it should be! The rooms are also quiet, with no noise from either the street or the neighbours.

The Hotel Ryumeikan was an unexpected treasure. It wasn’t as easy to find as we’d anticipated. Getting out of Tokyo Station to the Yaesu North Exit was a task in itself. Once going through the two parts of the Daimaru department store, we couldn’t easily see the building which is on the street directly out of the exit – look to the tops of the buildings for the hotel sign as in the pictures, to your left, on the opposite side of the street. Even the taxi driver parked in front of the station didn’t know where it was, including after seeing the address. There’s a diagonal crosswalk out of the Yaesu North exit – cross diagonally to 10 o’clock, and keeping walking past a couple of small streets/alleys, and the building will be almost at the end of the main street.Finding the building was the only challenging part – the rest was wonderful. Once inside the building, from reception where they gave us towels to freshen up, to the actual rooms, which were small but absolutely wonderful. They block out all the street noise, and are geared for a calming experience. The showers are exceptional – they have rainfall showerheads and massage showers, including a seat to sit on while the shower jets massage your back. The shower is built so that the steam also does flow out into the bathroom or the rest of the hotel room. The rooms are spotless. There are a large assortment of tea and coffee to choose from. They even provide mini fold up maps of the city and transport that include useful phrases in English and Japanese.This will be my new go to place each time I return to Tokyo – but the challenge may be the availability, as it wasn’t available the next time I tried. Seems like others have caught on to what a gem this place is!

I stayed in this hotel for one night as a stopover between Kyoto and Narita airport, so a location near Tokyo JR station was important. What I underestimated is that the station is massive, so it was still about a 15-20 minute walk from the hotel to the platform for the Narita Express back to the airport!It's very easy to find from the station but the one odd thing is that the reception is on the top floor of the building, with the rooms underneath - something I'd never seen before! The room was generously sized, for Japan, with a TV and the amenities you'd expect. The bed was large and comfortable, the bathroom clean.There are plenty of places to eat and shop nearby but obviously being so near the station opens the door to being anywhere in the city very easily.

We used this hotel for a two night stop over when travelling to Australia. It is in an extremely convenient location close to the main railway station. We booked direct with the hotel securing a corner room which was a very good size with separate bedroom, bath/shower room and toilet with automatic features! It was a spotlessly clean and well provisioned room. Even the smallest items were replaced after use and the free bottles of water much appreciated, as was the expresso machine. The beds were very comfortable indeed but storage was primarily hanging space rather than drawers. Access to the metro was good and the Imperial gardens and palace within easy walking distance; even in the heat of the summer. The staff were faultlessly polite and helpful. Free storage of our luggage on the day we flew to Sydney was very useful; we were even bid a personal farewell at the lift when we departed. Would certainly use this hotel again if we visited Tokyo again and recommend it to other travellers.

A true gem next to Tokyo station with easy access to all the major sights by subway. The decor is stylish boutique and the staff are extremely helpful and attentive. The standard rooms are small by western standards without closets or drawers but there are pegs for hangers and the rooms are clean and comfortable. The room amenities include free Wifi (very fast), kettle with a selection of teas, room safe and every toiletry you could ever need. The lobby on the 15th floor has wonderful views, free international papers and a very nice restaurant. This is a real treat and a great value.

We stayed one night while transiting through Tokyo and picked this hotel because of its proximity to Tokyo JR station. It took us some time to locate the front entrance as the hotel is located on top floors of an office building. Once inside, it's like a small boutique hotel. By the time we arrived, it was very late, but the evening staff were very professional and we had no problem checking-in. Since this was a one night stay, we paid for the lowest rate room, so, it's small, very small. I didn't expect much as this is Tokyo. Besides the basic, there were no other amenities in the room. The room was well maintained and clean. Our view was the adjacent non-descriptive office building. Since the hotel is across the street from the Tokyo JR station, there were plenty of food near-by and was very convenient.

The staffs understand a little English although not very fluent. However, they are extremely helpful & friendly. So, English or no English, they're willing to help, that works for me. Rooms are clean, free drinks everyday, from plain water to canned drinks. :) Free WiFi too.Superb location, its just a few minutes walk from Tokyo Station exit. All the main spots in Tokyo can be reached directly from Tokyo Station, lesser worries on changing train or station. Lots of restaurant, shops, department stores & a few tourist spots around it, reachable by just a few minutes walk.The streets nearby are planted cherry blossoms & hanami spot as well, ideal shooting spot for tourist in spring. :DI'll definitely come back to this Hotel again.

My granddaughter and I stayed here at the end of July. I was concerned that we were in a safe location and that it was close to Tokyo Station and the metro. Hotel Ryumeikan scored on both needs. We walked out of Tokyo Station and could see our hotel. ( I printed the directions from the web site ) The staff was great, they welcomed us with wet hand towels and noticed my birthday and sent some drinks to our room. Our room was modern, clean, had free water each day, free wifi and the fanciest toilet ever, and this wasn't my first trip to Japan. The toiletries were the best. This hotel is at the top of an office building with secure access to the hotel. All in all it was a great stay.

This hotel is excellently located just a stones throw from Nihombashi metro station and a very short walk from Tokyo Central Station which is ideal if you are travelling on within Japan via rail (also highly recommended!) For such a well located hotel it was really quiet and that, together with a very comfortable room, ensured that I slept perfectly for the two nights I was there. Yes, as others have said, the rooms are quite small, but you are in Tokyo centre so you are unlikely to be spending large amounts of (non-sleeping) time in your room!

Loved everything about Hotel Ryumeikan! Perfect central location, more upscale than I even imagined when booking, very modern yet tastefully decorated. Clean, chic and very satisfied! Yes, the rooms are small, but this is on par for Japan, so that wasn't a deal breaker for me. Wi-fi was also easy to access. If you want to eat breakfast at the hotel, I recommend making a reservation. We weren't able to eat there due to space. However, there are a TON of other options at the station across the street. Note: my parents (who were staying here as well) had trouble finding the hotel. I had no problem, as I had looked up other traveler's directions on how to find it. Go to North or Central Yaesu Exit out of Tokyo Central, go across the street, and turn left. It will be just past the mini mart store, and the lobby is on the 14th floor (not ground level!). Signs were well marked, however, guiding us to the elevator/reception! Great stay, would TOTALLY stay here again! : D

We booked a semi-double room, realising it was very small but hoping we'd be OK. One side of the generously sized bed was against the wall (apart from the complex control console) so one of us had to crawl to the end of the bed or over the other one but that was OK. While we were expecting the small size, the quality of the room facilities and fittings was a very pleasant surprise. There was an amazing array of toiletries and accessories. We didn't manage to work out all the buttons on the toilet control panel but it was interesting.As mentioned by other reviewers, the reception staff were very helpful and friendly although, with reception on the 15th floor and our room on the 8th, we didn't get to see them that often. The location just near Tokyo Station was really good and we walked to interesting places like the Imperial Palace and the Kite Museum.

We stayed one night in early June 2012 after flying in from New Zealand. As we were only in Tokyo for an overnight stay we wanted a hotel handy to a Narita Express/Shinkansen Station so this hotel was perfect. We found the hotel very easily by following instructions on their website -take the Yaesu North Exit and walk 'left' up the street. The hotel is on the other side of the road from the exit and has plenty of signage on top of the building and at street level.We booked a Forus 'semi double' and there was plenty of room for our overnight stay. Very tidy room and we were pleasantly surprised at how big the room was, plenty of room to move and a decent sized bathroom with quirky 'porthole' window through to the sleeping area. Generous array of toiletries provided along with bottles of water which is a nice touch.We arrived at 7pm at night and had dinner at a fantastic restaurant at Tokyo Station. Anyone who knows Japanese staions will know if you are close to a decent sized one you won't go hungry! Getting to our Shinkansen in the morning was a breeze after a quick check out and less than 5 minute walk down the street.
Very clean hotel, steps away from main Tokyo Station.Small room but fine for single business traveler without too much luggage. Larger rooms may be suited for 2 people.

We stayed for 5 nights at this hotel. Upon arrival at this hotel, we were greeted by very friendly staff who spoke good english. The room size was quite good for Tokyo standards, the room was newly refurbished so it was very clean and modern, the bathroom was fantastic and it had a super toilet and the hotel very close to Tokyo station. If you follow the instructions on how to find the hotel, you will not have too many issues. Tokyo station is a very big station and can be very overwhelming. We found it difficult to get an American breakfast close to the hotel (hotel only serves Japanese breakfast) and the staff at the hotel were not able to help out too much. They gave me 2 cafe names but one was a cafe that allowed smoking and the other was Starbucks which does not really serve a great breakfast. This was a problem for us because we have a toddler that wants to eat toast and eggs for breakfast.
user_name:
Judy G
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: We chose this hotel through trip advisor because we were coming in on an evening flight from KL and this place offers the convenience of walking straight off the Narita Express through Tokyo station to your hotel. I printed off the directions the hotel gives on their website which probably could be improved ,looking for an ivory coloured building wasn’t much help at night , however if you use their instructions cross the road on the zebra crossing turn left and follow the road for around 800mtrs its one of the last buildings on the street. You will probably see the Rose & Crown bar before you see the hotel sign as this is right next door.We tried to book directly with the hotel however the website said that they had no rooms available so we booked a standard semi double room through Agoda. The room was small i.e. one person had to be on the beb to allow the other one to walk around , however on the plus side the bed was comfortable , the free toiletries the best we have ever used in a hotel and the rooms extremely quite. We didn’t hear any noise from the adjoining rooms or outside.Because it’s in the business district & its proximity to the station and Daimaru there were plenty of options when it came to eating that didn’t break the bank. Another major benefit was that it’s only a couple of minutes walk from the Nihonbashi Metro station, walking distance to Ginza and the Imperial palace. All in all this is a great place to stay.

Super handy for onward travel from Tokyo. The directions from the train station were easy to follow. The room was, as expected, on the small side but how much space does one person need for an overnight stay? The staff were delightfully friendly and the rooms had all you could need and more. I will absolutely be back when travelling through Tokyo again.

Good points, walking distance to nearby Tokyo station so easy access to JR railways shinkansen and other trains, metro, and buses if using it as a base for visiting nearby cities. With the JR rail pass you can use the Yamanote line that circles Tokyo. You must be observant to spot the hotel sign since it’s more of an office building with hotel rooms starting about mid-building and lobby / restaurant on the top floor. To reach the hotel, enter a small elevator lobby just inside the main building entrance. Hotel is maybe 2-3 blocks north of the station above ground, but after a while in the area you realize that you can almost reach the hotel underground in the maze of shops, restaurants, below street level around Tokyo station.Basic business-style rooms and no view unless you like looking at nearby office buildings. Single rooms are small with basic accommodation having no closet, but hangers on a hook for clothes. Below the hangers was a bench/single-drawer that had space for a small in-room safe. Nice touches are complimentary Tokyo mini-map (on the bed on check-in), daily bottled water, and room slippers. There’s also a “low-tech” foot massager for those long days of walking around Tokyo sightseeing. Room is equipped with a modular, compact bathroom with one of those technically-advanced Japanese toilets. The bathroom did have a strange feature – a large porthole window over the bed – maybe to watch TV (though the angle is difficult) since there's also a speaker system to hear the audio from inside the bathroom. The room compactness and porthole really made me think of a ships' cabin - Ahoy Matey!

This looks like a new hotel - it has no reception on the ground floor / street level - so, when you arrive with bags you have to take a lift to the top floor reception and a staff member will come down with a cart to help with your bags. We stayed 1 night on arrival in Tokyo having taken the limo bus from the airport and then 4 nights when we returned to Tokyo to leave Japan. The 1st night was in a junior suite which was very good but one side of the queen bed was hard up against the wall (which is common to all of their junior suite rooms) which is OK if you are a single or happy to climb over to find your side of the bed - which we aren’t! So, we upgraded to a full suite which was excellent. The room was large and during both visits the staff could not be more helpful.
Stayed here for 4 nights. The hotel is great for the price and couldn't be in a better location for exploring Tokyo. The staff were also very friendly and spoke excellent English.

I love this hotel because its just walking distance to the tokyo subway station which is ideal when you still want to walk around Tokyo at nights. Its walking distance to lots of Japanese restaurants and cafes. There's also a KTV bar near if you want to sing your heart out. Their bed is so fantastic it has a genius system that allows you to configure what time you want to wake up. The bed vibrates too! I had an amazing stay there.

Tokyo is so vast and sprawling that it's not an easy task to pick out suitable accomodation. I decided on somewhere near Tokyo Station as I was going to be using the Narita Express to travel to and from Tokyo and also the Shinkansen for my trip across Japan.Hotel Ryumeikan had a very good rating and availability for the the beginning and end of my month's holiday and it completely lived up to that ranking.The hotel is just a couple of blocks and a few minutes walk from Tokyo Station so once you've worked out which exit to use (the hardest part) getting there is a breeze. There is also a subway station about five minutes walk away from which you can get to just about anywhere using Tokyo's superb transport system (when arriving at Narita airport buy a Narita Express + Suica card, the latter can then be used on all rail lines within Tokyo including subway and private lines).I was a little early for check-in so I left my bags at the hotel and went to explore. When I returned my bags had been delivered to my room.I had a semi-double room on the 12th floor with a nice view over downtown Tokyo. The hotel occupies the top section of an office block so all rooms will be on high floors. The reception is on the 15th floor.The bedroom was small (as many are in Japan) but with a double bed. The only possible drawback could be if you required storage space for clothes as there was none save for a few hangers. The bed was very comfy though and they provided a fresh yukata and bottled mineral water every day. There's also a fridge which is left empty and not filled with the usual overpriced booze.External noise levels were very low and I had some of the best nights sleeps of any hotel (although the sake may have helped!). Free Internet was available via a ethernet cable or fast WiFi. There were also Ice and vending machines on my floor and a coin-operated washing machine and dryer which was very useful as I never really saw a lot of laundromats. The bathroom had a full range of amenities which were replenished everyday. The toilet was a typical Japanese one with bidet,washing functions and a heated seat (a very nice way to start one's day). Everything was neatly arranged to the extent that all the nozzles on the soap dispensers were turned so that they all pointed in the same direction!)I never saw or heard the housekeeper but the room and bathrooms were kept spotlessly clean. There was a restaurant next to the reception on the 15th floor but as the hotel is located on the edge of the Ginza entertainement district there didn't seem much point in using it. There's also an English style pub by the ground floor entrance.At street level Tokyo can be quite difficult to navigate so I'd highly recommend getting a portable WiFi device (there are several companies you can rent one from who will deliver to your hotel) to use with your smartphone.Even more impressive than the hotel though were the staff who couldn't do enough to help me with any requests. They booked several restaurants for me and even let me know when the chef at one of them had moved to a different location. Well worth sending any special requests ahead of time to them.I'm already planning a return trip to Japan and the Ryumeikan will be top of my list for accommodation in Tokyo.

Really easy to find (even with jet lag). Make sure you come out of Yaseu North exit, cross the road, turn left and it's about 2 mins walk (with luggage), hotel on the right, reception on 15th floor. It's an oasis if calm with Japanese high tech toilets. We economised on the smaller double, the room was quite small but everything in it was of a very high standard and bed was normal size. We thought breakfast was too expensive ¥2,500 there is a 24/7 mini supermarket next door that sells an abundance of take away food and a coffee shop 2 doors up, and many restaurants just round the corner.We walked to the tuna auctions, took about 30 mins, and walked back through Ginza the very expensive part of Tokyo. We went to Shinjuku, the manic neon light area and were releived to get back to the peace and calm of this hotel and the area. I would stay there again for price, location and ambience.

We picked this hotel for our brief stays in Tokyo at the beginning and end of our trip. It's very conveniently located near to Tokyo's main station, so for arrivals both by Shinkansen and the Narita Airport express service. Best exit for the hotel is Yaesu North, cross the road, then go left for about 100 yards. The reception is on the top floor which initially caused some confusion.We had a more basic room for our first stay, which was nevertheless comfortable, quite compact, but had everything we needed. Our second stay we went for the slightly nicer room with bathroom divided into shower/bath room, toilet (complete with automatically opening toilet lid and the usual inbuilt bidet) and basin room. The staff were always polite, friendly and helpful, example including helping us book Sumo tickets, and getting a cab for our red eye excursion to the fish market. They also remembered that it was my girlfriends birthday on our second visit and sent us up some complimentary bubbly...a lovely touch. Next to reception there is a small restaurant which does a nice buffet breakfast and evening meals. It's not the cheapest, but if you don't fancy going out it's decent.As another reviewer mentioned, if you want the livelier part of Tokyo, head to Shinjuku, this seems more of a business area, but it's close enough to Ginza (about ten minute walk) for more upmarket shopping and Chuo for the fish market. I would recommend staying here.

I stayed 4 nights in the Hotel Ryumeikan in Tokyo.I booked a Forus room. The room is not huge but actually not bad for Tokyo standards. Let me start with the Amazing bed in the Forus room ... it lulls you to bed coordinating gentle vibration, synced with relazing music as well as light dimming.The bathroom is great, top of the range Toto and if you are a Toto Washlet connoisseur, I'd say the best Toto Washlet I have ever had in a hotel! Finally the amount of little nice things in the room, amenity wise is amazing. From air ionizer, to spray to deodorize clothes, a super comprehensive set of bathroom toiletries ... Location is good - perhaps a little CBD - but with great links ... Tokyo station, Nihombashi and Otemachi metro stations all can get you anywhere in central Tokyo fast.

If you're going to be in Tokyo for a couple nights and you want to stay out late in the more lively spots, I would suggest staying in Shibuya or Shinjuku instead of Chuo, but if you are looking for a convenient, comfortable place to stay on your way in or out of Tokyo, I think this hotel is perfect. It's quite affordable for this area and it feels like a luxury hotel. The location is very convenient - just two blocks from Tokyo Station where you can easily catch the Narita Express or Sobu Line to Narita airport. Tokyo Station is a huge transportation hub so you can pretty easily get anywhere in the city from here by subway or JR Train. There is a 24 hour convenience store right next door to the hotel. The area around this hotel is real swanky, which was fun to experience, at least for one afternoon. The rooms are small and ours, on the 13th floor, lacked any kind of view, but they're so thoughtfully designed and decorated that you barely notice, and the bathroom was very spacious for a Tokyo Hotel - the shower was especially nice. I loved the little espresso maker they provided in the room. This was a great place to relax on our last night in Tokyo.

Approx 5 mins from Tokyo Station, but also benefits from a few other close by subway stations. Very easy to find.+vesLocation - good for transport linksClean functional roomStaff very helpful and even surprised us with birthday bubbles in the room.Walking distant to Ginza - 10/15mins-ves Stayed in shinjuku previously which is more happening, the area around the hotel is quiet from 11pm.

After 3 nights at the imperial palace, which was really O.T.T. for my tastes, this hotel came as a real nice surprise. The room are spacious, really well soundproofed and the location near Tokyo station is really practical. The service at the reception is a bit cold and intimidating : are 6 members of staff really required behind such a small counter ? Buffet breakfast was 100% Japanese but nice.

We stayed overnight at the Ryumeikan, between flying in from Sydney and departing by Shinkansen for Kyoto the next morning. It's a great location, a short walk from Tokyo Station, with plenty of local restaurants. The reception was smoothly efficient, the staff helpful, charming and english speaking and the room was delightful. (NB We booked a standard double which was spacious by Tokyo standards, and very comfortable. Smart decor and an amazing bathroom! The semi-double is much smaller but could accommodate 2 people at a squeeze.)The only problem was that, arriving on Friday night around 7.30, most restaurants were full of office workers enjoying the end of the working week and seats were hard to come by!

The Hotel Ryumeikan is an excellent choice for visitors to Tokyo. It is located a few minutes’ walk from the Yaesu North exit of Tokyo Station (once you exit and cross the main street, turn left and walk three blocks). Tokyo Station is absolutely massive, but if you follow the signs to the Yaesu exit you’ll be fine. The hotel lobby is interestingly on the 15th floor of the building, and the guest rooms are located on floors 8 through 14. The staff spoke decent English and were very helpful. The hotel lobby, hallways, and rooms are kept in immaculate condition. Our “semi-double” room was small even by Japanese standards, but its functionality made up for its size. There were many power outlets, the lighting was able to be controlled from several places within the room, the thermostat worked well, and the window opened enough for a breeze to come in. The bathroom was larger than expected, and the amenities provided were all top-of-the-line. The hotel has complimentary wired and wireless access in the rooms, and wi-fi is available in the lobby. There are coin laundry machines & dryers on the 10th and 12th floors for guests to use – detergent is added automatically. There are also vending machines on each floor – choices vary, but you can get tea, coffee, soft drinks, and beer. As mentioned above, Tokyo station is nearby, but the closest subway station is actually Nihombashi (out the hotel entrance, turn right and go around the corner), and it is an easily-navigable station with a few lines running through it. Also, within walking distance of the hotel are plenty of shopping and dining options, as well as the Imperial Gardens. This hotel is a great choice for anyone visiting Tokyo for a few days.
Just across the road from the main station, this hotel is in the centre of everything. Very clean & compact room with free water & wifi. Would definitely stay there again

Compact, but perfectly clean and efficient. Comfortable sleeping in spite of tight room. Free wireless and water provided. Good, strong shower plus all the little toiletry/amenities provided. Location is right across from major metro stop (Tokyo) and very lively night time restaurant scene.Room was virtually windowless. That is, it had a window, but it didn't open, nor could you see out of it. Further, they only allowed me to extend my checkout time (11 am) by one half-hour.
user_name:
Aroundtheworldeater
New York City, New York

review_body: Walking around the hotel, you just know that you are in a CBD location instead of where the action is. The hotel is located very close to Tokyo Station but is a distance away from Ginza. Food options around the area is not as plentiful as we would've liked, but you could find them in a short walk.We enjoyed the Forus B room. Boyfriend really liked the bed that lulled you to sleep with relaxing music and soft vibrations at the foot of the bed, but I thought the vibrations were actually quite distracting. No chance of me waking up to vibrations and soft music either. The sleep itself was comfortable.I did not like the idea of paying 1,000 yen for access to English shows - otherwise you were stuck with the normal Japanese channels and BBC. Wifi worked well.Loved the bathroom. Ryumeikan Hotel provided the biggest complimentary toiletries basket I have ever seen. Everything from shampoo/conditioner, body soap, sewing kits, shaving kits, lotion, toner, moisturiser, toothbrush, comb set, etc. The bathroom was relatively roomy. The rain shower feature was very nice. Also booked a Universal room for an older travel mate. The room was much roomier and came with a massage chair.Tried the Japanese breakfast (at 2,500 yen per person). Everyone left breakfast feeling duped. It was buffet style Japanese breakfast, so understandably the food had the left-on-bain-marie-for-too-long taste. I thought the food was adequate, but not at 2,500 yen.The location is a distance away from Shinjuku/Shibuya, even Roppongi. But all accessible via taxi.If you prefer to be closer to the action, I'd recommend other hotels in the Shinjuku area.
Stayed 1 night. Very easy to find from Tokyo Station. Decent size rooms( for Tokyo) modern, clean and excellent service.

Our budget did not extend to the top ranked international hotels so we tried this one and were very happy with the whole experience. Conveniently located to explore Tokyo by train, in a quiet area despite it's centrality with plenty of nearby eating options. What impressed us most was the cleanliness of the rooms, good amentities and very helpful and patient Reception staff. Being a smaller hotel, there is no Concierge as such but every one of the front office staff were English speaking and were happy to take the time with any of our sight seeing plans including bookings, maps, and hand writing directions for taxis (be aware that Japanese written notes are the best way to give the taxi driver the info they need to find your choose of the thousands of restaurants on the hundreds of lanes in the impressive myriad of civilized suburbs comprising this great city). Nice people, efficient transport, fabulous food and interesting culture.We've already decided this is the place to stay next time we visit Tokyo.

We spent 4 nights here in Tokyo. The location was great- right across from the train station and Daimaru (huge shopping center with wonderful grocery on bottom level and shops). The room was nicely decorated, decent size and they have free wifi. Like others noted there are no hooks to hang any of your clothes, so we used hangers in the closet. As for places for breakfast there isn't much in this area so it's best to take a right out the hotel and head down the street a few blocks for places. We didn't eat here but it looked nice. Overall a very nice hotel, conveniently located.

I thoroughly enjoyed my stay in this hotel. Decent sized rooms, great amenities in the room, in a very convenient location near Tokyo station. The staff was very helpful and there is free wifi in the rooms. Only slight downside is the fact that the only breakfast they offer is a japanese styled breakfast. On the other hand there is a Family Mart nearby to get water, and Excelsior Coffee makes a decent cup of java!

The hotel room is so smart. Everything is where it should be with one and only one glaring exception. There isn't a retractable clothe's line in the shower. So there is almost nowhere to dry towels or hang clothes in the bathroom. Aside from that, the room is excellent. The location is fine, though the business district is far sleepier than Ginza. Finally, don't expect much help from the reception desk in terms of directions or making restaurant recommendations or reservations. We had problems with all of these on the first and second day and then decided to just ask other people, use Google, etc. to get that information. Overall 4/5.
user_location: New York, New York, United States
user_name:
Henry J
New York, New York, United States

review_body: Spent 2 nights here on our arrival to Japan. Great location, great service and staff, wonderfully comfortable and quiet rooms that are spacious and that is important when traveling with a teenager. We ate in the restaurant both nights and were treated to some specialities the first night that we didn't order which we very nice. Highly recommend and can see why it is ranked number 1.

We really liked the Hotel Ryumeikan. It was very easy to find - just down the block from Tokyo Station at the Yaesu North exit. The very lovely reception area is on the 15th floor. There were several floors (including the ground floor) that were offices and the hotel rooms were in between. These are the things we really liked:- Stylish decor- 2 complimentary bottles of water each day- Nightwear, which we used as robes, came freshly pressed each day- Toilet with all the Japanese buttons (heated seat, sprays, deodorizer)- Big tub and shower with large pump bottles of shampoo and conditioner- English language newspaper (complimentary) in the reception area- Empty refrigerator for you to fill with snacks- Free in-room wifi- Having the train station, shops and dining halls right across the street- Walking distance to Ginza- The staff: although not everyone spoke English, they were all exceptionally friendly There were only a few things that could have made the place perfect. 1. We booked the least expensive rooms and they were tiny. There was virtually no storage - a few hangers and part of a drawer which shared the safe. We managed because we didn't unpack even through we were there for 4 nights. We considered upgrading, but the only rooms left were smoking rooms. They were considerably more expensive and much bigger. 2. On a Friday night, you need reservations to gain entry into most of the local restaurants.The housekeeping staff even folded our nephew's clothes which he left on the floor of the room.

We stayed here on an overnight in Tokyo. Originally chosen due to its proximity to Tokyo station but after staying here we will definitely chose this hotel in the future. It is quite new and spotlessly clean. A different feature is the lobby is on the 15th floor and all of the rooms are below. Literally just a few steps from Tokyo station on the Yaesu side, north exit, it has everything nearby you need. From Daimaru department store and numerous restaurants in the station itself to a variety of restaurants and bars in the small streets nearby. The rooms are smallish but quite adequate even with several large suitcases - which we had. The hotel held these for us when we departed for a couple of days. The bathroom is wonderful. A great Toto washlet toilet and a large Japanese style soaker tub, both in seperate rooms. Free internet is included. Since Tokyo station is the center in Japan for most domestic travel it is a convenient spot. Buses run to Haneda or Narita frequently at the south Yaesu side and of course all of the trains to everywhere. Definitely recommended.

We received a room different from (smaller than) the one we booked, and the receptionists were really rude about the matter. We had a print out of the booking, but they still would not acknowledge it. It worked out in the end, but was a really bad start of an otherwise nice stay. Location good, rooms nice and fresh.

Stayed overnight because we needed quick morning access to Tokyo station. Location is superb and plenty of small restaurants around the hotel, Takashimaya and Daimaru are also within walking distance for those needing to shop.Now, the hotel... It was perfect! We loved every bit of it. We chose the Forus room. It was spacious enough for 2 people, amenities were great, and the unique bed system (night mode = lights off, relaxing music on, with bass vibration) was definitely fun to play with! The rain shower was faultless.The service too was great. We mentioned it was our honeymoon, and we were given a small bottle of champagne! We enjoyed it. Also, complementary bottle of water - 4 of them!We wanted to return (and cancel our other hotel booking), however the hotel was fully booked for that time frame :( We will definitely return the next time we visit Japan.

We stayed in this hotel for five nights in February 2012 in a "deluxe twin" room. This has an advertised 37 square metres and felt very roomy for Tokyo. Each of the full-size beds was reasonably comfortable with a standard pillow and a half buckwheat one. The room rate includes internet (wired and wireless) as well as lots of room amenities.We did not have a Nespresso machine in our room.The hotel is really a three minute walk from the entrance to Tokyo station. However, getting from the Narita Express platform to that entrance will take at least ten minutes (if you do not get lost, as I did).The dinner food in the restaurant was good, but the "last order" time of 8:00 pm on Saturdays is rigidly enforced. There is no view to the South from rooms on floor 8.

I've read some of the other reviews so won't repeat everything. We stayed at this hotel on Jan 2 and 3, 2012. After finding our way out of Tokyo Station with a lot of help, the hotel was right across the street. Took the elevator to the 15th floor reception desk and we were greeted with warm wash cloths and hand warmers (and it really wasn't that cold). The desk people are the most helpful I've ever run across. When we left, the girl at the desk went down on the elevator with us, hailed a taxi and explained to the driver where we were going (the bus station to get a ride to the Haneda Airport). And there's no tipping so this wasn't an attempt to get money. These people are just genuinely nice! The room (described as a FORUS room) was fairly small but had an incredible array of amenities; every kind of toiletry item you can imagine. The amazing Toto toilet had a control panel that I never actually figured out, but touching the toilet was unnecessary. There were buttons to lift the lid, the lid and the seat and close everything. The seat auromatically heated when anyone was in the vicinity and a small light came on in the toilet if you approached it at night!! The bed had an alarm system that vibrated the bed, played soft music and slowly turned off the lights at night and did the reverse in the morning. No cheap old coffee pot. The room was equipped with a Nespresso machine and a separate container to heat water. Each day we got new slippers that were sealed (and quite nice) and instructed to take them with us. Fresh robes were laid out on the bed every day. When we went to the front desk to inquire about a city tour for the one full day we were in Tokyo, the entire front desk staff got involved and made reservations for us; then gave us detailed instructions on how to get to the pick up point. This is a place I would recommend without any hesitation; both for the accommodations and the extradorinarily helpful staff.

Just returned from Tokyo and six nights at the Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo. Selected the hotel based upon TripAdvisor reviews and wasn't disappointed. Although the hotel is in a business district and located on the top floors of an office building, it was a great base for this senior mom/adult daughter team to explore the city. HOTEL RESERVATIONS: The hotel offers a variety of discounts for booking online. I received a 30% discount for booking more than 30 days in advance. I booked approximately 120 days in advance. When I tried to book earlier than that the reservation system was not set up to accept the rate so I kept checking back every week or so. NOTE: The card you use to make the reservation is the card that will be charged upon check out. We wanted to use a different card (one with no foreign transaction fee) than the one used to make the reservation but found out (or at least were informed very politely) we could not switch cards because the hotel staff does not have access to the online payment system. Choose your card wisely before booking online!FROM NARITA TO THE HOTEL: We used the Airport Limousine (AL) coach bus service to Tokyo City Air Terminal (referred locally as "T-CAT") and then took a taxi to the hotel. This route was recommended by the hotel, as the walk from the closest AL bus stop was farther than my mom and I wanted to negotiate in the dark, after a long flight, with our luggage (mom also uses a cane). The one-way fare from Narita was 2900Y per person and our taxi fare was approximately 800Y. The ride from T-CAT to the hotel was relatively short because we arrived on a Sunday evening and there was no traffic. If you take a taxi from T-CAT when traffic is heavier the fare to the hotel will be more.CHECK IN: Reception is on the 15th floor and check in was fast and efficient, especially since all credit card information was already on file. The elevators have a security system; you will need use your room key to access your floor.THE ROOM: Guestrooms are on floors eight through 14. We booked a non-smoking standard twin (two beds) and were very pleased with the room size and location (12th floor, overlooking Sotobori Dori, the street in front of the hotel). Very impressed with the soundproofing -- it was one of the quietest rooms we've stayed in. The room aesthetic consists of clean lines and calming effects. There was plenty of space for the two of us to each have our own "space." We invited two of my mother's university colleagues who are in Japan on sabbatical to see the room and we were informed that it was only a little smaller than their two-room university apartment! In addition to the two beds (each were the equivalent of U.S. full size bed with a firm mattress, and two pillows, one of which was half-filled with buckwheat or something similar), the room had an armless easy chair and matching ottoman, a wardrobe for hanging clothes, a wall desk unit with good surface space, a comfortable desk chair, a humidifier (which we used after a staff member showed us how to turn it on) and plenty of lighting. The sink and vanity were separate from the shower/tub combo and Washlet toilet. The tub is shorter and deeper (by U.S. standards) and the water pressure and availability of hot water is exceptional. The pictures on the website are very accurate as to the room layout and furnishing.ROOM AMENITIES: Free wi-fi, two bottles of complimentary water every day. Small fridge in the desk unit (not a mini bar) and an electric kettle for tea (which is provided). If you want in-room coffee you'll need to bring your own instant, like Starbucks Via.Very nice green tea shampoo conditioner, and bath gel in large pump containers. They were always full, so we suspect the housekeeping staff refilled them every day. There are two drawers underneath the vanity filled with every toiletry and personal care item you could imagine. Be careful about using the moisturizers - they are very runny. When I opened a package the liquid squirted out of the package, ran off my hand, and onto my t-shirt. In addition to slippers, the hotel also provided each of us with a sleeping garment: a white waffle weave, robe-like garment with front buttons.They were replaced fresh every day. HOTEL SERVICE: We experienced excellent customer service, from my email inquiries about transportation from Narita to our day of departure, when a reception staff member escorted us downstairs to the front of the hotel, went around the corner during a rain storm to hail a taxi, and stood over us with two umbrellas as we put our luggage and ourselves into the car. During the week I had transportation questions about using the train to get to destinations outside the Tokyo. I was provided with a detailed train map in English and Japanese and directions for correct train to take. The reception staff patiently wrote out a half dozen phrases in Japanese that we could show a taxi driver once we reached our destination. While our questions and requests were answered in English with varying degrees of fluency it was always with a uniformly high level of courtesy and willingness to help. We never saw the housekeeping staff but our room was always serviced by the time we returned (housekeeping service begins at 10:00 a.m.) and they kept our room meticulously clean and well supplied with water, towels, sleeping garments, and toiletries. LOCATION: Perfect for our purposes. Easy access to the train (the north entrance of Tokyo Station is a three-minute walk; Tokyo Station is also a good place for a meal, as there are a number of restaurants throughout the station - try DomPierre in Kitchen Street for Asian-style curry). Very close access to the subway (Nihonbashi Station, entrance/exit A3, is a one-minute walk around the corner on Eitai Dori). Coffee and light American-style breakfast items are available at Tully's (on Sotobori Dori, across the street from the hotel entrance, next to the post office), Excelsior Caffe (exit the hotel, turn left, just past the Family Mart, a 24-hour convenience store), and Starbucks (exit the hotel, turn left, walk a couple blocks, turn left at the golf store on the corner and it's down half a U.S. block and across the street). Department stores within a five-minute walk: Takishimaya, Mitsukoshi, and Daimaru (don't forget to check out the department store restaurants for sit-down meals and food halls on the basement levels for takeaway). Other places to visit (distance from the hotel is noted in minutes) include the Nihombashi Bridge (Tokyo history and Japan geography - five minutes); Kite Museum (a small space crammed with a fraction of a fantastical collection of Chinese and Japanese kites - five minutes); and the Bridgestone Museum of Art (built during the post-war period, it houses a modest but charming collection of French and Japanese Impressionists, with a smattering of sculptures, including some ancient Greek and Egyptian pieces - seven to ten minutes).The Imperial Palace Gardens are nearby (northwest of Tokyo Station) and the Crafts Gallery (west of the Gardens).After exploring Tokyo and making discoveries, either locally or farther afield, we always looked forward to returning to our room for what we knew would be a relaxing and restful night's sleep.

Rooms is more space than other hotel in Tokyo. It's clean and have more amenities , bathroom is good and shower is good function . Bed and pillow is make you sleep well. Great interior !!Location is near JR Tokyo station and have continent store.Staff is gentel and helpful good in English.

I stayed at the Ryumeikan early November 2011 for 2 days in a Forus B (Success) room.The Ryumeikan is just across the JR Tokyo Station (literally and figuratively) and is therefore only 3 minutes on foot from the Yaesu North Exit of Tokyo Station. This is very convenient if you are taking the N’EX (Narita Express) or the Airport Limousine buss from the airport. You won’t have to take a taxi or subway to reach the hotel since the hotel is just across the station. In addition if you need to take the Shinkansen you are also just across Tokyo Station. The hotel is also right around the corner (literally and figuratively) from a Nihonbashi station exit/entrance.Once in the building you need to take the elevator to the 15th floor where the lobby (and check-in) is. There is nobody to welcome you or help you with your luggage on the ground floor though, not a problem since the elevators are right beside the entrance of the hotel.Check-in was quick and the staff always polite (you’re in Japan after all). I was informed/reminded of my restaurant reservations as well.My room , a Forus B (Success) room, was small (any room in Tokyo will be small) but it’s wasn’t cramped at all. The layout was very efficient even though there was a double bed, desk, and couch in the room. The room looked new and is quite modern.I was actually surprised about the free amenities in the room: slippers, internet, Nespresso machine, bottled water, toothbrush, razor, and lots of other toiletries. I wish chain hotels would offer these amenities as standard as well (yeah, I think I will have to keep on dreaming though)… The bathroom does not have a tub (expected for such a small room) but came with a shower booth that had a big rain showerhead. Fantastic was to start or end your day (water pressure was great btw)! The toilet was a Toto washlet (a super fancy toilet) that had an electric lid and (heated) seat, automatically flushed, front/rear washing, and dryer among other things. There is also a good sized sink with enough counterpace.The bed was also interesting. It lulls you to sleep or wakes you up with the use of a vibrations in the bed, lights, and sounds… Very interesting, relaxing/soothing, and effective.I only had breakfast (a buffet) once in the hotel (the restaurant’s name is Hanagoyomi and is on the 15th floor) and it was overwhelming. It’s an extensive and very heavy breakfast which could probably pass as lunch.The concierge was very always helpful in answering any question, directions, places, stores, anything.Checkout was quick and efficient as well.Next time when I will be in Tokyo I will definitely stay at the Ryumeikan again since it is a very good base when visiting Tokyo.

Stayed here for combination of business for my husband and then another week for pleasure. Not a stand alone hotel but connected to an office building just ~ two blocks across from the recently renovated Tokyo Train Station and New City shopping and eating galore! Lobby is at the 15 floor along with a small Japanese restaurant where one can enjoy a full Japanese only breakfast. The breakfast can be overwhelming to an American who's used to cereal or toast and coffee in the mornings, as it includes lots of steamed veggies, braised meats, salmon, rice, miso soup, etc. Great every once in a while but not everyday! If you want simple, then got down the street to local coffe house and get your danish and coffee there. Rooms were very nice, quiet and updated. Washer and Dryers available on certain floors for those wanting to have clean clothes during your stay. Very helpful Japanese staff can speak English and can guide you to special sights and eateries. Very close to the famous Takashimaya Dept. Store, Nihonbashi Mitsukoshi Main Store, and the Imperial Palace area.

We have stayed at other hotels near by like the Marunouchi and Grand Palace but this hotel did the trick at a very reasonable (for Tokyo) price. Easy access walking with luggage from Narita express and only 5 minutes to the Shinkansen, this hotel was no frills but just what we needed.Lots of restaurants and bars around and a starbucks and other coffee chain a minute away for breakfast!. Rooms are compact but well designed ( as usual in Japan) and free internet access in the rooms! All the usual room amentities ( more in Japan than most countries, even in lower star rating hotels!) Conceige was very helpful in assisting us with maps and information for where we wanted to go in Tokyo! Hotel web site has great maps and directions for walking from Tokyo station with photos so it was super easy, even with luggage! Will stay again if the price is right but will compare to Marunouchi and Yaesu Terminal hotels.
Checked into this hotel for 3 nights in January. Rooms were super clean and the amenities were plentiful. The location was close to Tokyo station. Would definitely recommend this hotel.

Firstly, the hotel is really excellent from any aspects :- Design, rooms, foods, service, location etc. Though it was my first visit to the hotel, I felt it very homely and thanks to the friendly behaviour of the staffs! I would love to be there soon!

We enjoyed our stay and got a really good rate online - so very good value!Positives- Very close to Tokyo Station: we arrived after dark and found it easily - about a 3 min walk.- Many supermarkets, restaurants and department stores very nearby.- Convenience: We walked to Ginza in 10 minutes most days. Easy to take metro anywhere!- Shower didn't look that much... but had amazing water pressure.- Clean.- Staff friendly and helpful.Negatives- Small rooms - but that is the same as most places in TokyoWe would stay again.

The Hotel Ryumeikan is the perfect base for your Tokyo visit. It is conveniently located close to Nihonbashi, the Imperial Palace and grounds, the Ginza shopping and theater district, and Tokyo Station where you can get many local subway trains as well as the Shinkansen high speed national train system. Dozens of taxis are lined up waiting to take you anywhere in the city or beyond.This review is based on our 3 day stay at Hotel Ryumeikand in a standard twin, non-smoking room in November 2011.The spacious rooms at the Ryumeikan are decorated in a simple but elegant style and have stunning city views. The beds are heavenly with large, soft pillows and smooth, soft linen. The rooms are very private and quiet. Heavy curtains keep out early morning light but glide back to show a floor to ceiling view of vibrant Tokyo. There is a large desk and ample closet and bureau space. A large chaise longue by the windows give the room the feel of a suite. Everywhere in Japan hotel guests are provided with night wear. At the Ryumeikan, the wonderful soft cotton pajamas and yukatas are especially comfortable.The bath is well appointed with plenty of room for toiletries, many bath amenities and luxurious towels. For those guests planning a longer stay, the hotel provides excellent, clean and inexpensive laundry facilities on every floor. In addition, high speed internet access is free.The staff at the hotel is fluent in English and are very helpful. Because we had two large suitcases, the staff quickly arranged for a second luggage rack. They helped us with dinner reservations, tickets for the Kabuki Theater, and helped us figure out how best to get to Haneda Airport for the domestic flight we were taking as part of our visit to Japan. In our experience, most cab drivers speak only Japanese. If you are concerned about telling the driver your destination, the hotel staff will arrange for a taxi and provide you with a return address card which can be very helpful.In passing, I would like to mention that we traveled to Japan on Japan Airlines (JAL) because they offer foreign visitors a special "yokoso fare" on up to five domestic flights. While the trains are a wonderful way to travel while in Japan, the yokoso fare is more economical and faster if you plan to travel longer distances.And two final tips: When attending the Kabuki, be sure to pack a picnic to enjoy during the long intermission. It is the customary thing to do! Make it a special bento or some wonderful bread, cheese, fruit and wine purchased at the bustling but sophisticated food markets in the basement levels of Ginza departments stores like Mitsukoshi or Matsuya. Mitsukoshi also has a branch very close to the Ryumeikan in Nihonbashi. If you arrive in time for the 10 AM opening of this store, you can watch the store staff perform their traditional store opening and special greeting. American tourists will be amazed by the large number of store employees who are friendly and helpful and eager to provide first rate customer service.

We stayed at this hotel for 3 nights. We had a double room which was perfect. The hotel was very close to Tokyo station, only a 3 minute walk. This meant that it was the perfect base for exploring Japan by rail. The staff were very friendly and helpful, providing us with maps and suggested itineraries of different areas, and even some hot towels when we arrived to check in. We didn't eat at the restaurant so can't comment on that. The room was spotless, had a fridge and the most bathroom ammenity packs I have seen anywhere. I would not hesitate in staying at this hotel again. There is a 24 hour convenience store on the same block as the hotel which is good if you just need a quick snack.
A good modern hotel with city view. the food was awesome especially for the restaurant view from the heights of 15th floor. Clean and elegant. will visit here again on my next trip.

Convenient sums it all up. No frills, at least not when staying in standard rooms. Before we arrived, I had read that rooms are quite high tech with "smart" toilets and "intelligent" beds that wake you up in the morning with some music and massage! Another thing that I was expecting was a Nespresso machine in the room. Well, there was none of that, I am quite certain because all I reserved was a standard room. All of those amenities might very well be present in more expensive rooms, which may also be bigger, as ours was very small, with a small bed and a window that looked out onto a back alley and a fire escape. However, the hotel is 1. very affordable for Tokyo and overall quite pleasant with very nice reception staff, and 2. very conveniently located close to Ginza with all of the shopping and fabulous restaurants, as well as next to 2 major metro stations, which makes getting around very easy. Traveling to/from airport is quite easy as well. Beware of Narita Express trains, which cost 3 times more than regular subway and only save you 15-20 mins. Do you research on transportation before you go.

We travelled as a family of four, the children are 16 and 17. It's difficult with teenagers because you don't want to share a room,( not that you would find one big enough anyway in Tokyo) so you are stuck with paying for two rooms. The Japanese room at this hotel is the perfect solution. It is divided with a sliding screen, lovely bedroom on one side and dining area on the other. Two extra mattresses and bedding were all made up for us in the dining side and were very comfortable for the girls. Free drinks in the fridge, fantastic bathroom with loads of toiletries and we requested the balcony room which we got, was also a very nice touch, although there is no view. Location excellent and finally, the staff are superb, extremely helpful and efficient. Based on the suite we had, I would definitely recommend this hotel.

So closed to all forms of public transportation in Tokyo. Not the biggest room you may find compared to modern Western style hotels but there is plenty of room for 2 large luggages. Bathroom size big with western style bath tub and shower head. Good sound barrier. Very clean. Modern hotel. Are there lower price hotels in Tokyo? Yes. Will they have the same convenience, amenities, or room quality as Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo? Probably not.Staff was so awesome. Printed maps and wrote down directions on various places we want to go. Arrived @ hotel early and had a late flight out of Tokyo so hotel allowed us to leave baggage with no extra charge. Safe. Can't say enough about the location and the hotel's helpful staff members.Tokyo JR Station also has Daimaru Dept Store attached, which has a large food court and large of shopping options. This hotel is great choice for business, sightseeing.
Very clean, modern, hotel with large rooms by Tokyo standards. Convenient location near Tokyo station. Would recommend.
Great location for travel, good and pleasant service, internet booking ahead of time great value.

I had a very good deal by booking in advance. Room was new and clean, spacious, and quiet. The hotel is located across from Tokyo Station, great for getting anywhere in downtown Tokyo, great for shopping and eating out as well. Having coin operated washer and dryer in the hotel was really nice, and staff was helpful. Only minor problem I found was that there was no good place to dry your bath towel after you use it once. Towel bar in the bathroom was set low and because it was right where you shower, it doesn't dry and would get wet if anyone uses shower.Except for that, It was very nice hotel, would like to stay there again.

I had to spend one night in Tokyo, preferably near Tokyo Station as I had an 8am Narita express train to catch to the airport the next day, and found the Ryumeikan on TripAdvisor. It was voted 2nd best in the area of Chuo (1st best was fully booked!). I found the price per night quite reasonable - cheaper than a night in a 3 star in London! - and wasn't disappointed.Now Japanese standards are high, we all know that, but this was pure luxury! It is literally less than a 5 minute walk from the MASSIVE Tokyo rail station if you exit by the north exit, and you will spot the tall building straight away as it's clearly marked. Reception is on the top 10th floor, which was a bit weird, but service was excellent and very attentive. My room was impeccable, sound proof and clean, fully equiped with more than you could ask for. The bathroom was pure luxury, the toilet detected that I was in the room so it would heat up the seat as soon as I entered the room, and you don't even have to touch the lid or the seat, a button will do it all for you! The toilet control panel looked like a stereo sound system and had all the usual levels of spray for the "front" or the "back". The bathroom came with plenty of wonderful towels and the power shower was amazing, it had 3 jets and it was more like a wet room, it even had a stool inside so that you could have a little sit down to enjoy it all - I the same installed in my house! The room is equiped with more gadgets and goodies than you can shake a stick at: Nespresso machine - I was very excited to use one for the first time and for free! - a basket absolutely packed with all sorts in the bathroom, a safe under the bed, a fridge (empty but handy), free bottles of water, free internet, free slippers, free origami (!) a humidifier, shoe horn, shoe brush and shoe polish, flatscreen TV, a super equipped "office" area, I was impressed that it even had a kettle and mugs, I thought that was only a UK thing!The bed was pure heaven, it came with 3 different types of pillow but the thing that made a lasting impression on me was the radio alarm system by the bed. The instructions in English were atrocious - honestly I couldn't understand them - but once I managed to get it to work, it woke you up with not only soft music, but soft lighting which got brighter and brighter - very much like a SAD alarm clock - and it even made the bed vibrate very softly to wake you up! What a lovely way to start the day!The Chuo area is mainly a business area so you might find it a bit quiet and dead at night. If so, head down to Ginza, which is only about a 15min walk and you will hit one of the most exciting and visually stunning areas of Japan. There are plenty of restaurants, game centres, shops and vibrant "yakitori" restaurants with outside seating and friendly, inviting staff, I loved it!
