If you want to venture further into crazy Shinjuku, the Tokyo metro in Tokyo station is very handy.I didn't get a chance to try out the restaurant but I'm sure it's an equally amazing experience. All in all: amazing, it made my short stay in Tokyo very special and comfortable, (specially as I had spent 2 weeks volunteering in the north of Japan helping out with the tsunami clear up and the manual labour and basic accommodation were killing me) and hopefully I will stay there again one day.

I spent a night here in the middle of a business trip, with a colleague. It's a good quality upper-mid range business hotel, new and fresh. The pricing was at the upper range for this style of hotel, but occupancy seems high (couldn't book all the nights we wanted) and it's a very short walk to Tokyo station, so very convenient.The reception is on the top floor of the hotel. Check-in was fairly quick and efficient. As is usual for business hotels, you pre-pay the room charge. The room was comfortable, with a good bed and working space. The wireless internet was free and worked well throughout the hotel. There was one of the highest-tech toilets I've ever used (in the land of high-tech toilets), and a good quality unit bath. Everything was clean, bright, and well designed.Check-out was as efficient as check-in, and the service was as polite and helpful as you might expect. We didn't eat in the hotel so can't comment on the food.This would be a good choice if your business meetings are spread across the city, or if you need an early train or come in on a late one.

I stayed Hotel Ryumeikan with my boyfriend the first week of Nov, we loved this hotel!First of all-it's right opporsite Tokyo Station, it's really 3 mins walk, also 1 min walk to Niponbashi station-direct line bring you to Asakusa and Shibuya!On sat night we were wondering around where to go and drink-as a lot of places around Tokyo station are closed, the reception lady was very friendly(forgot her name though), she searched internet and circled some places on a map, and also show us how and how long to reach those places.I'm on business trip all the time to Japan, i'll come back again and stay in Hotel Ryumeikan.

This is a modern, clean, excellent hotel in a great location. We had an inside room so no view to speak of. By booking a month in advance, my partner took a chance but got 30% off. Japan is expensive and every little bit helps. The staff is very polite and helpful. The room was cozy as was the bed (and we are both slim to average individuals). There was an espresso machine! The shower was fabulous, the washlet a mystery. There were about 12 buttons, all in Japanese. Stand clear before you press a button or you might get an unwanted spray to the face!

This hotel is excellent value - conveniently located next to Tokyo Station (once you've found the right exit...), warm and helpful staff, rooms are compact but not cramped, there's a vending machine with coffee and beer on each floor as well as a washing machine for laundry emergencies. Only hesitation in recommending it is that it will be completely booked up next time I try to book a room there.

The hotel was within sight of the central Tokyo, near the train station, it an excellent location for traveler inside Japan. The staff at hotel was very friendly and helpful, the rooms were very clean as Japaneses style. Amenities in the room was modern and light. We stay here for 3 nights before we started our trip to south east Asia. I would recommend this hotel especial because of the central location in Tokyo.

Practically across the street from Shinjuku Station (where you can catch the Narita Express), this place is pretty cool. The lobby is on the top floor, which is strange, and to use the internet in the lobby you need to pay, but there's free internet in the rooms.Speaking of which...The rooms are pretty nice. Modern, lots of amenities and an incredibly gracious staff. The lobby has a killer view (check out the green rooftops) and hot drinks, so it's a pretty nice place to chill out. Didn't have time to enjoy the bar/restaurant, but it looked pretty nice. At $190 a night, right in the heart of Tokyo, this place is a pretty sweet deal, but doesn't feel like a budget option. Highly recommended.

this place has it all! location, wonderful rooms, restaurant and nice reception area on 10th floor with great view. showers to die for. staff is so friendly! i stayed as a member of organization helping Japanese people after tsunami and we got huge discount as sign of gratitude. highly recommended!

Stayed on a Friday night as I was arriving on the last train from Kyoto and wanted to be on an early train to the airport. Booked through Expedia for $200.Arriving at close to midnight, I had to pick my way through the massive crowds of Tokyo Station post-drinkers, which draws attention to the fact that, although very close to the Yaesu exit from the station, the hotel is not actually ABOVE an exit. It's definitely too close for a cab, but it would be a bit of a hassle if you were schlepping more than a little luggage.Room was compact, but ultra-modern and agreeable. The large porthole in the bathroom wall was a neat feature, adding to the relatively spacious feel. Not a room you would want to hang around in, but thoroughly fit for purpose. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who needs to be close to Tokyo Station.

This hotel is absolutely great. I'm going to be honest. I chose this hotel because of the price. I wanted to stay as close to Tokyo Station as possible and not pay a limb. Hotel Ryumeikan is practically across the street from the North Yaesu exit of Tokyo Station. pros:-Excellent Location-AWESOME rooms with every amenity you could possibly want-Modern design-Helpful, friendly, and knowledgeable staffcons:-The view out of my window was of construction in the building next door. (I'm sure rooms with a view are given to those who ask, but I didn't really care for it) Overall, a great hotel! I will definitely be back.

In our visit to Tokyo Disneyland, resort hotels were already full or the price was absolutely insane for just two nights. The best choice was choosing a hotel around Tokyo since to Disneyland it just takes 15mins. by train-keiyo line, maihama sta.- and luckily Ryumeikan Hotel had an excellent summer plan for families checking in after 6pm. 3days-2nights @36000yen,around 300US,was excellent considering the luxury of the room,the facilities and the gorgeous japanese style breakfast! My partner and son loved it.Definitely if we go back to Tokyo again, Ryumeikan hotel will be in our plans!

Currently in Tokyo for a brief visit. SUPERB service with the most friendly staff we've seen! Staying in one of your Western-tatami suites with the open Zen gallery - spacious and impeccable in every way! Our favorite is the large bathroom with the fully automated Toto toilet - complete with heated seat! And of course, we all LOVE your traditional Japanese breakfast buffet. We will surely stay here again in our next Tokyo visit!

I stayed here for 2 nights during New Years. I booked a standard twin room and was really pleased with it's size, cleanliness and comfort. It's located near several subway stations and the main Tokyo station. The room was massive and had a great city view. I joined in with the hotels traditional new years celebration both on new years eve, eating cold noodles which were very tasty and on new years day making mochi.I choose this hotel because of all the good reviews and because of it's location near to Tokyo Station and the Imperial Palace. On the 2nd January every year the Palace doors are open to members of the public and foreigners are welcome too. It was a really enjoyable experience to witness the passion and loyalty of the Japanese people to their Emperor and his Family. I would recommend this hotel and would certainly stay here again.

My wife and I stayed there for 4 nights while visiting friends in Tokyo. The room was superb, the location was great for catching trains/metro and for sightseeing, and the staff were incredibly friendly. We were impressed by the engineering involved in the toilet......felt like we commanding the Starship Enterprise! Didn't try the food there, as there are too many good eating places in the alleys just around the corner from Hotel Ryumeikan.Would certainly recommend this hotel!!Todd and KaraDoha, Qatar

One of the best hotels we stayed at. Knowing how small Tokyo hotels were we chose the double room (32.7sqm) and it was big! alot of room for our luggage spaced out and closet space. very clean and neat! state-of the art toilets (very awesome)large bathtubfree complimentary wifi (ask reception for password)Very close to tokyo station and minimart downstairs.I asked for top floor during booking and they did (though, it was before the earthquake).Reception is on top floor which is very strange but nice. Enjoy some complimentary japanese tea in the foyer and watch the Tokyo skyline.

Perfect spot near Tokyo station - only a few minutes walk depending on the exit you get out of. Rooms were clean and comfortable. Lobby is up the top and rooms on all the floors below - so needed to remember to go up to drop the keycard at reception before leaving! Free internet in room. Would definitely stay here again.

We stayed at the Ryumeikan primarily because of the proximity to Tokyo Station. Location could hardly be more convenient. Staff was very professional and the hotel was extremely quiet. Meticulously clean room. With a family of 4, we do not fit in their standard rooms. During our second stay at this hotel, we asked fort the Japanese room. This room was cheaper than 2 separate doubles. It was huge, almost like a suite. There was even a patio with a Japanese garden. The drinks in the fridge were all free. The room has 2 standard western beds and another tatami room with 2 futon beds. They can be folded up and put away, so that you end up with a separate room with a table and four chairs. This was great for the breakfast we had in the room so that we did not have to pay for the very expensive breakfast in the hotel. You could also go out for breakfast in the area of the hotel. We were amazed at the size of the room and the amenities. If you have a party of 4, go for it! Would go back in a heartbeat.

The hotel is literally 3 minutes away from the Tokyo Station. I had two big suitcases and a big backpack while my wife carried our 2 yr old from the station to the hotel. The staff was great when we first arrifved and when we went to ask them questions. Here's a hint...the male staff is your traditional "all business" and may not always come across as too friendly. We always went to the female staff at the desk. They were extremely friendly and spoke close to perfect english. We had the traditional twin room and it was very large compared to our last stay in Tokyo. The bathroom had awesome water pressure. The green tea shampoo, conditioner and soap were incredible. I can't believe I'm saying this...but I agree with my wife that it was very energizing and refreshing. I'm not sure if it is because the hotel isn't that busy, with everything that has happened, but the room was virtually soundproof. We couldn't hear our neighbours or any noise from outside. It was a great room and we loved our time there. The great thing about it is there is also a self-service laundry on various floors that were very inexpensive.The hotel is in proximity to all the train lines via Tokyo station or the Nihombashi station. There is plenty of food around. We personally loved the food at the Yaesu underground...so many choices at great prices...but so little time since we tried food all over the place.

We stayed here for the last two nights of our Trip in Japan as the Shinkansen back from Hamamatsu terminated in Tokyo station, literally 3 minutes from the hotel, and we could take the Narita Express to the airport also from Tokyo station.The lobby is on the 15th floor and all the rooms are below this. One of the receptionists during check-in had excellent english and all staff we met were friendly. But you don't tend to encounter staff often in this hotel as you don't go through the lobby to get to your room.Also on the 5th floor is a restaurant that looked good but was expensive for breakfast so we didn't try it and a small seating area. Other than that there are no public spaces in the hotel. Vending machines can be found on each floor.We had booked a superior non-smoking double and the room was large and comfortable and equipped with all necessary amenities.The proximity of this hotel to Tokyo station and the Yamamote and Marunouchi subway lines makes it a great location. There is a Starbuck's just around the corner from the hotel and a myriad of eating options (some great choices in the station) down the sidestreets.Would certainly recommend this hotel.

Staying at the Ryumeikan for 10 nights. Booked months ago so was able to get the best rate on their website. The hotel itself is excellent value. Very comfortable 4 stars! A couple of aftershock happened in the first few days I got here. I was sitting near the lift waiting for the maid to finish cleaning the room when the 4.9 aftershock happened. Strangely I felt very safe. The whole building is built to sway gently. Within a few minutes a staff was running up the stairs to calm the guests. In terms of the location there are way too many choices of food around here. The best anago (sea eel) place is just around the corner not to mention the 'eating streets' inside Tokyo Station and around Tokio/Nihonbashi area. I've been here 4 nights and am still excited by the options. Transport wise too it couldn't get any better. The post office a couple doors down has ATM for foreign cards (hard to find in Tokyo). A convenient store is just downstairs too. The hotel also has coin laundry and drinks vending machines. The one small minor disadvantage is the expensive breakfast. I would have love to try it but then again other options are plenty.

We started our honeymoon in Tokyo. Before i get into the detail of the room, i should explain that we were in the hotel when the earthquake struck. I've tried to remove this aspect from the review but in fact it did underline my view that the staff were professional - my only slight comcern was that amongst all of the staff, the level of English speaking and comprehension wasn't advanced enough to help me get the best out of the city. This came to a head a little in our time of crisis!The hotel location is perfect. It's right outside Tokyo Station, which makes it ideal for anyone coming into the city from the airport. It also means that you're on the Yamanote Line, which we used to get around the city. The immediate vicinity is also home to a number of bars and restaurants, which is a bonus.The hotel lobby is great and the rooms are equally pristine and well equipped. This is basically a business hotel but it feels like it has more character than most US hotel chains i've stayed in.All in all a great choice, particularly for first time visitors who have a guidebook and a vague idea of what they'd like to do.

Although I booked this hotel, I didn't get to stay here because my flight got cancelled due to the earthquake. They were incredibly nice (Mr Masaki) & cancelled my booking at the last minute without charging me a cancellation fee. Hope to stay here on my next trip to Tokyo.

A short walk from Tokyo station and the Narita Express, we managed to find the hotel quite easily thanks to excellent directions supplied when we booked, even though we were tired after a long flight from NZ. We had booked a larger room, which was very spacious and immaculately kept. Robes and slippers were provided. The bathroom was an interesting and positive experience for novices to the refinements of Japanese toilets. We did not try the restaurant, and there was no bar as such, although there was a 'pub' on the ground floor of the building. Had I read the room instructions more carefully, I would have found that there was a vending machine to get a drink on another floor. There are plenty of restaurants close by, but ordering a meal tends to require a leap of faith as one is very definitely 'abroad' in Japan. There are coffee shops for breakfast just a few steps away. A very comfortable stay in a convenient location with excellent links to public transport. Would certainly stay there again.

This hotel is exetremely clean with fresh bathrobes and slippers every day. Could not fault the housekeeping and the bed and bedding are so very comfortable. The hotel is only 5 minutes walk from Tokyo Station with Nihombashi underground station just around the corner, There is a restaurant on the top floor but it is very close to lots of small restaurants around the back streets which are interesting and reasonably priced. Would definitely stay here again.

Friends and I stayed at the Hotel Ryumeikan for the final 2 nights at the end of our trip to Japan. Clean, comfortable and surprisingly spacious for a Japanese hotel, it was a great way to end the trip. The hotel is directly opposite Tokyo train station, which makes it super handy for getting around Tokyo and seeing the sites. Comfortable beds and nice bathrooms too.

An excellent choice for location, style, comfort and Price! We stayed with our 1 year old and had a ball. Being so close to the station was god send after a long trip.The staff at the front desk were a little cold but we there to spend time with them. The room was great.We can highly recomend this hotel and we will be back next time we are in Tokyo. Just dont believe the staff when they say the washing machines adds the detergent itself. It doesn't!

This hotel is located very conveniently next to several restaurants, shops, the Tokyo train station and of course the metro station, so one can easily go anywhere from there. The area is very safe. The rooms were modern and elegant, and we loved all the little goodies they had provided us with in the bathroom.

This is a great hotel! The lobby is at the 15th floor with a nice view over the surrounding area. The staff was very helpful and spoke good English. The rooms are on the floors below the lobby. Our room was spotlessly clean and surprisingly roomy for Tokyo. There were more amenities in the room than we had time to explore. The bathroom was a wonder of features and technology.The location is a few hundred meters from the central station and metro stations.I would stay here again.

We stayed in Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo for 3 nights in July 2010. This was the last part of our 10 day trip to Tokyo, Nagoya, Toba and then back to Tokyo. I picked this hotel because in the first half of the trip we stayed in Shinjuku area, and so when we get back from Nagoya, we wanted to stay on the other side of Tokyo. This hotel is 5 min walk from the Tokyo station.It's an easy walk, so the location is convenient, and there is a convenient store downstairs. Location is good if you plan to travel to other areas of Japan, because Tokyo station is right there. The hotel's lobby is not on the ground floor, hence, we had lots of luggage, we had a bit of a problem getting upstairs to check in. Otherwise, the hotel is very good.If you are travelling solo, or a couple of people, definitely suitable and price is very reasonable.We stayed in their special suites. With tatami area in the room. We had three adults, and two kids in the room, the amenities are very nice. Room is very new, clean, and comfortable and very luxurious. Breakfast is buffet style, can't say it is very good, it's only ok in standard and not much variety. It's good if it's included, but if I had to pay, i wouldn't bother.Staff are professional and doing their job.We would consider staying here again because of its location and price.This hotel has many rooms for single travellers at a reasonable rate. Reservations must be made on their website. Changes or requests afterwards also only by online. Airport limousine bus stop is at walking distance, and we were about 20 minutes by taxi from Haneda Airport. We ordered a private transfer through Airporter Tokyo, it was 6200 yen to get to Haneda which was a good price for our group instead of other options.

We had a king size bed in a very comfortable room. The hotel supplied Evian water which was much needed as it was very hot in Tokyo. We enjoyed a Japanese buffet breakfast which was very filling and cost Y2500 per person. The room and hotel was very clean, toilet was extremely modern. We could have clothes dry cleaned at a reasonable cost. we suggest that if you arrive early (before 14:00) that you advise the hotel staff before you arrive. The hotel was fully booked and we couldn't check in early on the morning we arrived. We would happily stay here again. The hotel was close to Tokyo's main station and other subway stations were nearby.

Stayed for 2 nights here since we only had a short time in Tokyo. The location near Tokyo Station was our main factor in choosing this hotel. We didn't want to spend a lot of time getting to our hotel from the airport so this place was really convenient. The room was small but enough space to put our bags down and rest for the evening. The bathrooms are amazing! The rain shower was awesome. Overall, very satisfied with our stay here and would recommend it.

The staff at Hotel Ryumeikan Tokyo was very polite and helpful - on multiple occasions they gave us maps/directions, called to find out about events and availability of tickets (although I'm sure they were secretly amused by the two American girls asking about Sumo tickets!), and helped us figure out the best type of subway/bus/train/etc to get to where we wanted to be. The hotel was immaculate. Definitely also try the tea in the lobby - very good. The rooms were small, which is why the rooms only got 4/5 rating, but it wasn't a surprise after reading other TripAdvisor reviews. Conveniently located across from Tokyo station, it was a great location to start from for sightseeing, especially easy to catch the shinkansen to Kyoto since Tokyo station is the beginning stop. A great value for the area, though there were not many late night food options. Overall, it was a great place to stay!

We stayed here for five nights while exploring Tokyo. The rooms are really nice, has huge windows, and a nice bathroom. The sink is in not in the actual bathroom which is good if you're a family. We didn't spend alot of time aside from sleeping in the hotel room, but as it was such a nice room we went there to relax and rest our feet after walking around in Tokyo.  The staff was quite helpful, helped us to try to reserve a table at a restaurant etc. They speak quite ok english, some pretend to understand you, while others actually do. They also have a small library of guidebooks you can borrow to your room during your stay free of charge, which is great.  The hotel is great value if you paid what we did, around 18000 yen per night for three adults.  The area is good for arriving and departing from Tokyo as it is close to Tokyo station where Shinkansen and Narita Express trains go. The shopping however, is soso. It is close to Ginza, but unless you're shopping for international snob brands like Armani and the likes, it's not so good. There are tons of izakayas close to the hotel, and some Karaoke bars. We didn't find a lot of good restaurants though (except for a great classy sushi bar), but it's close to a subway station so it doesn't really matter. We never tried the hotel breakfast buffet as this was the end of a two week trip when we really couldn't take anymore japanese breakfast (but still loved japanese food for lunch&dinner), instead we went to Illy coffee bar close to Tokyo station which served us cappucino worthy of Italy, excellent croissants, and good sandwiches.

I stayed with a friend in one of the double rooms for 3 nights.Typical of Japan hotels, the room was small but good enough for the 2 of us since we spent minimal time in the room.Most staff at the lobby of this hotel do not speak v good english but the more senior guy did. We were 2 gals looking for help to get our luggage across the street to Tokyo station, we had 2 large luggage each and we were anxious about how we can go about doing so. We seek from the hotel staff and this guy was so rude and unhelpful about it. How about getting a lecture from the staff when asking for help?This just dampened our holidaying mood.In the end we had to move the luggage by making one more trip to the hotel. No help from any staff to try to even help us move the luggage to the ground floor. If this hotel was on discount rate I would still recommend this to travelers for its clean rooms and location. But if you have a better choice (value for $$) spend it elsewhere.

My Wife and I stayed here for 5 nights for the first leg of our 14 day Japan vacation, and we could not have booked a better hotel. The hotel is perfectly located next to Tokyo Station (Just follow the directions on the hotel's website), and is only about a 55 minutes train ride on the NEX train from Narita. The staff all spoke good english and help arranged a luggage forwarding service for us. We stayed in a standard semi-double room, and found that the bed and the room were big enough for the two of us. The bathroom was always stocked full of amenities and clean enough to eat off. What makes this the perfect location for first timers is the location. Being so close to Tokyo station, which is a big station, but not as hectic and frantic as Shinjuku or Shibuya, makes this a great base for exploring Tokyo. There are many great and reasonably priced restaurants nearby as well. We'll definitely return here on our next visit to Tokyo.

Great hotel at a good price in a great location for the Narita Express. I have stayed in cheaper hotels in the Tokyo /Ginza area, that were fine (e.g. Hotel Monterey Ginza is good value for money), but I liked this one the best. If you are sharing a room with someone you don't want to share a bed with and appreciate a little extra space (rare in big cities) go for a "deluxe Twin" - I did as I was with my 17 year old daughter. It was a corner room so had views from 2 windows over Tokyo Station and down towards Ginza - loved it!. Great bathroom set up too if your sharing - with the Japanese style bath/shower in a separate room to the toilet with the basin sepaarting the 2 rooms. Even the toilet had a view. Helpful staff spoke good English as well. I recommend booking online direct with hotel (try the "special recommendation" for a good deal). close to both Tokyo and nihombashi stations. Try dinner or lunch at one of the small booths in Mitsukoshi (mitsukoshi mai store) if you dont want to go to a restaurant - great food at a bargain price and just a few minutes around the corner from the hotel! Or take some food back to your room! There is also washing machines/dryers & drinks machines provisded on 2 floors of the hotel - a useful provision for travellers needed to refresh. Just one word of caution - if you don't smoke - make sure you book a non-smoking room - the smoking floors really reek of cigarettes!

On my first trip to Japan I stayed 5 nights in this beautiful hotel located in Nihonbashi, a very convenient location for people who travels via JR as the Tokyo Station is a few mins walk from the hotel. The furniture of the rooms are very modern, high tech toilet and great ladies amenities, I was staying the in the Premium suite and I had the best view and best service.I highly recommend this hotel for business or leisure,

I booked this hotel on the first and the last night of the trip. Between that period of time I went to Tohku region using Shinkansen so I need hotel that is near to Shinkansen station which there are only two (Ueno and Tokyo). As this website said it is 100% recommend (never saw like this before) so I choose hotel. It was the most expensive one in my trip. Staying in sendai for two nights still cost less than one night here. The lobby was small which is same size as the hotel. However tthe room was quite big (compare to size of hotel) and was very secure, the customers need to scan their key card in the lift before they will be able to get to their floor. That mean other people who didn't stay in the hotel or didn't stay on the same floor can't go to your floor. (i'm not sure if this system is apply to other hotels in tokyo as well) One of bad thing about this hotel is that there aren't any public phone. (As we are foriegner, we don't have mobile phone so public phone is the easiest way to call to our home country) Only few hotel staffs can speak English well. They can do most of the services we wanted them to do.
New comfortable hotel, 5 minutes walk from Tokyo station. Convenient for an overnight stay.

Stayed at this hotel for 3 nights. It is a stones throw from Tokyo train station which is why we booked it as we were getting the bullet train to Kyoto. We stopped in 4 hotels while in Japan and this was by far the best value for money. new modern hotel. Our room was quite big with a lovely spacious bathroom - we only booked the standard room. loads of little personal touches which made the difference. we really liked the toilet which had a toliet seat that lifted and closed automatically. most japanese toilets have heated toilet seats including this one. staff really freindly and couldnt do enough. would definately recommend this hotel1

This is the Ryumeikan Hotel Tokyo: a hotel so brand new that when you look for it in Google Street View all you can find is the construction site!Located 150 meters from Tokyo JR Railway station, and a mere 50 meters from Nihonbashi Metro station, this is as central as it gets in Tokyo and you can hardly beat this location unless you pay a lot more. The fancy stores of Ginza district are just a 10 minutes walk away.We booked "semi-double" rooms online through their site for 130 EUR/night (without breakfast), which is fantastic value for money.Don't be afraid by the "semi-double" name, these rooms are also offered for single use but they are perfectly adequate for double use. The size of the room is definitely above average by Tokyo standards and if you're visiting as a tourist you'll probably won't spend enough time in your room to feel it's small anyway. The bathroom/shower is impressive and the complimentary toiletries provided by the hotel surpass what you can expect in most 5-star hotels.The only negative comment I can think of is the lack of closet to hang your clothes.If you are budget-minded, I would also recommend you prefer the local cafes over the hotel breakfast which is a bit pricey at 1.400 Yen -there are two cafes located just down the hotel with plenty of choice for breakfast and at much cheaper prices.As a conclusion, the Ryumeikan is a brand new and sparkling clean hotel in one of the best locations you can dream of in Tokyo with highly competitive rates. Need I say more?Pros+ Location+ Price+ Fantastic roomsCons (I had to search hard to find some...)- No closet in rooms- No free wireless internet (cable only)- Breakfast a bit pricey

Hotel Ryumeikan is a perfect choice if you're staying in Tokyo for business or pleasure. We chose this hotel for the location, as it is located right infront of Tokyo station's north Yaesu exit. The lobby is on the 15th floor, very nicely furnished with a good view of down town. The staff is extremely helpful. Rooms are a good size for Japan. We had a semi double that was quite comfortable for two people. State of the art toilet and shower. The hotel was very reasonably priced for what it offered. I highly recommend this hotel if this is the area you want to stay at in Tokyo.

We decided to stay at this hotel for the last two nights of our stay in Tokyo due to its convenient location, opposite the train station. We definitely have no regrets and would even contemplate coming back to stay here next time.The moment you step into the hotel's entrance, you are greeted by this woody incense fragrance which instantly relaxes you. The reception and lobby is on the 15th floor of the hotel - whilst the rooms are below. The hotel has a really plush and grand yet comfortable feeling.We were very pleased with the convenience of a laundry machine and dryer on our floor -which costed about 200Yen for a wash and 100Yen for drying (30 mins cycle). The hotel has a laundrette on floors 10 and 12. All floors have a drinks machine and ice machine.The room itself is pretty compact and average space size for a Tokyo hotel. The bathroom is large, with a Western size bathtub - which is also nice as we both like our baths after a long day out walking in the cold in Tokyo. We bumped into another couple who has been staying at this hotel for the 4th time. Clearly happy customers. Bonus part of the location (apart from the obvious proximity to the train station) are the little 'Izakaya's behind the hotel - where there are many restaurants and bars, full of drunk working Japanese at about 9pm. :)
Perfectly located, everything perfect. Large room for Tokyo. Excellent value for money

This hotel has just had a renovation and is super-clean and modern. We stayed in one of the cheaper rooms and were very impressed by it's size and decor. The bathroom is incredible, best shower I've ever seen. The bed was western style queen size and very comfortable. We stayed at the Yaesu Terminal hotel (around the corner) last year and it was nice but a lot smaller rooms and a little dated.This hotel is really close to Tokyo station, which makes it very easy to get on the Shinkansen (Bullet trains) and the Narita express back to the airport. This hotel also has a nice western style coffee shop next door that is awesome for breakfast.Value for money is what this hotel is all about. Some hotels in Japan can easily cost you over $300 US a night and still not compare to this hotel. We got our room for about $120 US and were very impressed by the helpful staff.

Love this hotel, regrated that we only stayed one night.It is a brand new place so the hotel is contemporary decorated and everything is very well design and compact. The location cannot be beaten, 5 minutes walk from Tokyo station and the direction from the hotel website are the best (they even have photograph of what each turn looks like).The amenities in the bathroom are outstanding with specific items for man and woman. The bed was not as hard as some other hotel we stayed in Japan. The hotel staffs are very helpful and doing everything with a smile. BTW, window does open, very important if you are in Japan and got stuck in a smoking room! It is the best price hotel you can find if you want to be around Tokyo station. I will stay here again if I can.
